In effect, this makes students extremely uncomfortable and creates an environment that appears to punish making mistakes (or being unsure about something), as opposed to encouraging learning and individual growth. Similar to the note above about Robert, the fact that members of the teaching staff act in this manner completely TURNS AWAY students from being passionate and wanting to learn physics. Instead, all it causes is students purposely trying to avoid these members of the teaching staff, knowing that asking them for help will only lead to further judgement and frustration. Despite my aforementioned complaints about AP50b, credit is due where credit is deserved – the saving grace for this course and silver lining amidst tons of issues is Kelly Miller, one of the new course heads. This semester, Kelly was introduced as one of the new instructors and began taking over the AP50 series. She will also be the primary course head going forward for both AP50a/b. As an instructor, Kelly is one of the most SUPPORTIVE individuals I have ever met, oftentimes trying to uplift students and encourage them to continue achieving higher. When students have questions, she acknowledges their needs and works to improve their understanding with compassion. As students bring up points of frustration with the class, she remains extremely receptive (and RESPONSIVE) to feedback, piloting new initiatives to try and fix the weak points of the course. Lastly, Kelly is just extremely positive – always seeming genuinely PASSIONATE about the course and as if she wants to see her students thrive. Knowing that Kelly will be permanently taking over the course gives me hope that AP50 will change going forward, with the intent of better supporting the needs of students. As a whole, Kelly should be seen as a role model to AP50 teaching staff on what a genuinely outstanding instructor looks like!Similarly positive things can also be said about the following TFs, who have gone above and beyond to make the class an enjoyable and learning class environment: Tayna Camargo, Alex Buzali, Soy Choy, and Anna Luong. Thank you to each of these amazing individuals for making AP50b more tolerable, and a better learning environment (despite the aforementioned flaws).With this in mind, I think AP50a/b is a great option if you are looking to ensure a good grade in physics and can accept the faults of the course. However, go in with a realistic expectation on the time needed to complete assignments, and an understanding on some of the weak points of the course overall. To any student choosing between PS 2/3 and AP 50a/b, good luck – I wish you the best of luck. Physics is a lot regardless of which course you choose, but work hard and you will get through it.
worse_comment: Be very careful taking this class. if you are a person who is not good with deadlines or a person who THINKS they are good at deadlines, think very critically about enrolling. I thought I was good at deadlines but realized that was for normal classes with normal types of deadlines and workflow. This class is insane and something is due EVERY SINGLE DAY. If you miss one thing you are at risk of your grade dropping an entire letter grade. The teaching staff does not teach nor provide any sort of teaching, guidance, or advice going into the various modules. They are also overly strict about meeting specifications in order to receive a particular grade.  It is really unfortunate that most students leave this course having learned nothing, being unclear about what they did or why, because there is no guidance from staff. If you actually want to learn physics, please take PS2/3/12 etc. I did not care to actually learn so I took it, but if I wanted to learn things I'd be very disappointed with this class.
course_title_2026: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part II
description: AP 50B is the second half of a year-long, team- and project-based introduction to physics focusing on the application of physics to real-world problems. The AP 50A and B sequence, designed for engineering and physics concentrators, is equivalent in content and rigor to a standard calculus-based introductory physics course sequence. Lectures and exams are replaced by interactive, hands-on, and collaborative learning activities that will not only help you master physics concepts and hone your scientific reasoning and problem-solving skills, but also grow your capacity for self-directed learning and develop your collaborative skills.Course Content: Electromagnetism and optics
notes: The assigned course time (Tu/Th 9:45 am to 12:30 pm) includes regular class activities, section activities, and time for project work. There are no other sections or laboratories.

course_title_2025: Quantum and Classical Electromagnetic Interaction with Matter 001
best_comment: Donhee is a great lecturer and this class is super well designed. Homework generally aligns well with what we are learning in lecture and is often a repeat of derivations or calculations covered in class—usually very approachable save a few questions here and there. Definitely recommend having a strong background in quantum mechanics. There’s a lot of mathematical tools and notations (Dirac notation, phasors, etc) that you are assumed to be familiar with.
course_title_2026: Quantum and Classical Electromagnetic Interaction with Matter
description: The first half of the course will cover the interaction of quantized atoms with electromagnetic fields, introducing a number of basic concepts such as coherent Rabi transitions vs. rate-equation dynamics, stimulated & spontaneous transitions, and energy & phase relaxations. These will be then used to study a range of applications of atom-field interactions, such as nuclear magnetic resonance, molecular beam and paramagnetic masers, passive and active atomic clocks, dynamic nuclear polarization, pulse sequence techniques to coherently manipulate atomic quantum states, and laser oscillators with applications. We will also touch upon the interaction of quantized atoms with quantized fields, discussing the atom + photon (Jaynes-Cummings) Hamiltonian, dressed states, and cavity quantum electrodynamics. The second half will cover the classical interaction of electromagnetic fields with matter, with special attentions to collective electrodynamics in particular, magnetohydrodynamics and plasma physics with applications in astrophysics, space physics, and Bloch electrons in crystalline solids.

course_title_2025: Research Practices and Academic Culture in Applied Sciences and Engineering 001
best_comment: Definitely take this class, it is super helpful for research!
course_title_2026: Research Practices and Academic Culture in Applied Sciences and Engineering
description: This course supports new PhD students in finding their research fit, building good research habits, and becoming a researcher. It consists of two 2-unit courses: 290a (spring of G1 year) focuses on adapting to a research group, developing strong reading and writing habits, and preparing students for teaching during their G2 year; 290b (fall of G2 year) focuses on oral communication and on preparing students for the qualifying exam. This course also develops other skills necessary for success in graduate school such as setting goals, peer feedback, research ethics, collaboration and teamwork, and negotiation.
notes: This course is open and optional for all SEAS G1 PhD students outside CS (CS PhD students should take CS 2901/2902). This course can only count as a 'breadth course' towards SEAS PhD requirements.
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: Open to first year Applied Mathematics, Applied Physics, or Engineering Sciences students only

course_title_2025: Research Practices and Academic Culture in Applied Sciences and Engineering 001
best_comment: Definitely take this class, it is super helpful for research!
course_title_2026: Research Practices and Academic Culture in Applied Sciences and Engineering
description: This course supports new PhD students in finding their research fit, building good research habits, and becoming a researcher. It consists of two 2-unit courses: 290a (spring of G1 year) focuses on adapting to a research group, developing strong reading and writing habits, and preparing students for teaching during their G2 year; 290b (fall of G2 year) focuses on oral communication and on preparing students for the qualifying exam. This course also develops other skills necessary for success in graduate school such as setting goals, peer feedback, research ethics, collaboration and teamwork, and negotiation.
notes: This course is open and optional for all SEAS G1 PhD students outside CS (CS PhD students should take CS 2901/2902). This course can only count as a 'breadth course' towards SEAS PhD requirements.
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: Open to first year Applied Mathematics, Applied Physics, or Engineering Sciences students only

description: A course on the application of the principles of many-particle quantum mechanics to the properties of solids. The objective is to make students familiar with the tools of second quantization and diagrammatic perturbation theory, while describing the theory of the electron liquid, the BCS theory of superconductivity, and theory of magnetism in metals and insulators. Modern topics on correlated electron systems will occupy the latter part of the course.
notes: Applied Physics 295b is also offered as Physics 295b. Students may not take both for credit.

course_title_2025: Introduction to Photography: Looking In, Looking Out 1
best_comment: Take this class if you are genuinely interested in learning more about photography as an art, and with purpose. It is a time–consuming class, and requires lots of independent work doing photography during the week, editing the photos, and selecting the best ones, and doing so every week. It has the potential of being incredibly rewarding (which was the case for me, I walk away with strong technical foundations, a greater understanding of this art, and also a keen interest in pursuing my work in the future), but I would not take it if you don't have the time or desire to truly immerse yourself (otherwise it might backfire and make you not like photography). I took it just because I was curious and wanting something different in my schedule, and I walk away with a new hobby and passion that'll last me forever, so I am very grateful, and if that seems to be the case for you, then I would highly highly recommend it. Plus, Richard and Claude are amazing, they are available and helpful, and built a tight–knit class and welcoming learning environment.
course_title_2026: Introduction to Photography: Looking In, Looking Out
description: This course will introduce you to the conceptual, artistic potential of photography. Your understanding and use of the medium will be contextualized within contemporary and historic photographic art practices. Your own art practice based in part from your interior life will be developed alongside technical skills. We will discuss topics such as the ethics of photographing people, how to make meaningful images amid the proliferation of digital images, and traits that are unique to photography. This class is organized around presentations on artists’ work, presentations on photographic concepts, assignments around portraiture, self-portraiture, lighting, studio, still life, landscape, conceptual, and documentary themes, individual meetings with the instructor and breakout meetings with peers to develop your practice, technical skill workshops, readings, reading discussions, group critiques, and visiting artist presentations. Curiosity, a strong work ethic and a sense of adventure are required.
notes: No prior art experience necessary for enrollment in this class. The professor of this course is Richard Renaldi.

best_comment: Genuinely transformative course. If you go through Harvard AFVS without taking this course you are doing yourself and your education a massive disservice. This is one of those courses that reminds you why you go to Harvard. Teaches you everything about the crazy process of filmmaking. Will be a pretty huge and sometimes unexpected time commitment that sneaks up on you but the work is fulfilling and fun. Everyone in your class will feel like family by the end. Robb, Joana, and Vera are all truly incredibly instructors that will help you grow as artists. This is also a class unlike anything you could take anywhere else in the world, the opportunity to shoot such an insane volume of 16mm film and edit by hand on a Steenbeck is not offered at any film school anywhere. Even if you don't have an interest in documentary filmmaking, please please please apply to take this course, I am mainly interested in fiction and feel that I gained so much from taking this.
description: Introductory exercises in live-action 16mm filmmaking culminating in the production of a nonfiction film as a group project in the spring term. Students must complete both terms of this course (part A and part B) within the same academic year to receive credit.
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: AFVS 50A

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!! As a fundamentals/beginners class, you don't need any prior art experience or even need to know how to draw. This class is all about learning from scratch in all sorts of different mediums. Some of them are:– 2D animation (drawn)– sand– clay– puppets– paper on layered glass (very cool)– stop motionJust so so cool. Every week there are exercises (not assignments, and as far as I could tell, not graded) where you learn a new medium. So one class will be dedicated to learned how to use Adobe After Effects, and the exercise that week will be to create a short (maybe 30 second?) long video with some of the stuff you learned. You're not graded on how good the thing you made is, just the fact that you learned how to use anything at all. It's literally the perfect environment for learning because you're encouraged to just mess around.The second–ish half (or maybe last third? time has all muddled up for me now) of the semester is dedicated to the final project. So the first half is working on a specific new tool each week and the second one is mostly self–work. After each week you will have ended up learning a bunch of new techniques and you'll have so many new tools at your disposal, that you can start pitching and idea for a final project. Some people made films that were 2–3 minutes long, and others under a minute. Every single student, with or without prior art experience, made amazing works and I'm so glad to have been able to see them all (and see them being made!)There are weekly screenings every Friday from 12pm–2pm (unless the schedule changes, but it's roughly 2 hours) where we watch a bunch of short animations. Just so so cool. If you can't go, you can make it up by watching them on your own time and submitting your thoughts on each one, but I can't recommend enough to show up in person because 1. you won't have to write anything, and 2. the in–person discussions are just so great.Lastly, the 4–hour long class can seem daunting, but it really does fly by. We take breaks half–way through (I use mine to get lunch lol) and plus it's not 4 hours of intense work, you're mostly sitting around comfortably working on your animation or messing around with puppets or clay.I've learned so much from this class from specific skills to how animation works as a process in general. I feel so much more prepared to animate more in the future, and will be taking the intermediate class too next semester!Ruth is AMAZING, and so is Michael!! They are so kind, patient and knowledgeable and it was just an honor to have been able to learn so much from them. I had a hard time with my final project because I'm a perfectionist, completely overestimated how much I could get done in the time I had AND started way too late (horrible combo), but Ruth and Michael helped me so much throughout the process. They really guided me on how to make my animation better, what to cut, and just generally how to go about it. I seriously cannot recommend enough that you take this class. Even if you're not an AFVS concentrator, you'll have such a fun time taking this as an elective and you'll be able to say you made animations during college lol!ONCE MORE TAKE THIS CLASS IT'S AWESOME !!!!
description: An introduction to the possibilities of animation for absolute beginners.
notes: There are weekly screenings for this course on Fridays from 12pm to 2pm.

course_title_2025: Sight and Sound: Introduction to Narrative Filmmaking 1
best_comment: This class with Tala Hadid and Madison Howard (TF) is incredible. The mini assignments we have before working on our final films help a lot in developing our understanding of the filmmaking process with low stakes and super helpful feedback. They do a really great job of showing us a variety of films. And they’re super helpful as we work through the process of making our final films. Both Tala and Madison are incredibly kind and passionate about their work. If you’re interested or curious about filmmaking in any capacity (fiction or not) definitely enroll in this course. You learn the basic fundamentals of cinematography, sound, editing, and color correction while also learning how to best execute the story you want to tell. I’d say go into the class having an open mind and some ideas of what film you want to make. The last thing I’ll say is Tala brings incredible directors and producers as guests to speak with the class. If for nothing else, having the opportunity to speak to people who work in the industry full time is pretty awesome especially if that’s what you want to do.
course_title_2026: Sight and Sound: Introduction to Narrative Filmmaking
description: A practice based course in which students are introduced to the fundamentals of visual and aural story-telling. During the semester the class will explore techniques of cinematographic production including camerawork, sound recording and montage. Students will make short films and be encouraged to explore diverse forms of cinema from fiction to non-fiction to other hybrid forms. The course will include creative workshops, film screenings and discussions of student work.
notes: The instructor of this course is Tala Hadid.   This is an introductory-level course limited to 10 students. If there are more than 10 applicants, preference will be given to concentrators and intended concentrators in AFVS, for whom there are concentration requirements to fulfill, and then to other undergraduates.

best_comment: Such an amazing course. If you have the opportunity take it. You have to put in the hours in the studio to make it worth it, but if you can you will gain so much out of this class.
description: This course emphasizes the role of composition, color and form outside of representation. How does an artist working outside of nameable objects transfer intent? Far from creating a mess - this course seeks to explore through making, the means, reasons and many definitions of abstraction. Starting with the square - students will move from visual problem solving on two dimensional surfaces into their own projects. While the initial emphasis will focus on abstraction in painting, students are encouraged to branch out into other dimensions as the semester progresses. Rigorous making will be buttressed by discussion, texts, videos and material questioning.
notes: This course is open to all levels, however those with previous painting/ AFVS course experience are encouraged.

course_title_2025: Film Direction: From Script to Screen 001
best_comment: You should definitely take this class if you are committed to working with your ideas over the course of the year and learning from what does and doesn't work and forming close relationships with other filmmakers. Hopefully Alice and Kendra will teach it again sometime, they were a great team!!
course_title_2026: Film Direction: From Script to Screen
description: This production course is an advanced continuation of 150A. It is compulsory for students to have the first draft of their short screenplays on the first day of class. Content includes scene analysis and script revision, directing professional and non-professional actors, cinematography, blocking and mise-en-scène, sound design, editing and post-production. Students will be given assignments related to their written screenplays throughout the course, culminating in what will be their final project: the production of a narrative short film. Film professionals will occasionally be invited to conduct workshops or hold masterclasses with students.

best_comment: AFVS is an amazing place. Classes like this where you use physical materials and get instruction from the BEST OF THE BEST, are what make it so. Robb will forever be my favorite professor at this school and one of my favorite people. He makes you feel insane and sane at the same time, makes you feel like you can be a filmmaker. I am forever grateful for the time I had with him.
description: All work in this course will be shot on 16mm film using Bolex cameras. Some projects will be silent and cut with splicers, others will add a soundtrack and will be edited using a computer. Through a series of non-fiction projects, students will explore the possibilities of the 16mm film image and the freedom of working with silence or in non-synchronous sound. Class time will include technical workshops, film screenings and discussions of student work.
notes: Pre-requisite: One course in video or film production.

best_comment: Best class ever! Amazing break from academics and non–arts classes, made me reflect not just about art but life in general. I took it senior spring and it was a banger
worse_comment: Start thinking about your final project early on because you go from spending no time outside of class to a much more demanding schedule depending on what you choose to do. That might be hard because other classes ramp up as the semester progress too
course_title_2026: Intermediate Animation: Animated Realities--Constellations of Belonging
description: In this class, you will explore animation as a powerful form of personal expression and documentary storytelling. Through a combination of hands-on workshops, weekly assignments, film screenings, and in-class critiques, you will gain experience in both analogue and digital techniques. From flip-books and under-the-camera animation, to rotoscoping and digital drawing, each method will offer a new way to explore your ideas and experiences. You will also learn how to record and mix sound, integrating audio as a vital foundation of your animation. Over the course of the semester, you will build a body of short pieces that will culminate in a final short film—a poetic, personal, and technically rich animation that reflects your unique voice.
notes: There will be weekly screenings for this class on Fridays from 12pm to 2pm.

course_title_2025: The Matrix of the Visible: From Thought to Screen 1
best_comment: Tala is such a lovely professor. She truly went out of her way to help in whatever way she could. She genuinely cares about each individual student and their films.
course_title_2026: The Matrix of the Visible: From Thought to Screen
description: An intermediate filmmaking course that explores through theory and practice (studio workshops, in-class film screenings, critical readings and group discussion) the ground of the moving image and its potential for the creation of shared spaces of invention. Through examination of and experimentation with different approaches to camera-work, mis-en-scene, form, montage and sound, students will be encouraged to expand their perception of the moving image medium. Students will be required during the semester to conceive, direct and edit one short film (8-15 minutes long) in any style or genre (fiction/non-fiction, experimental or other) to be presented at the end of the term.
notes: The instructor of this course is Tala Hadid.   This course is limited to ten students. Admission will be decided upon course application forms submitted and interviews where possible. Priority will be given to AFVS concentrators and CMP students, however students from all backgrounds, experiences and disciplines are welcome.

best_comment: Take it. I am a humanities person, but this was my favorite class this semester. I was terrified at first, but the content and homework turned out easier than I've expected. If you put in effort, I'm sure you'll easily succeed. Psets might be hard to solve on your own, they aren't necessarily tied to the readings rather to lectures, but our TFs were extremely helpful (SHOUT OUT TO MATTHEW AND ABI WE LOVE YOU SO MUCH) This course's TFs are my favorite people on Earth. Extremely smart, kind and helpful. Overall, after every lecture I felt as if I've learned something new, and now I know a crazy amount of random facts about space (which was the initial goal).
description: We will discuss the big questions of astronomy that have engaged scientists and the general public alike for centuries: How did the universe begin? What is the ultimate fate of the Sun? How do planets form? Is there life outside the Solar system? Students will use telescopes to study the night sky and examine how the combination of astronomical observations and physical theory have led to an understanding of the vast and dynamic cosmos we inhabit.

best_comment: Astro16 is one of my favorite courses I have taken at Harvard. Professor Johnson and the teaching staff are absolutely excellent. The format of the class is "flipped" and involves a lot of independent work in group settings through problems, usually after brief lectures by Professor Johnson to start you off and introduce a concept. Personally, since I learn best by doing, this was an extremely effective way to learn. It was so much fun to get to know and learn from and work with the other people in our group, and we formed a close bond over the semester. Also, working in groups to try to figure out ways to tackle these challenging problems is legitimately a really good way to learn. Homeworks were very reasonable on Professor Johnson's part and you always feel very supported throughout the class. I thought the labs were a little bit frustrating, mainly because it felt like we didn't have enough background to write the level of depth needed for the reports. Nonetheless, the night lab where you try to observe an eclipsing binary on the Clay Telescope is REALLY COOL. The midterm exam is a group midterm where you have to explain class concepts to a random person who knows nothing about astrophysics. This is an AMAZING exam format. It really forces you to go back through all the material and make sure you fundamentally understand astrophysical concepts, so you can't get away with just knowing how to use equations. This is not something that we do nearly enough of at Harvard, and I really appreciate Professor Johnson's approach to learning. Whether you are an astro concentrator (and have no choice) or just interested in astrophysics, I strongly recommend this class, and specifically taking it with Professor Johnson!
worse_comment: This class partially killed my love for astronomy. The class was solely based on these worksheets that my group always got behind on, because it was riddled with material never covered in class, where we'd have to jump to crazy conclusions to figure out. Our motivation in the class dwindled severely over time just because we had no support and no idea what we were doing, and other groups just breezed by us because they "got it". Even worse were the labs, complete disorganized messes and the lab reports were horrible. So many things on the lab reports were very complex or not even gone over properly or at all during the lab section, and the teaching staff was extra inaccessible when so many people needed help with the lab reports. I don't think I've ever been so disappointed in something I've submitted for a class than my second lab report. The labs were so separate from the class too, they could have just not existed, it's crazy.
description: This course provides an introduction to the physical principles describing the formation and evolution of stars and their planetary companions. Topics include thermal radiation and stellar spectra; telescopes; energy generation in stars; stellar evolution; orbital dynamics; the Solar system; and exoplanets. This course includes an observational component: students will determine the distance to the Sun, and use the Clay Telescope atop the Science Center to study stellar evolution and detect exoplanets.
notes: This course is offered each year.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: Physics 15a, Physics 16, or Physical Sciences 12a.  May be taken concurrently.

best_comment: If you're excited by research, I highly recommend doing a senior thesis and taking Astro 191! The class is well–structured and provides you with support and guidance through regular check–ins, while being flexible. The final presentations are a great opportunity to present your work! Prof. Hernquist is very helpful!
worse_comment: Astrophysics theses are much less stressful than theses in other concentrations.
description: Individually supervised reading and research leading to the senior thesis. The Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics is home to one of the largest groups of astronomers in the world, providing extensive opportunities for undergraduate research. Both Part A and Part B must be taken in the same academic year in order for students to receive credit. Part two of a two part series.
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: ASTRON  99A

best_comment: This class was super interesting and Professor Connor is great. It is quite hard in some places but the lectures take you through the content well.
description: In this course we will learn the basic tools of modern astronomical research, including telescopes, detectors, imaging, spectroscopy, and common software. Emphasis will be placed on both the theory behind telescopes and their use, and hands-on experience with real data. Using this basic knowledge we will analyze science-level astronomical data from a wide range of telescopes and review the basic properties of stars, galaxies, and other astronomical objects of interest. The course includes a trip to the F. L. Whipple Observatory on Mount Hopkins, Arizona, to gather data with various telescopes.
notes: This course is offered each year.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: Astronomy 16 OR Astronomy 17

best_comment: This class is quite interesting and is a great introduction to various diseases affecting the different systems of the human body. Lectures are quite informative (could be more engaging) and problem sets and exams are very fair! It's definitely a class where you get out as much as you buy into it. Nancy is great and super nice and understanding.
description: This course explores the pathogenesis of disease by examining mechanisms operating at the molecular, cellular, system and whole-body levels. We will discuss diseases of the major body systems, as well as hematological disorders, cancer, the normal and abnormal function of the immune system, as well as aging and death.  Throughout the course we will look for common underlying pathogenic pathways and integrate relevant public health perspectives on the epidemiology or control of diseases.

best_comment: This class is quite interesting and is a great introduction to various diseases affecting the different systems of the human body. Lectures are quite informative (could be more engaging) and problem sets and exams are very fair! It's definitely a class where you get out as much as you buy into it. Nancy is great and super nice and understanding.
description: This course explores the pathogenesis of disease by examining mechanisms operating at the molecular, cellular, system and whole-body levels. We will discuss diseases of the major body systems, as well as hematological disorders, cancer, the normal and abnormal function of the immune system, as well as aging and death.  Throughout the course we will look for common underlying pathogenic pathways and integrate relevant public health perspectives on the epidemiology or control of diseases.

best_comment: This course requires a significant time commitment, making it challenging to balance with other academic responsibilities. If you’re planning to take it, consider treating it as the equivalent of 2.5 courses in terms of workload. If you have prior experience with cell culture and a background in cell biology, the course will be pretty easy– but regardless of your experience level, you will spend a lot of time on this course. That said, you’ll gain a deep understanding of cell biology, and the course is both engaging and enjoyable!
worse_comment: This course is a hands–on meat grinder that teaches students highly applicable and relevant lab skills. If you are looking to hit the ground running as an undergrad with limited/no previous experience, this course will whip your ass into shape quicker than greased lightning.  The lab staff is supportive and available quite often, and TFs are highly invested in the course material, which helps to somewhat ease the demanding nature of the course. Admittedly, this course demands your time, but as an undergrad, the only way to improve your technique is to get reps at the bench, which takes time. This course is highly rewarding, and I personally feel as though I am walking away from this course with more takeaways than a majority of the other bio–related courses I have taken. As for Professor Parker, he is a somewhat polarizing man. He speaks with authority, and far more directly than other professors I have encountered. For some, this is a huge turn–off, especially if you are used to sugarcoated feedback and calm lectures that bore you to death. For others, myself included, direct constructive feedback is probably the most helpful thing I could ask for as a learning student. Bottom line: if you are doing something stupid, Parker will say "hey, stop doing that stupid thing" (sometimes in a more colorful manner).
description: This is a combined introductory graduate/upper-level undergraduate course that focuses on examining modern techniques for manipulating cellular behavior and the application of these techniques to problems in the biomedical and biotechnological arenas. Applications in drug discovery, regenerative medicine, and cellular agriculture will be discussed. Topics will include controlling behavior of cells through cell-matrix interactions, cytoskeletal architecture, and cell behavior in processes such as angiogenesis and wound healing. Lectures will review fundamental concepts in cell biology before delving into topical examples from current literature. Students will work weekly in the lab learning cell culture techniques, soft lithography, microscopy, and classical in vitro assays measuring cell behavior.
notes: BE121 and ES222 are the same course. This course has a mandatory laboratory section that will require hands-on work outside of scheduled lecture times.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: LS1a (or LPS A); LS 1b; Math 21b (or equivalent); Physical Sciences 12a and 12b (or equivalents); and Engineering Sciences 53; AND Co-requisite: Biomedical Engineering 110

course_title_2025: Biomechanics of Movement and Assistive Robotics 001
best_comment: This is a great course. It's a really good opportunity to learn about the field of biomechanics, with Prof Patrick Slade, who's a fun, down to earth, and really invested in everyone's learning. It also has a good opportunity to experiment and build something of your own, fairly rudimentary but nonetheless a good way to do some actual building. It's less on the hardware and more on understanding human motion and human augmentation and touches on exoskeletons but not necessarily in the sci–fi way (the field is not that evolved yet). Regardless, it is a bit intense on the workload, but manageable, and a good experience. Great to do with friends, but also great to do solo and learn from others.
course_title_2026: Biomechanics of Movement and Assistive Robotics
description: This course will study the fundamentals of human movement, emphasizing applications in rehabilitation, athletics, and assistive devices. Topics will focus on the biomechanical principles of movement (muscle and tendon properties), experimental data collection techniques (motion capture, wearable sensing, and imaging), simulation with musculoskeletal modeling, and cutting-edge topics in assistive robotics (human-centered design, human-in-the-loop optimization, exoskeletons, etc.). A semester-long project will allow students to apply the topics to solve a problem of interest relating to human movement or assisted mobility.

best_comment: If you take this class, expect to dedicate a lot of time to it. There will be four papers assigned each week, each with a required discussion post. Papers range many topics in the biomedical sciences, so most of the articles will likely be out of your area of expertise, meaning they will take more time to read. It's not necessarily that the course material is difficult to understand, it is just that there is a constant stream of work throughout the semester – you will consistently have a paper waiting to be read for this class. At the end of the semester, there is a assignment to write a 5–page (~4000 word) proposal. The class unfortunately did not provide much context on best practices in writing a proposal, other than a tip sheet from a different university (which was helpful). The proposal will take a lot of time, as it is also required that you write it about something outside of your area of expertise. In taking this course, you will learn how to get the main ideas from a paper in a timely manner, and will gain experience writing proposals. While both of these are good things to learn,  you will have to spend a lot of time in order to do so.
worse_comment: If you are not a BIG student, this class would be an interesting way to be exposed to a wide variety of work being done in the computational biology/genomics space. The grading is not too harsh BUT it is quite a bit of work every week, especially towards the end of the semester when there is a large final assignment with no in class time devoted to learning about or working on it. I would not recommend this class if you are not very interested in this field and/or if you do not already have a strong background in biology, as there is no lecture and we go straight into reading scientific papers, which can be really challenging.
description: This is an upper-level critical paper reading and discussion course in the areas of experimental and computational functional genomics. Topics include genome sequencing, sequence analysis, transcriptomics, epigenomics, gene regulation, proteomics, chemical genomics, metabolomics, phenomics, and genetic variation analysis. Journal articles will comprise both classic, landmark papers in genomics and also more recent papers. Topics will be covered through paper presentations and in-class discussions. Students will be responsible for ‘chalk talk’ style presentations of assigned articles and leading class discussions of those articles, as well as active participation in discussion of all assigned papers. There will be written and oral presentations of final student proposals at the end of the term.

best_comment: This was, without doubt, one of my favorite classes at HSPH. It was uncomfortable, fast–paced, and I needed to work (very slowly) through the calculus and linear algebra to understand what Professor Wang was teaching. Doing the homework and exams was a truly humbling experience, but I came out of the course with a newfound sense of confidence in understanding advanced mathematical and statistical concepts, and with an insatiable desire to learn more. I loved that every morsel of knowledge in this class was earned – there was no other way to learn asymptotic theory without, for example, sitting down and understanding how Taylor series are involved. If you are in search of a class that is taught by a wonderful (and very funny!) professor and TFs, with ample support, and in a manner that will change the way you see models and estimation (the bread and butter of many public health disciplines), please do this class. It is so incredibly rewarding.
description: Exponential families, sufficiency, ancillarity, completeness, method of moments, maximum likelihood, unbiased estimation, Rao-Blackwell and Lehmann-Scheffe theorems, information inequality, Neyman-Pearson theory, likelihood ratio, score and Wald tests, uniformly and locally most powerful tests, asymptotic relative efficiency.
notes: Offered jointly with the School of Public Health as BST231.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: Biostatistics 230

best_comment: This class is a really strong course. It gives a very practical introduction to many important concepts in biostatistics. The workload is manageable and should not be too difficult for anyone coming from a stats background (familiar with linear regression, basic prob/inference, etc.). The teaching staff gives great feedback throughout the semester.
description: BIOSTAT 233 is an intermediate-level graduate course in the analysis of continuous, categorical, and time-to-event response data, with a focus on regression modeling as a tool for data analysis. While most of the presentation will be from the frequentist perspective, estimation and inference from the Bayesian perspective will be also be presented for select topics. Specific topics include: Heteroskedastic continuous response data; Theory of generalized linear models; Analysis of binary response data; Analysis of count response data; Analysis of multinomial response data; Analysis of time-to-event response data; Basis methods.
notes: Offered jointly with the School of Public Health as BST233.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: Biostatistics 232

best_comment: If you have an interest in machine learning in Python, this course is likely a great resource. Otherwise, this course is unlikely to be relevant to you. The assignments are long and the material is challenging unless you have a strong computer science background.
description: This is an introductory graduate-level course focusing on statistical computing. It seamlessly blends critical programming and statistical computing concepts, designed to complement the collaborative and reproducible biostatistics research. The curriculum covers a wide array of topics, including (1) optimization techniques such as Gradient Descent (GD), Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD), Newton's Method, Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM), and constrained optimization; (2) sampling methods like Importance Sampling, MarkovChain Monte Carlo (MCMC), Langevin Dynamics, and stable diffusion alongside foundational linear algebra applications through QR and Cholesky Decomposition, and (3) dynamic programming. Beyond the algorithm aspects, the course emphasizes practical skill development, from coding proficiency and essential best practices to the use of computational tools such as Cluster and Linux environments, Git for version control, and techniques for reproducible research using RMarkdown and Jupyter Notebooks. It also covers software development practices with a focus on developing R packages, visualization and web design to effectively communicate findings, and exploring innovative coding approaches, including automation through advanced tools like ChatGPT. This comprehensive course is designed to equip students with the necessary tools and knowledge for navigating the complexities of statistical computing, with a strong emphasis on practical skills like reproducible research, effective coding practices, and the utilization of modern computational tools.
notes: Offered jointly with the School of Public Health as BST236.

best_comment: If this class is taught by LJ, take this class for an easy A and advanced doctoral credit. If you have a fairly solid understanding of Probability and Inference I, then this class shouldn't be hard at all. The most stressful component is a short in–class presentation that I believe is completion graded.  At worst you may be asked to make some modifications or improvements before your slides are shared on the Canvas. I think it's a blessing and a curse that LJ prioritizes teaching intuition.  Especially when it comes to the martingale theory, the in–class presentation of the material is mostly chalk–talk presentation where at times intuition is prioritized heavily over rigor.  This is great for seeing the material for the first time and maybe understanding how it was motivated before it was made rigorous, but I don't think anyone with a mathematical background would be satisfied with the presentation without going on to read the texts.  At least the texts alluded to throughout the class are quite rigorous.
description: Discusses the theoretical basis of concepts and methodologies associated with survival data and censoring, nonparametric tests, and competing risk models. Much of the theory is developed using counting processes and martingale methods.
notes: Offered jointly with the School of Public Health as BST 244.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: BIOSTAT 231 AND BIOSTAT 232

best_comment: I highly recommend this class to any student with an interest in causal inference, so long as one has the appropriate background (e.g., the first–year Biostatistics PhD core courses). I found that many of the concepts in this class were directly relevant to improving my own research. Overall, a fantastic way to get acquainted to the field to a surprisingly deep level within the span of a semester. As it is a newer course, some content is likely subject to change from year to year, but the core content of the course is extremely valuable.
description: Randomized experimentation is the standard for quantifying the causal effect of an intervention in the public health and biomedical sciences, yet randomization may be impossible, impractical, or unethical, leading to real-world scenarios in which causal inferences are based upon observational comparisons. This course reviews the foundations of causal inference in (bio)statistics, outlining causal-analytic methods that help to extract as much evidence as imperfect observational studies carry about causal effects commonly of interest in applied health science settings. This survey of statistical causal inference begins with foundational concepts: the potential outcomes framework and counterfactual random variables, graphical modeling frameworks, and common assumptions and strategies for the identification of the causal effects of static and dynamic interventions. Methodological extensions for studying the causal effects of time-varying, longitudinal interventions will be touched upon as well. Further topics to be addressed may include instrumental variables approaches, principal stratification, causal mediation analysis, treatment effect heterogeneity, the causal dose-response curve, and causal survival analysis. This course may also introduce elements of semi-parametric theory necessary for the development of asymptotically efficient estimators of causal effect estimands. Where possible, the role of modern regression (i.e., machine learning) techniques and tools for the practical estimation of causal effect estimands will be emphasized.
notes: Pre-requisites: BIOSTAT 231 and BIOSTAT 232.

best_comment: I would only take this class if it is required. It tries to bridge the experimental and computational without quite effectively addressing either. Make sure you have a solid background in programming with R or python. The instructors are quite engaged and looking to improve the course, and it provides an overview of many genetic sequencing approaches, with a focus on the theory side, though assignments focus on application.
worse_comment: Probably a required course but not particularly useful. Lectures were technical but not applicable, homework required more coding experience than the prerequisites and office hours were not helpful, the packages used often had incompatibilities with Apple computers. The format of the journal club felt a little bit silly and the final project setup of people doing work then handing off makes it unnecessarily difficult to collaborate.
description: Introduction to genomic data, computational methods for interpreting these data, and survey of current functional genomics research. Covers biological data processing, programming for large datasets, high-throughput data (sequencing, proteomics, expression, etc.), and related publications.
notes: Offered jointly with the School of Public Health as BST 281.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: BST 272 or BST 273

best_comment: I would only take this class if it is required. It tries to bridge the experimental and computational without quite effectively addressing either. notes: Offered jointly with the School of Public Health as BST 281.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: BST 272 or BST 273

best_comment: The workshops are quite helpful for keeping you on track and accountable, and the spring workshop in particularly was helpful for suggesting programs/software you could use to make your figures, and for giving you time to start working on them. It was also nice to be in the same space as other thesis writers, where we could share our struggles and feel less alone in the process. I will say that needing to email your PI the results of each workshop feels kind of silly, especially when it doesn't seem to merit any response from them – I feel like it would've been sufficient for me to email it to my direct mentor. It feels like the course's expectations of how invested your PI is is rather idealized in comparison to reality. In terms of the thesis–writing experience, I ended up hella grinding all my experiments in the two months before the deadline, and (other than the introduction I wrote in the fall/winter break) wrote most of it in like two weeks.  During the summer before, I should've realized how much harder it would be to get things done during the school year – if you can, get as much as possible done during the summer and don't bank on making too much progress during the fall. Also, if you're going to leave your writing to the last minute, at least pretend like your thesis is due a day before it's actually do – the extra 24 hours left gave me time to do so much editing, and to write a whole extra section in my results (using data with inconclusive results that I had previously decided I didn't have time to include).
description: Laboratory research in topics related to the CPB concentration, culminating in an undergraduate thesis submitted to the CPB undergraduate office for review by members of the Board of Tutors in Biochemical Sciences and the greater Boston research community. The course includes a series of workshops designed to help prepare students for the process of writing their thesis.
notes: Limited to students writing a thesis in CPB. Students are required to submit a written proposal to the CPB undergraduate office in the summer for review by the Board of Tutors in Biochemical Sciences for enrollment that fall. Only those students whose thesis proposals are approved are eligible to enroll. Ordinarily may not be taken as a fifth course. Students must complete both terms of this course (parts A and B) within the same academic year in order to receive credit. Students must complete basic laboratory safety training and other safety training required by the host lab prior to starting work.
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: CPB  99A

best_comment: Take this class. It was not easy, but I LOVED it. It's an amazingly well supported, well organized, well taught class. Logan is awesome and so are all the TFs and CAs. They're so passionate about chemistry and want to help you learn and succeed. There is a LOT of material to learn (including a fair amount of memorization), but the course also provides a huge amount of practice material. (This does make feel like there's always more studying you could be doing, but ultimately it's super useful.) Collaboration is highly encouraged –– in fact, psets and exams always have a group portion. It is a hard course and took a lot of time and energy, but I am so so glad I took it. Would absolutely recommend. Also, labs are super fun and you often get out early.
worse_comment: DO ALL THE PRACTICE PROBLEMS!!! The inly way you can succeed in this class is if you are exposed to different variations of questions and you continually practice the mechanisms. You cannot study for the exam 2 days before it, you must be doing all the practice problems as you learn the content.
description: An introduction to structure and bonding in organic molecules; mechanisms of organic reactions; chemical transformations of the functional groups of organic chemistry; synthesis; determination of chemical structures by infrared and NMR spectroscopy.
notes: Chemistry 20/30 is an integrated two-semester sequence that prepares students to study chemistry and other physical sciences, whereas the Chemistry 17/27 sequence focuses on application of organic chemistry concepts to the life sciences. Either sequence satisfies the organic chemistry requirement for medical school and the chemistry concentration. The content of Chemistry 17 is accelerated and overlaps with topics from both Chemistry 20 and 30. Students may not count both Chemistry 17 and 20 toward the degree. However, Chemistry 27 and Chemistry 20/30 cover different material, so students may choose to take Chemistry 27 after completing the 20/30 sequence.

best_comment: Take Chem 27! A difficult but incredibly rewarding class, particularly if you have a strong bio interest and want to understand the mechanistic principles of biology better. Make sure to prep consistently throughout the semester by reviewing lecture slides, Pollev questions, rewriting notes, redoing module + psets, etc. More memorization–based then Chem 17, but you can simplify all the different mechanisms down to their core principles, which makes the process much easier. Teaching staff are really supportive and there to help you succeed. As long as you don't procrastinate and have a consistent study schedule it should be fine.
worse_comment: Exams should reflect what is taught in lectures and the problem sets/practice tests given to students. Midterm 1 was fair, but midterms 2 and 3 were awful. It reflects quite poorly on the course and the instructors when the exams have extremely low averages, and students are dealing with severe mental and physical health issues as a result of this course. This year, they had to curve midterm 2 by five points, which they haven't done historically. Setting up students for failure and screwing them over isn't something that I expected from a course at Harvard, especially a course that is already supposed to be so rigorous and is a requirement for premeds to take. Sending thoughts and prayers if you're going to take this course next year, because after a certain point, there's not much you can do.
best_gem_comment: ****** ABSOLUTE GEM!!!! EASIEST COURSE EVER! You'll love every second of your 12+ hours of problem sets, labs and exam prep per week! Oh and don't forget the amazingly tedious labs that are pretty inconsequential to your studies. You'll love the random content on the exams that were covered in a single bullet point on one lecture slide and never mentioned again! In all honesty, If you're taking Chem 27 you don't really have a choice so idk why you're looking at the Q report for it...
description: Chemical principles that govern the processes driving living systems are illustrated with examples drawn from biochemistry, cell biology, and medicine. The course deals with organic chemical reactivity (reaction mechanisms, structure-reactivity relationships), with topics specifically relevant to the life sciences (chemistry of enzymes, nucleic acids, drugs, natural products, cofactors), and with applications of chemical biology to medicine and biotechnology. An understanding of organic reactions and their "arrow-pushing” mechanisms is required.
notes: Students who completed Chem S-17 in Summer 2023 or before have the option to be exempted from the lab component of Chem 27. Similarly, students who have completed both Chem 20 and Chem 30 may be exempted. If students choose to be lab exempt, exams will make up a greater percentage of their final grade. The course syllabus describes the grading scheme in greater detail.

best_comment: Watch the lectures online on 3x speed. Prof Mason is great at explaining things and very patient but easy to zone out in class as the pace is fairly slow. It's not an easy class if you're not a physics/physical chem person but definitely doable. Make sure you understand how to do all psets, or it will come to bite when exams come. There are no lectures slides and everything is written on a chalkboard, so you need to keep good notes and rewatch lectures before exams. Other than that great, Prof Mason is amazing and TFs are also great
worse_comment: Solid class. The language in the problem sets can be difficult to decipher at first.  Ask questions in office hours and read the textbook for more difficult concepts. From what I read in the last few year's Q Reports, they are working to make this class better and more structured every year and that pattern continued this year.
description: Students will be introduced to the basic concepts of inorganic chemistry. Principles of chemical bonding and molecular structure will be developed on the basis of electronic structure, symmetry, and group theory. These concepts will be applied toward understanding coordination chemistry and organometallic chemistry.

best_comment: Khaled is an absolutely wonderful instructor who cares an incredible amount about the students in the class and is willing to help them in whatever way possible – I cannot emphasize how much I appreciate the help that he gave me over the duration of the final project! All in all, the experience of being able to design,  execute, and present the final project is a wonderful experience that I had a really great time doing and recommend for anyone interested in pursuing an independent research project. You will truly have the freedom and resources to do any sort of research project you want.
description: The goal of this course is to provide students with both detailed knowledge of established and fundamental methods of experimental physical chemistry and an introduction to selected state-of-the-art experiments that address contemporary scientific questions. You will learn about tools that are of broad utility in many areas of science and have fun discovering how to make these experimental apparatus work. The fundamental methods discussions will demonstrate how specific chemical phenomena can be used to interrogate complex molecular systems. Some of the experimental techniques introduced in this class are now employed in many different fields of fundamental and applied science and are considered the often cornerstones of modern day experimental nanoscience. The class will provide a hands-on introduction to physical methods and techniques used widely in chemistry and chemical physics research laboratories. Computer-based methods of data acquisition and analysis are used throughout.
notes: Recommended as preparation for research in experimental chemistry (Chemistry 98R and 99R), chemical physics, engineering sciences, or related disciplines.

best_comment: Chem 171 is a great class overall, but it does have its quirks. Here are some notable pros and cons:Pros:– Professor Balskus is great! She is incredibly knowledgeable and friendly, and genuinely wants everyone to learn– The TFs are also quite good– they gave very useful feedback, held frequent office hours, and genuinely wanted everyone to succeed– The course material is quite interesting– the first 1/2 of the course is pretty much a speedrun of Chem 27 (how organisms make all kinds of biomolecules) but more in–depth and with some added categories, and the second 1/2 of the course is how to apply your knowledge of how biomolecules are made to do interesting science (such as identifying the genes responsible for making the molecule, identifying the molecule made by a set of genes, and using biocatalysis to engineer new ways to make molecules)– The class is a good mix of Undergrads and Grad students, so you will definitely meet new people– The class takes ~7 hours per week, which is pretty standard– There are a few guest lectures from people in Biochem / Biocatalysis who come and visit, so you will see industrial applications of the topics and maybe even build useful connectionsCons:– The sections are not very engaging. The sections are quite interesting in theory– each section, you learn about and use a new Bioinformatic tool, and in your final project, you use 3 of those tools you learned about. However, the sections do not have enough structure in my opinion, as most of the time was spent just playing around with the bioinformatic tool yourself– The grading on psets was incredibly harsh– multiple points are taken off for simple / non–understanding mistakes, such as not writing water or acid/base co–products. This detracted from finding where my understanding was lacking– The psets, tests, and projects took a while to be returned (but the feedback was good, so this is not the biggest deal)– No information was provided about the grading curve at any point in the semesterTL;DR: Chem 171 is a good class and I would recommend it to anyone interested in biochemistry. It has some quirks, such as the grading being harsh and the sections not having enough structure, but overall, I learned a lot and had a great time in the class!
worse_comment: The content is interesting, but I hated how a lot of the work felt like busy work to me. In a graduate level course, I should not be feeling that way. The grading was also overly harsh.
description: This course will examine synthesis from a biological perspective, focusing on how organisms construct and manipulate metabolites, as well as how biological catalysts and systems can be used for small molecule production. Topics to be covered include mechanistic enzymology, biosynthetic pathways and logic, biocatalysis, protein engineering, and synthetic biology.

course_title_2025: Practical Crystallography in Chemistry and Materials Science LEC
best_comment: I don't recommend taking this class until an extreme overhaul is done. The content is valuable but the quality of the teaching is frustrating and honestly subpar. If you are interested in learning about crystallography, you would be better off reading the textbooks assigned on the syllabus (because that's honestly the only place I learned anything anyway) or waiting until another instructor picks this course up/until you can take it at another institution.
worse_comment: This class is a must–take for anybody who will be reliant on crystallography for their current or future research. That being said, it is not a pleasant class and requires substantially more work than seems necessary to learn the important material. It is possible to learn a lot and pretty much be prepared to become a DIY user of the x–ray facility, however Shao is extremely harsh and frequently openly criticizes individual students, which makes for an unpleasant learning environment. Many assignments must be completed on a weekly basis with little guidance, though very little of it contributes to your grade and assignment of numerical grades seems very subjective or arbitrary.
course_title_2026: Practical Crystallography in Chemistry and Materials Science
description: Due to great technical advances, crystal structure analysis plays an increasingly important role in the structure determination of complex solids. This course involves the basic principles of crystallography and covers advanced aspects of practical crystal structure refinement. Topics include crystal symmetry, space groups, geometry of diffraction, structure factors, and structure refinement. Students will gain a working knowledge of x-ray crystallographic techniques, including how to: grow quality crystals, collect data, reduce data, determine a structure, visualize structure, utilize structural databases, publish crystallographic results. Watch Learning Crystal Structure Analysis at Harvard.

instructors: Gregory C. Tucci, Lu Wang, Wyatt Hurt
description: This course will teach graduate students how to communicate scientific concepts in the classroom. Students will focus on becoming effective teachers in discussion sections and in the laboratory. The course will emphasize hands-on experience in teaching and explaining scientific concepts. Students must complete both parts of this course (parts A and B) within the same academic year in order to receive credit.
notes: Required of all first-year graduate students in the Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology.
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: CHEM 301HFA

instructors: Gregory C. Tucci, Lu Wang, Wyatt Hurt

course_title_2025: Environment and Society in the Premodern World 001
best_comment: This class has expanded my understanding of "environmental history" by asking the very simple question: what was environment in the past, especially the pre–modern era? This has allowed us to consider as a classroom both today's environmental conundrums but also the very different demands of ancient and early modern environments and the variety of human adaptations to them. This has been a great opportunity to learn from peers across the Humanities and Social Sciences at Harvard, and I am immensely grateful for it.
course_title_2026: Movement and Migration in the Ancient Mediterranean
description: In this course, we will trace the movements of people across the Mediterranean Sea, from the earliest coastal settlements to the 21st-century refugee crisis, with a focus on Greek and Roman antiquity. What drives a person to leave home and make an arduous or dangerous journey? What do they experience once they arrive? What have been the causes and consequences of mass migrations across the Mediterranean? Through the lens of human mobility and migration we will explore topics such as ancient climate, colonization, war, slavery, imperialism, economic integration, social mobility, and identity. We will also consider practical and theoretical problems in the study of mobility and migration in the archaeological and historical record.

course_title_2025: Introduction to the Ancient Roman World 001
best_comment: Let me just preface this comment by stating that this is not an easy class.  Kathleen Coleman is definitely not an easy grader (though she is a fair one), not inflating assignments in the manner that most classes might do.  While this realization was at first difficult, in hindsight, I very much appreciate this approach to teaching.  I think that Coleman's approach could be described as a sort of "tough–love" –– she grades a bit more harshly not to be mean, but to spur growth.  After I got a lower grade than expected on one of my assignments, I met up with her, during which she told me that she gives students grades such that inspire improvement and push one to his full potential –– an approach that inspired me to learn much more in this course than I think I otherwise would have achieved.  Looking back on this course, I have fond eyes; in response to the higher expectations, all of us students formed deep bonds which I know will last far beyond this class.  Coleman is also an excellent lecturer.  Lectures are thematic rather than purely chronological (education, slavery, economy, etc), though she does include timelines in her lectures.  She delivers lectures in an engaging and memorable manner, making studying much more streamlined.   Assignments are very well thought–out and the expectations are clear (though demanding).  All in all, I highly recommend this class to any student who truly wants to learn about Roman history.  This course is by no means a gem, but anyone who puts in the work will enjoy this class and be glad that he took it.

course_title_2026: Introduction to the Ancient Roman World
description: This course provides a comprehensive exploration of Roman history, culture, and research methodologies. It consists of three key components: a chronological survey of Roman history, beginning with the founding of Rome in the mid-8th century BCE and concluding with the dissolution of the Western Empire in the late 5th century CE; thematic examinations of crucial aspects of Roman culture and daily life, encompassing topics such as religion, economy, law and administration, technological advancements, and urban topography; and an introduction to the tools and methods utilized in Roman world research, with particular emphasis on material culture and documentary sources. The course aims to provide a robust understanding of both the historical trajectory of Rome and the intricate workings of Roman society. Students will gain valuable insights into the processes of historical inquiry through the study of physical evidence, such as artifacts and archaeological remains, as well as written records, fostering a multifaceted approach to understanding the ancient world.
notes: Concentrators are required to take either one or two semesters of Classical Studies 97, depending on their concentration track.

best_comment: The trip makes this class worthwhile and brings the readings to life! The first half of the class was a bit dry, but after we returned from Sicily, our discussions became much richer, and students were more willing to participate (since we had gotten to know each other much better during spring break).Readings are very archaeology heavy,  which can be frustrating. (I would have appreciated more historical/literary sources.)Overview of Sicilian history was a bit cursory, and class discussions were often repetitive. Professor sometimes seemed underprepared for lectures.Still, the trip and the final paper gave me a solid understanding of Sicilian history and culture and motivation to continue learning.
description: The advanced undergraduate seminar Classical Studies 112: Regional Study is a capstone course required of concentrators in Classical Civilizations and Ancient History (Greek and Roman). It will explore in depth the cultural, political, and social histories of ancient Sicily, from the Bronze Age to the Norman period, drawing together the different skills and knowledge that you will have acquired during your time as a concentrator.Through the study of sites, objects, and texts, the course will examine a number of themes key to understanding a discrete region of the ancient Mediterranean world, including landscape and ecology; identities and ethnic interactions; empire and government; religion and myth; and much else. We will aim to analyze all available types of evidence, including architecture, art, coins, geology, inscriptions, and literature. Students will travel to Sicily during Spring Break.
notes: This course is required for concentrators in the Classical Civilizations track, joint concentrators in Ancient History, and all joint concentrators in Classical Civilizations and an Allied Field. Admission is by application only. Students interested in enrolling should contact the Director of Undergraduate Studies (classicsDUS@fas.harvard.edu).

best_comment: This is a class if you are at all interested in learning Greek! Nadav and Alex were both fantastic — super engaging, interesting, and great at explaining grammar/history/etc. The class is pretty manageable work–wise, but I still feel like I learned a lot.
description: Greek 2 continues from Greek 1. You will continue to deepen your knowledge of the Ancient Greek language while being immersed in the world and culture of Ancient Greece. The course also includes various enrichment activities, such as visits to museums and libraries.
notes: Students wishing to continue after Greek 2 should proceed to Greek 3, which concludes the normal introductory sequence.   No auditors. May be taken pass/fail (undergraduates) or SAT/UNSAT (graduate students) with instructor permission.

best_comment: Greek 10 is a wonderful way to secure your Greek and get more fluent, especially if the texts are as interesting and fun as they were this semester. Sarah is wonderful––she really cares about her students and has great insights into reception especially, but is also very helpful with and good at explaining grammar.
description: Greek 10 is dedicated to close reading and analysis of Ancient Greek literary texts, both prose and poetry, beginning at an intermediate pace. You will hone your Ancient Greek linguistic skills by reading authentic texts (e.g., Plato, Euripides, Homer, and Herodotus) and thereby improve your command of the language. By reading original Ancient Greek texts you will also be introduced to the literature and culture of Ancient Greece, while developing an appreciation for features of style, genre, and meter. The course will also include various enrichment activities, such as visits to museums and libraries.
notes: After Greek 10, students may take Greek courses at the 100-level, but are encouraged to consult with the Director of Undergraduate Studies in the Classics (classicsDUS@fas.harvard.edu) about their choice of course. Students may also take Greek 10 more than once, with the permission of the course head. Auditors allowed with permission of course head.

best_comment: An amazing experience! If you have done some Latin before and are looking for an interesting and engaging course that doesn't break the bank time wise then I highly suggest this.
description: Latin 10 offers close reading and analysis of Latin literary texts, both prose and poetry, beginning at an intermediate pace. Participants will improve their reading proficiency while developing an appreciation for features of style, genre, and meter.
notes: After Latin 10, students may take Latin courses at the 100-level, but are encouraged to consult with the Director of Undergraduate Studies in the Classics (classicsDUS@fas.harvard.edu) about their choice of course. Students may also take Latin 10 more than once, with the permission of the course head.  No auditors. May be taken pass/fail (undergraduates) or SAT/UNSAT (graduate students) with instructor permission.

best_comment: This class is incredible. The professors are so wonderful and smart, hearing them speak is probably the best part of it. They really foster an open and safe environment where people can feel comfortable speaking on difficult topics. The class was very warm and felt almost like a family. It’s a great class.
description: By focusing on literary narratives, cultural representations, and critical theories, this course explores ways in which issues related to migration create rich and complex interdisciplinary conversations. How do humanistic disciplines address these issues—human rights, cultural translation, global justice, security, citizenship, social discrimination, biopolitics—and what contributions do they make to the “home” disciplines of migration studies such as law, political science, and sociology? How do migration narratives compel us to revise our concepts of culture, polity, neighborliness, and community? We will explore diverse aspects of migration from existential, ethical, and philosophical perspectives while engaging with specific regional and political histories.

They really foster an open and safe environment where people can feel comfortable speaking on difficult topics. The class was very warm and felt almost like a family. It’s a great class.
