course_title_2025: Comparative Literature in Theory and Practice SEM
course_title_2026: Comparative Literature in Theory and Practice
description: An introduction to the discipline of comparative literature, looking at major issues in the history and current practice of the discipline as practiced in the USA, with special emphasis on seeing how comparatists enter into ongoing debates concerning theory and method. Several of our faculty will join us for the discussion of their work. Additional readings will include selections from Herder, de Staël, Adorno, Auerbach, de Man, Glissant, Said, Spivak, Apter, Venuti, and Heise.
notes: Required of first-year graduate students in Comparative Literature; open to all graduate students interested in the study of literature in transnational and interdisciplinary perspectives.

best_comment: Definitely take CS1! I am extremely glad that this was how I chose to fulfill QRD. Python is such a great coding language to start with, Professor Leitner is an incredible resource, and I never found the workload to be unreasonable. If you come to lecture, you will be fine. You will want to come to lecture, too; Leitner is fun! As a humanities major, this was the perfect way to (finally) take QRD.
worse_comment: use this course as a gateway to cs for students who are uncertain
description: An introduction to the most important discoveries and intellectual paradigms in computer science, designed for students with little or no previous background. Explores problem-solving and data analysis using Python, a programming language with a simple syntax and a powerful set of libraries. This course covers basic data types and collections (lists, dictionaries, tuples, and sets), control flow, recursion, supervised machine learning via regression, visualization, information hiding and encapsulation using classes and objects, and introduces the analysis of program performance. Presents an integrated view of computer systems, from switching circuits up through compilers, and examines theoretical and practical limitations related to unsolvable and intractable computational problems. Other topics include the social and ethical dilemmas presented by such issues as software unreliability, algorithmic bias, artificial intelligence, and invasions of privacy.
notes: May not be taken for credit after completing Computer Science 50.

course_title_2025: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001
best_comment: 209b is really fantastic, and the topics we discuss feel very relevant and current. I had mixed feelings about 209a, but I really enjoyed 209b. I'd say that while the general workload of the homework is roughly the same in 209b as in 209a, I found the homework in 209b to be more interesting and enjoyable to complete. I believe that 209a and 209b truly built the foundation for the SM in Data Science program, and I'm glad I took both. Pavlos, Chris, and Nitesh are all fantastic instructors, and I am grateful that I had the opportunity to learn from them.
worse_comment: You can learn a lot from the class but the experience is not easy.
course_title_2026: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science
description: Data Science 2 is the second half of a one-year introduction to data science. Building upon the material in Data Science 1, the course introduces advanced methods for statistical modeling, representation, and prediction. Topics include multiple deep learning architectures such as CNNs, RNNs, transformers, language models, autoencoders, and generative models as well as basic Bayesian methods, and unsupervised learning. Students are strongly encouraged to enroll in both the fall and spring course within the same academic year. Part two of a two-part series.
notes: Can only be taken after successful completion of CS 1090a (previously CS 109a), AC 209a, Stat 109a, or Stat 121a, or equivalent. This course was previously numbered CS 109b.
course_requirements: Requisite: (Must take CS 1090A OR APCOMP 209A OR STAT 121A before taking CS 1090B) AND (Not to be taken in addition to APCOMP 209B, OR STAT 121, OR STAT 121B.)

course_title_2025: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001

best_comment: This might be the best course I've taken. Obviously this is a hard class. I recommend making this your only hard class tbh to give it the time and attention it deserves. As someone who got an A without a cracked background (took CS50 & 51, etc.) who didn't take CS20/120/121 before this class (I did do Math101, which I thought was really great prep for proofs), I think it is very possible to succeed in this class if you put in the time. I think going to lecture is very helpful. Watching recordings is almost always a worse way to learn. Doing the problem sets yourself and not trying to cheat your way through them is the single most important thing to succeed in this class. You learn this stuff by thinking really hard about it, getting really frustrated, and then going to OH to understand what you're not understanding. Course staff is great and full of cracked people that are very open to help you. Kitty, Maxwell, Collin are all especially amazing. Overall one of my favorite and most useful classes I've taken at this school, and Madhu + Sitan are both really great. Good luck!
worse_comment: Take it bc are you a real cs major if you don't? First half of the course is interesting but the later half is a drag. All throughout the course materials are incredibly confusing, misleading at times, and the slides are just so boring and made with no effort at all. Professors are nice and actually help out with pset problems but pedagogically have not made a lot of effort.
description: Design and analysis of efficient algorithms and data structures. Algorithm design methods, graph algorithms, approximation algorithms, and randomized algorithms are covered.
notes: This course was previously numbered CS 124.

description: Design and analysis of efficient algorithms and data structures. Algorithm design methods, graph algorithms, approximation algorithms, and randomized algorithms are covered.
notes: This course was previously numbered CS 124.

best_comment: You will learn fundamental results like the G–S theorem: that it is mathematically impossible for a voting rule to have all three following properties: free from manipulation, any candidate can theoretically win, and voters are incentivized to report honest rankings of their preferred candidates. Or that for two–sided matchings, it is mathematically impossible to have a rule that incentivize both sides to be honest–reporting, while resulting in a matching that is stable (where pairs won’t want to switch partners). Or that for allocating schools to students, it’s impossible to have a mechanism that satisfy all the following properties together: incentivizes honest–reporting, equal treatment of students with equal preferences, and doesn’t result in a subpar matching that a better matching exists. Incredibly fundamental results with extremely practical results.Probably the best class I have taken at Harvard (but this is conditioning on me as a junior and after taken some proof classes, and is interested in voting and allocating resources and fairness) (I am not a 55 kid though)Time split by week, rounded up by hour2, 5, 4, 2, 13, 6, 3, 7, 5, 7, 8, 4, 13, 2, 5, 3The two spikes are 2/23–3/3 (one week before midterm) and 4/20–4/28 (one week before reading period, last pset, I think I was doing some catching–up studying during this week).Lectures are required, but Ariel’s lectures are the best I have had at Harvard. I really like the pace, and I can understand everything at that pace without feeling bored. Attendance is monitored through in class quizzes about new material, which are honestly quite fun. The slides are also well–made and beautiful. The material is well–motivated and presented logically, with definitions clearly defined, and examples to illustrate. Ariel is also very responsive Ed.I think the value to effort ratio is pretty high, given that I spend <7 hours per week. Note that the value is intellectual value though.All in all, highly recommend!
worse_comment: Solid course. Lectures and psets are fun, but the tests are just a few very memorization based question which just feels a little bad.
description: The course explores the interaction between the disciplines of economics and computer science. In one direction, we will see how computational thinking (including concepts like approximation algorithms and worst-case analysis) gives a new perspective on areas of economic theory such as game theory, mechanism design, and social choice. In the other direction, we will discuss how economic approaches can address timely questions in computer science and artificial intelligence. Special attention will be devoted to problems of societal significance. For a detailed list of topics, see the course schedule.
notes: This course was previously numbered CS 186 and CS 136.

best_comment: This has been a crazy (in a great way) class, and I've really enjoyed it. The material is very, very abstract, so it may be a bit unintuitive at first, but there are a lot of tidbits here and there that make for very interesting material –– some really weird math is sometimes sprinkled in to formalize things, and it's always quite fun. I think this class plays a complementary role to CS121: if your CS education is a brick wall, 121 is the grout, and 152 is the finishing coat, filling in the few details that really make everything work together. As someone who has never cared at all about systems, for instance, the framework given in 152 has really inspired me to go think about the implementations of programming languages in compilers, etc. in ways I'd really brushed off before.The class itself is not a huge amount of work: to be sure, it's backloaded, so be careful about the amount of work at the end of the semester, but the exams were fair, the TFs very helpful (shoutout to my personal GOAT, Jonas), and Prof. Amin is incredibly knowledgeable about the material and friendly. Her knowledge of the material is a bit of a double–edged sword: she's clearly incredibly smart and a fantastic researcher, but this means she assumed we all are, too, so a lot of the examples given in class are a bit too difficult to pick up on the fly, and I think they could benefit from a tad more hands–on time with the material over pure powerpoint lecture (she live–codes in a really impressive way, though, I have to give her that).I thoroughly enjoyed this class, and would highly recommend it to folks looking to round out their theoretical CS education or looking for a good bridge between theory and systems, because you really see both come alive.
worse_comment: There are not many good spring classes, so this one is one of the only ones that is relatively chill. Not a lot of good options tbh.
description: Comprehensive introduction to the principal features and overall design of both traditional and modern programming languages, including syntax, formal semantics, abstraction mechanisms, modularity, type systems, naming, polymorphism, closures, continuations, and concurrency. Provides the intellectual tools needed to design, evaluate, choose, and use programming languages.
notes: This course was previously numbered CS 152.

best_comment: If you enjoy systems (taking CS 61 will probably help you make an informed opinion about systems), enjoy long hours of programming and debugging and not having a life, this is the class for you :DIn all seriousness, I loved 161. I think it's truly a transformative and fun experience working on low–level systems programming. Assignments were long but definitely very enjoyable and give you both a lot to learn and the opportunity to really sharpen your skills as a programmer and solidify your understanding of lecture concepts. Mickens is an incredible instructor and lecturer and there is not a single dull moment in his lectures. Remember to appreciate his incredible PowerPoint skills as you explore the lecture slides with great awe. There are diagrams – quite a lot of them. But fear not, they'll become your friends (maybe). You'll be acquainted with quite a few recurrent characters, such as the pagetable walk diagram, Bob and Alice, angry/condescending Linus Torvalds, The Internet™©, the great address space VOID, struct proc, the Duolingo streak and Bitmoji James. All characters that you will remember in the years to come as you smile and reminisce about an unforgettable 161 experience. This class is definitely legendary to me and I am thoroughly glad I had the opportunity to take it. Highly recommended!
description: This course focuses on the design and implementation of modern operating systems. The course discusses threads, processes, virtual memory, schedulers, and the other fundamental primitives that an OS uses to represent active computations. An exploration of the system call interface explains how applications interact with hardware and other programs which are concurrently executing. Case studies of popular file systems reveal how an OS makes IO efficient and robust in the midst of crashes and unexpected reboots. Students also learn how virtualization allows a physical machine to partition its resources across multiple virtual machines. Class topics are reinforced through a series of intensive programming assignments which use a real operating system.
notes: This course was previously numbered CS 161.

best_comment: Professor Doshi–Velez is amazing! Prof. David Alvarez–Melis is very kind and makes the class fun and is very personable. I am a bit biased towards Doshi because she was my first female CS professor, but learning from her was an absolute privilege. She is passionate about her work, and sharing her knowledge and excitement with student.  I'm ngl this class is hard. Imo, not 124 hard, but the exams are nothing like the psets. The psets are fun, lectures are understandable and you learn a lot, but exams are a whole different beast. Be prepared to really exercise your brain linear algebra wise. Could not recommend this class enough! Very glad I took it. Also I've had friends take 182 over this but I would highly recommend 181 because I think what you get from will truly make you a better computer scientist when you come out.
worse_comment: This course is, frankly, an embarrassment to the Harvard CS program. While the material is both essential and fascinating, it is being held hostage by disorganized instruction and inexcusable sloppiness. I’m a graduate student, and when I reflect on the best courses I’ve taken, I usually favor the ones that have challenged me. This course did challenge me—but for all the wrong reasons.The course started out promising. After the first lecture, I assumed the harsh Q–reports from previous semesters had been exaggerated. But there were early warning signs: major typos in the homework assignments that required several corrections and derivation mistakes during lectures. Unfortunately, after the midterm, the course completely unraveled. The midterm itself was a mess, and the quality of the lectures sharply declined afterward.–––––––––––––––––––––––TL;DR–––––––––––––––––––––––This course feels like a slap in the face to Harvard students. It is shocking that it has been allowed to continue in such a dysfunctional state for multiple semesters, despite consistent and negative student feedback. If you take this class, you’ll likely survive it—but you’ll be learning in a disorganized and chaotic environment. It is high time that the CS department intervene. I would strongly consider taking the course at MIT if you are able to. –––––––––––––––––––––––Homework–––––––––––––––––––––––Typically, I start homework assignments the day they are released. In this course, I delayed by a week to avoid the initial wave of typos, broken code, and vague or poorly phrased questions. Even waiting didn’t always spare me from those issues. Content–wise, the homeworks are average. Grading, however, felt inconsistently nitpicky—not the biggest problem in the class.–––––––––––––––––––––––Teaching–––––––––––––––––––––––It is no wonder that the lectures aren’t recorded. There can’t be video evidence of this slop.  Finale is a capable lecturer, but David was an inconsistent mess.  His insecurity and incompetence are a large part of what is making this course so frustrating. His motto should be “good catch,” because that is what he says when a student points out a glaring error in his math.  At this point, I don’t trust what’s written on the board until I verify it against the textbook myself. I don't fully trust the textbook, but at least it's a concrete thing I can refer to. It's clear Finale is delegating much of the professorial work to David because of her demanding schedule. It is also clear David is not rising to this challenge. –––––––––––––––––––––––Midterm–––––––––––––––––––––––The midterm was a disaster. It was far too long, riddled with typos that had to be corrected in real time, and included poorly constructed questions. Nearly everyone I spoke with didn’t finish it in time. I left the exam demoralized.What was the pedagogical reasoning behind assigning an exam that most students were bound to fail? Was it some kind of hazing ritual? A test of ego? Why not simply assess the material as it was actually taught?Before the exam, I overheard Finale mention to David that a particular question “really made me think” and “took a while to work through.” I’d ask the professors to reflect on how long it took them to solve that problem—and then consider how long it might take a student seeing it for the first time under strict time pressure. How is that pedagogically sound? What is being accomplished? –––––––––––––––––––––––Final Exam–––––––––––––––––––––––The final exam was also long and very difficult. I read the entire textbook, reworked every problem, and reviewed the lectures multiple times—and still received a poor grade. At least the time limit wasn’t as much of a constraint as during the midterm.–––––––––––––––––––––––Final Thoughts–––––––––––––––––––––––As of now, final grades have not been released. Without a curve, my grade is around 75%, despite earning A–level marks on all non–exam material. I genuinely have no idea what my final grade will be, because the course team has failed to communicate that information. That lack of transparency reflects a broader disrespect toward students.
description: Introduction to machine learning, providing a probabilistic view on artificial intelligence and reasoning under uncertainty. Topics include: supervised learning, ensemble methods and boosting, neural networks, support vector machines, kernel methods, clustering and unsupervised learning, maximum likelihood, graphical models, hidden Markov models, inference methods, and computational learning theory. Students should feel comfortable with multivariate calculus, linear algebra, probability theory, and complexity theory. Students will be required to produce non-trivial programs in Python.
notes: This course was previously numbered CS 181.

course_title_2025: Designing K–12 Computer Science Learning Experiences 001
best_comment: AMAZING COURSE! This class provides a robust overview of different tools and topics in the K12 CS space. Each class they follow a different structure discussing the case studies. All resources and classes are incredibly well–thought out and fascinating. KB and Brian (sad that he's left) really make this course special. They're endless support for each person's projects and each person's progression through life is truly incredible. They foster an amazing class community, and really embody great teaching. If you can get the opportunity, I would highly encourage anyone interested to take this class. It's so worth it! The final project has a lot of freedom and I really encourage you to pick something you really want to learn about and to run with it. Make sure to make progress each week :)
course_title_2026: Designing K–12 Computer Science Learning Experiences
description: From computational thinking to workforce arguments, there is considerable interest in and excitement about including computer science education for all K–12 students. Yet, unlike other disciplines with a much longer history in formal schooling, the interest in computer science education is not yet supported by commensurate attention to research and teacher practice. In this course, we will examine the state of K–12 computing education: questioning its value, examining its history, and imagining and contributing to its potential. The course will be organized as both a reading group and a lab, building a community of people who are committed to K–12 CS education. Each week you will read classic and current research, and write accompanying memos to document your evolving understandings of the field. Throughout the course, either individually or with partners, you will develop an independent project that explores the design of K–12 computer science learning experiences. Some examples of possible projects include: designing CS-standalone or cross-curricular learning activities and curriculum, building a programming language for novices, developing an annotated bibliography, critically analyzing policy documents such as curriculum frameworks and standards from around the world, or contributing to current K–12 CS education research initiatives.
notes: The course enrollment procedure will be posted to the course website. Students who enroll in the course will be expected to engage in a term-long project related to K–12 computer science education. No auditors. This course is also offered as EDU T217 at HGSE. This course was previously numbered CS 196.

course_title_2025: High Performance Computing for Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: This is the best course I've taken at Harvard and I strongly recommend taking it if you're even curious. The lectures are engaging, and difficult. The material is technically complex, but the assignments are incredibly reasonable (much easier than the material I found), which made me feel like I had some extra time to dedicate to reviewing the harder concepts from the lectures. The project topics are admittedly a bit constrained, and come project time I was spending probably 20–30 hours a week on just the project, but we chose a bad topic, so invest meaningful time early in a project design. Your peers are also likely to be...unaccommodating... on the cluster towards the due date of the project, so plan accordinglyThe teachers are incredible – I think Chuck, Ignacio and Chris all have a unique flavor of HPC they bring to the lectures, and the lectures are an awesome balance of material and practical coding or demonstrations.  They know their stuff and are truly receptive on the Ed board to fairly technically difficult questions if you're stuck. If you ask for help, they don't let you struggle alone, which is really cool. If you're curious, take this class.
course_title_2026: High Performance Computing for Science and Engineering
description: As manufacturing processes approach the physical limits of transistor density, efficient code must exploit parallelism to scale with available computing resources. Scientific software developers must therefore adopt a “think parallel” mindset to solve complex problems across academia, industry, and society. This course introduces parallel programming and its relationship to computer architectures, with an emphasis on high performance computing. Students will develop experience with programming models such as OpenMP, MPI, and CUDA, applying these techniques in homework and a term project.
notes: This course was previously numbered CS 205.

best_comment: This is overall a strong CS grad course! I think you should have a strong or at least reasonable interest in formal methods to get the most out of this class, since most lectures focus on applying formal method x to analyze [insert some security issue], and if this sounds exciting for you, this class is great! Professor Chong is an extremely down–to–earth, engaging, and kind professor that is very accessible outside of class and I've really appreciated getting to know him better this semester. The psets had some pretty cool, fun problems. This course's emphasis is on the final project, so make sure you stay on top of your final project work throughout the semester.
worse_comment: TL;DR: I will describe this class using a Hoare triple.{Happy} CS 2540 {Sad}Now onto the details.This class is bad. Like, really bad. I wish “CS2540 says I speaksfor CS2540” so that I could make CS2540 say all the problems about itself. I want to robustly declassify and transparently endorse the pain of this class to the rest of the world while maintaining nonmalleable information flow.Starting with the lectures. They are not informative. On a lattice, it feels like Steve’s lectures are secret untrusted and I am public trusted with how difficult it is to make the lecture information flow to my brain. But when you ask a question, it flips; you suddenly become secret untrusted and public trusted as you can’t get any meaningful questions to Steve.It feels like Steve assumes too much during lectures. The prerequisites that he states (Good CS student and taken Formal Reasoning before) is nowhere enough as Steve will sometimes just skip over details and assume you know them when he has never taught them before. This creates problems; eventually he will just lose you unless you have studied this topic before, which is unfair to the students who took the listed prerequisites in good faith. Even with some knowledge of PL, a lot of his lectures are indecipherable. Steve says HisLectures speaksfor Steve, but the problem is that HisLectures says Indecipherable speaksfor HisLectures.Onto the homework. Why do they exist? What is the line between a “check” and a “check–plus” grade on the homework? Nobody knows. The line is so nonexistent that it will make you question whether you know the line using epistemic logic. What world are you in? Are you in a world where the line is clear? The homeworks say no. Are you in a world where you know that the homeworks are meaningful? The homeworks say no. In fact, using epistemic logic, you will eventually come to the conclusion that K_{You}(CS 2540 is a bad class). Of course, the only way you will know this is if you experience what set of worlds you may be in by taking the class, but I hope that this observation is enough for you.In fact, the class can be written in Tamarin like this. [CS2540()]––[]–>[Out(BadClass)]. Which, speaking of, is the worst homework I have experienced. No instructions, just pain. No practice in class, just pain. Steve gives you zero preconditions, and somehow expects your postcondition to contain happiness of working with Tamarin. Give us those preconditions. But given that the prerequisite list is terrible, is it a surprise that the preconditions are lacking?The project. Nothing but pain. Lack of instructions. Lack of rubrics. Lack of basis on grading. It’s so arbitrary that you can’t ever know if Steve is grading fairly or not. In fact, it seems likely that he isn’t. “Steve will always grade fairly” is a safety property, and if Execution Monitoring tried to enforce this property on this class, the class would have been canceled as soon as Steve began to grade. “Steve will eventually make good lectures for CS2540” is a liveness property, but it remains unsatisfied. No well–founded relation can be found to save this class.If you are still considering taking this course, think of a model of CS2540 that we will reason with. Reasoning through, we find that the class is vulnerable to a side channel. Through the pain it inflicts on its students, a side channel characterized by the stress of its students is created. Even when you have exploited this side channel, why would you try to experience a class of this exploitable model yourself? CS2540 and a class where you struggle and don’t learn much are contextually equivalent.To this end, remember that you have your secrets. With how public the pain of CS2540 is, if you want to enforce noninterference, you should not take this course and begin the transfer of information from a secret source to a public source. You might think you are going to take a fun formal reasoning course, but you have actually been exploited by a Man in the Middle Attack. You are communicating with a terrible class that is pretending to be a good formal reasoning course that has purposefully set up a Needham–Schroeder protocol to abuse this attack after throwing away Lowe from its protocol.Do not take this class. 1/5.
description: This course explores formal methods for computer security, including formal security models, relationships between security properties/policies and enforcement mechanisms, principled techniques and tools to specify, analyze, and construct secure computer systems. Specific topics include properties, hyperproperties, side channels, reasoning about cryptographic protocols, information flow, authorization logics, and verification techniques. Assessment will include homeworks and/or small projects during the semester as well as a final, larger project that is open-ended and driven by student interests.
notes: This course was previously numbered CS 254.

best_comment: Reading the recent research papers and presenting to the class was initially intimidating, but it was a fantastic experience. The first half of the class is basically just looking at what is happening at the DASlab, their research, and an introduction to the systems project, which was so amazing that I wanted to implement both of them. The second half is where students present research papers; each group is responsible for presenting papers. Choosing a good group, prep for it. This class is a no–brainer; take it. I loved this class. Probably one of the best CS classes I've taken at Harvard.
description: Big data is everywhere. A fundamental goal across numerous modern businesses and sciences is to be able to utilize as many machines as possible, to consume as much information as possible and as fast as possible. The big challenge is how to turn data into useful knowledge. This is a moving target as both the underlying hardware and our ability to collect data evolve. In this class, we discuss how to design data systems, data structures, and algorithms for key data-driven areas, including relational systems, distributed systems, graph systems, noSQL, newSQL, machine learning, and neural networks. We see how they all rely on the same set of very basic concepts and we learn how to synthesize efficient solutions for any problem across these areas using those basic concepts.
notes: This course was previously numbered CS 265.

course_title_2025: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture 001
best_comment: Very useful and interesting class!
course_title_2026: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture
description: This is a reading and discussion-based seminar designed for entering Computer Science Ph.D. students. This course prepares students to manage the difficult and often undiscussed challenges of Ph.D. programs through sessions on research skill building (e.g. paper reading, communication), soft skill building (e.g. managing advising relationships, supporting your peers), and academic culture (e.g. mental health in academia, power dynamics in scientific communities), as well as research and professional-oriented discussions. This is a full-year, 4-unit course, meeting once a week in each of the fall and the spring. Students must complete both terms of this course (CS 2901 and CS 2902) within the same academic year to receive credit.
notes: This course is required for new (G1) Computer Science Ph.D. students. It satisfies one of the CS 200-level electives (one of the 10 required classes for the Computer Science Ph.D. degree). SEAS G1 Ph.D. students in related fields may petition to enroll with instructor permission. This course was previously numbered CS 290B.
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: COMPSCI 290A

course_title_2025: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture 001
best_comment: Very useful and interesting class!
course_title_2026: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture

SEAS G1 Ph.D. students in related fields may petition to enroll with instructor permission. This course was previously numbered CS 290B.
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: COMPSCI 290A

best_comment: Writing a thesis was one of my most rewarding undertakings at Harvard! Do not be afraid, choose a topic you care about, and embrace the ups and downs! Some advice I have for future thesis writers … 1. Choose a project or topic that means something to you (i.e. a physical location / earth system you’re interested in, a project with policy implications you care about, a methodology that would be challenging but rewarding for you to master). I found this went a long way in energizing me to work on my thesis. 2. Think about when you’ll have pockets of time to really focus on your thesis. For me, it was helpful to carve out designated days or couple day stretches to put other things aside and really focus on my thesis (senior year winter break was an especially important stretch for me). Also, choose a designated thesis cave location (thank you Peet’s Coffee and Ernst Mayr library)! 3. Reading as much of the existing literature on your topic as possible will help you gain confidence and feel like the project is your own. I felt like I gained the most traction with my thesis when I started actively bringing new ideas and questions to meetings with my advisors. 4. Lean on other people (even in other concentrations who are writing a thesis) — it is a communal experience and it is fun talking / learning about other people’s little intellectual worlds!
description: Research and writing of the senior thesis under faculty direction.
notes: Senior honors candidates must take at least one term of this course (fall or spring) if writing a thesis; an oral presentation is required. To enroll, students must submit a registration form, which includes permission of their faculty sponsor, to the Academic Programs Manager.
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: E-PSCI 99A

best_comment: Be prepared to do the work, if you stay on top of it, you will cruise. I wasn’t a fan of the in class format personally but I could see how it works well for some. Eli is a fantastic lecturer, very entertaining and open minded. I would recommend this course for anyone interested in climate change and the math behind the science.
worse_comment: As someone who came into Harvard as a pretty committed climate activist with the intention of pursuing a full–time career in the environmental sciences, I’ll admit that I never thought it was possible to overstate the dangers of climate change. But this course challenged me to reconsider that assumption. I came to understand that there are real weaknesses and risks on both ends of the climate activism spectrum, whether through alarmism or denial. At the same time, the course helped me engage more deeply with the data itself, and I learned that while the evidence clearly supports the reality and urgency of climate change, it does not necessarily point to an immediate, apocalyptic collapse. That nuance was crucial.
description: An introduction to the science of global warming/climate change meant to assist students in understanding issues that often appear in the news and public debates. The course is intended for any STEM student with basic math preparation, yet not requiring any prior science courses. Topics include the greenhouse effect and consequences of the rise of greenhouse gasses, including sea level rise, heat waves, droughts, forest fires, expected changes to hurricanes, glacier melting, ocean acidification, and more. An ability to critically evaluate observations, predictions, risks, and popular press articles will be developed throughout. The students will be guided in a hands-on, in-class quantitative analysis of climate observations, models, and feedbacks using provided Python Jupyter notebooks.
notes: Non FAS students require instructor permission. This course fulfills the EPS sub-discipline requirement of Atmosphere(s) and Oceans. E-PSCI 101 is also offered as ESE 101. Students may not take both for credit. For SB students: this course can only count as a science elective in the concentration requirements, and SB students must enroll in E-PSCI 101. AB students may enroll in either E-PSCI 101 or ESE 101 to meet their concentration requirements.

best_comment: Great thermodynamics course that can be applied across most disciplines. Thermodynamics is often perceived as a difficult topic to comprehend, but I definitely think that Scot made it seem endurable and easier to understand.  Some concepts felt a little blurry, especially when you're looking at diagrams.  However, the books and lectures are mostly helpful. Section and office hours are definitely a key component of the course because that is where most of the application occurs. Also, be prepared to present every 2–3 weeks in this course. Most presentations are around 3 minutes and not too difficult if you put in the effort to learn the topic you want to discuss. Scot also likes to use cold–calling to induce classroom engagement.  I personally learn better in smaller sections/courses so definitely take this course if you need or are interested in thermo.
description: Fundamental concepts, formalisms, and examples of conservation of energy and change in entropy as applied to energy, environmental, and biological systems.
notes: E-PSCI 112 is also offered as ES 112. Students may not take both for credit. Undergraduate engineering students should enroll in ES 112. This course fulfills the EPS sub-discipline requirement of Climate, Atmosphere, and Oceans. Total class capacity of 18 includes students in both ES 112 and EPS 112. Please see course page for lottery instructions.

best_comment: This is an extremely enjoyable and worthwhile class.  Professor Jacob is thoughtful, engaging, and very knowledgable; he clearly cares deeply about the course material and wants to make sure that his students not only understand but also care.  Problem sets are useful and manageable; the final presentations are a low–stakes opportunity to dive more deeply into a topic of personal interest. I took this class as my last engineering elective and am very glad I did.
best_gem_comment: A gem of an EPS class! Really interesting and engaging and relevant to a variety of environmental and chemistry topics. Daniel is a wonderful lecturer and the structure of the class is really great! More about how much you learn than about how much you can memorize.
description: Chemical and physical processes determining the composition of the atmosphere and its implications for air pollution, climate, and life on Earth. Emphasis is on the construction of engineering models and the application of chemical principles to understand and address current environmental issues. Nitrogen, oxygen, and carbon cycles. Climate forcing by greenhouse gases and aerosols. Stratospheric ozone. Oxidizing power of the atmosphere. Methane. Surface air pollution: aerosols and ozone. Deposition to ecosystems: acid rain, nitrogen, mercury.
notes: E-PSCI 133 is also offered as ESE 133. Students may not take both for credit. This course fulfills the EPS sub-discipline requirement of Climate, Atmosphere, and Oceans.

course_title_2025: State-of-the-Art Harvard Climate Observatory and Associated Instrumentation 001
best_comment: Professor Jim is amazing, truly one of a kind. He creates a supportive and encouraging classroom environment and always provides thoughtful, constructive feedback. He genuinely cares about his students’ growth and makes sure you understand how to improve. His teaching goes beyond the material, he helps you become a better thinker and learner.
course_title_2026: State-of-the-Art Harvard Climate Observatory and Associated Instrumentation
description: ESE/EPS 166 engages the new Harvard Climate Observatory that will fundamentally herald a new era in both climate research and the development of strategic approaches to advancing the climate impact on public policy. The central objective of the New Climate Observatory is to address this problem by introducing, for the first time, the development of a new generation of innovative technology that takes explicit advantage of recent major advances in Harvard-based instruments and optical designs in combination with advanced solar powered stratospheric aeronautical design. The new solar powered stratospheric aircraft that together constitute the Climate Observatory engage multiple recent design innovations in photovoltaics, energy storage, as well as guidance and control. Together these enable a combination of long duration solar powered observing systems, each targeted at the highest priority risk factors that threaten global societal stability. The resulting observations will, for the first time, provide the irrefutable evidence needed for quantitative forecasts of the dominant risk factors stemming from the global use of fossil fuels.Important examples include the challenges of rapidly expanding wildfires in the western United States, the increasing rate of global sea level rise, the mechanisms controlling irreversible shifts in the large-scale (Brewer-Dobson) dynamical structure of the atmosphere, shifts in the drought patterns globally that trigger food shortages that in turn trigger refugee dislocation, as well as the mechanisms behind the loss of global fresh water supplies.While satellites have for years dominated the federal climate programs, for the purpose of developing tested and trusted quantitative forecasts of risk, satellites engender significant disadvantages. In sharp contrast to satellite systems, the new Harvard Climate Observatory provides, for the first time, orders of magnitude improvement in spatial and temporal resolution observations. ESE/EPS 166 will focus explicitly on this new generation of climate observations, forecasting, and resulting advances in public policy. An important part of the course is the display of Harvard designed and developed flight instruments in the laboratory in the context of multiple strategies for addressing unsolved scientific problems with new instrumentation.
notes: EPS 166 integrates the challenges of climate scientific objectives with the strategy for instrument innovation, the lab is also integrated with the course structure.  EPS 166 is also offered as ESE 166. Students may not take both for credit.

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! The teachers are ALL SPECTACULAR!!! They are so fun, so understanding, and so so helpful in learning Chinese. There is no other class and no other teachers I would have rather learned Chinese from, because they are that incredible. The class is definitely a bit of a time commitment, but it is so worth it, and this class has probably had the most payoff of any class I’ve taken at Harvard so far. Off–cycle (spring semester) is kinda nice because the smaller number of students makes a really personable class environment, but whether on– or off–cycle, the class is just an absolute joy and a great learning environment. Guo, Chen, and Zhang Laoshi are incredible teachers who understand so deeply well how teaching Chinese to English speakers work. They try so hard to make the class as good as it can be, and it absolutely works. There is no other language I would rather take here than Chinese because the department is incredible and BA is definitely in my top 5 favorite classes I’ve ever taken throughout my life! Also, I knew 0 Chinese coming in to the class, and I still got by really well! As long as you do the work, you absolutely don’t need to have taken Chinese previously to do well in this class. SO WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR??? TAKE BA!!!!
description: Non-intensive introduction to modern Chinese pronunciation, grammar, conversation, reading, and writing.
notes: No auditors. May not be taken Pass/Fail.

course_title_2025: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 002
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU WANT TO HAVE LOTS OF FUN AND LAUGHS WHILE ALSO RAISING YOUR CHINESE PROFICIENCY AND FLUENCY!!! Definitely one of my favorite courses I've taken at Harvard. Not only you'll become more confident and skillful in using formal chinese to discuss more complex and interesting topics, but you'll also be able to engage with your classmates in various group activities. While this is primarily a language course, you'll also talk about chinese culture, history, internet trends, social issues, and much more. The smaller class environment allows for a bit more personalized learning experience and you really get to know your classmates. Overall, it's an amazing course that I would highly recommend if you're looking to fulfill your foreign language requirement, working towards your chinese language citation, or just want to take chinese in general!
worse_comment: This course is an excellent course for students wishing to learn Chinese. It's everyday but that really simulates immersion. There are a few difficulties — like, you can't miss many classes which seems unfair for having it everyday.
course_title_2026: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners
description: Designed for students whose Chinese speaking and listening skills are near-native, but whose reading and writing skills are at a high-intermediate level. This course focuses on reading texts based on current issues and cultural phenomena, and then applying complex grammar structures acquired to students’ own writing. Covers the equivalent of Chinese 130b and other materials for reading and writing.
notes: No auditors. May not be taken Pass/Fail.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: Chinese 130XA or equivalent.

course_title_2025: The Modern History of Rural China 01
best_comment: Take this class! This class has everything you could want: great content where you will actually learn a lot, fun assignments that are challenging in a good way, fair and clear grading, amazing lectures, and interesting discussions in class and in section. This is really a class that does everything right, so I highly highly recommend.
course_title_2026: The Modern History of Rural China
description: It’s only in the last twenty years that China has become known as a place of cities and factories.  Before then, the majority of Chinese people lived not in cities but in villages in the countryside, and made their living from agriculture.  This lecture/discussion course, intended mainly for undergraduates, will introduce you to the modern history of rural China.  We’ll approach that history chronologically, thematically, and historiographically. No background knowledge of China is required, but the course might interest you even if you have some previous background, because it will show you the People’s Republic of China from a very different angle than what you’ve likely encountered before: that of its villages and the people who live in them.  You’ll come to appreciate their perspective better through taking their role in two interactive games.  You’ll also learn why the fate of China’s countryside matters to the future not only of China but also the whole world.

best_comment: Japanese 140b with Asakura先生 and Higurashi先生 was an absolute blast! I had so much fun in this class because (1) the homework assignments are pretty straightforward and fast, (2) the content is genuinely interesting (rakugo, traditional Japanese stories, subculture, dialects, short stories), (3) I had SOOOO many friends in the class (since I continued from 130ab), and (4) the outside–class events were insanely fun (making mochi, presenting final reports, end–of–year party). Both the teachers are great at engaging the class and sparking interesting discussions. Even tho I took this class mostly 9 am, I never felt sleepy or bored, and I always got a chance to speak. For me, I feel like Japanese language classes have been a consistent highlight of my time at harvard.
description: Continuation of Japanese 140a.  Readings of modern texts in both rapid and in-depth modes. Comprehension of media news and drama. Advanced conversation and composition on topics related to the preceding.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: Japanese 140A or equivalent.

best_comment: This class is very demanding of time and energy (like the workload is truly foul at times), but you can get a lot out of it and make good friends too. The 선생님 are great.
description: Korean 120b is the second half of the intermediate course and the continuation of Korean 120a. This course is designed for students who have completed Korean 120a or have demonstrated equivalent proficiency. The goal of this course is to increase students’ ability to communicate in Korean in a wide range of daily life situations, and the course places equal focus on expanding and consolidating students’ fundamental structural knowledge of Korean. Students are introduced to reading and listening materials, of increasing complexity, on a variety of topics in modern Korean society and culture.

best_comment: This is a fast paced course, but it's super fun and engaging. The teachers are very nice and make a great class environment. I feel like I really got a lot more confidence in speaking and writing in Korean.
description: Korean 123xb is a continuation of Korean Bx and is for those who have received significant exposure to Korean language and culture and thus have some listening and speaking skills. It is an accelerated course covering important grammatical structures and materials from Intermediate Korean (120a and 120b) for the purpose of providing tools to build upon the basic foundation of student’s Korean language ability. Hence, this class is designed to meet the linguisitic needs that are unique to heritage language students to (i) increase accuracy in grammar, (ii) develop basic reading writing skills, and (iii) expand vocabulary through introduction of Chinese characters.

worse_comment: Ba/Bb and 120a/b are much better courses and are more organized. I feel like this class was extremely messy and many of the assignments were not helpful in expanding my Korean knowledge. Most people take this class in order to complete a citation, so if you are reading this, you are probably going to take the class anyways, but just know I did not enjoy it.
description: Korean 130b is the second half of a pre-advanced Korean course designed for students who have either successfully completed the first half of a pre-advanced Korean course (Korean 130a) or have an equivalent background in Korean language and culture. Students in this course will reinforce their mastery of previously learned grammatical patterns and vocabulary through written and audio-visual materials covering a variety of topics. They will also explore various culture-related topics and styles in Korean while further improving their speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills, enabling them to better comprehend Korean culture and society.

best_comment: It's pretty good! There is a lot of work compared to Ec10a in the fall, as you have more writing (Deep Dives can get especially cumbersome), and while you don't have problem sets (which is nice), you do have section write ups, which also take a while, but sometimes you can get through most of them in section which is really nice. Anne is great and super enthusiastic about the content of the class, and altho it's kinda early, she really does try her best to keep everyone awake and engaged! The smaller class was kinda nice too and felt more approachable and personable. I will say though, the midterm and final are tough, so definitely be aware of those and really really study hard for them
worse_comment: This class is not the same as on cycle Ec10a.  Anne is a good lecturer but I found the slides to be hard to follow, and this made studying for midterms/finals difficult. Know that most of your grade will come from entirely multiple choice assessments (for us, midterm+final were 60% of the grade, and they were both entirely multiple choice). This is the same as on cycle ec10, but you also have a bunch of other random assignments that they do not. For example, the deep dives and final project. Deep dives are every two or three weeks, and they are a big time commitment. That is what makes the course so hard to follow; you can't plan out how much time you need per week because it is always changing. The deep dives and final project also have very little relevance to the exams, so it is a frustrating mix of needing to still do the assignments but knowing they are not helping for the main chunk of the graded part of the class. It is a fine class, but I wouldn't recommend if you aren't considering an econ concentration. Just take it on cycle; this class is inconsistent and harder than I feel it should be.
description: Economists study human behavior using a combination of models and data. Ec10a introduces students to economic models using intuitive discussions, graphical analysis, and, in some cases, basic algebra. The models study individual decision-making and markets, and range from classical approaches like supply and demand to more recent approaches that consider informational limitations and behavioral mistakes. We will also use data to understand the strengths and weaknesses of these models. The course also discusses the role that ethics and values play in people's choices and in policy discussions, including an understanding and critique of approaches like utilitarianism, Rawlsian principles of justice, and libertarianism. The goal of the course is to provide students with a set of tools that will help them develop answers for themselves on how to make better choices and participate in debates on major public policy issues in areas including tax policy, inequality, discrimination and racial justice, and the environment.
notes: Ec10a is the first half of an integrated sequence that continues with the study of macroeconomics in Ec10b. Students may elect to take only the microeconomics course and receive four credits. This sequence is designed with two types of students in mind. For students who will never take another economics course, Ec10a and Ec10b provide a self-contained training to prepare them to understand and engage with economic issues. For students who end up concentrating in economics, Ec10a and Ec10b provide a wide-ranging introduction to the field and are required courses. The Department of Economics strongly encourages students considering concentrating in economics to take these courses during their first year at the College. Ec10a and Ec10b are not duplicative of AP Economics courses but aim to provide a broader perspective and a deeper engagement with public policy and current developments in the field of economics (e.g., behavioral economics). Either Ec10a or Ec10b fulfills the Social Sciences divisional distribution requirement. It is not necessary for students to take both halves of Ec10 to fulfill this divisional requirement.

best_comment: Ec10b was a great course. I have a much better understanding of how the macroeconomy functions, from the role of the Fed to the effects of tariffs to the stock market. The lectures were well–developed. The course did not include much fine detail and instead focused more on developing our intuition about macroeconomics; without prior experience in macroeconomics, I valued this approach. It allowed me to understand macroeconomics as a whole before deciding whether I want to explore the area in more depth. However, if you have taken macroeconomics in the past, this course might not be challenging enough. Additionally, some of Jason's lectures felt dry and dragged on a little. The content was interesting, but I think he could have presented it with greater tonal variation and expressivity.The guest lectures were incredible. When David and Jason discussed topics in class, they mentioned some of the most important research on that topic, and the guest lectures were usually part of that research! I felt lucky to be exposed to such giants in economics!However, I would have liked a more diverse range of guest speakers. Most of them were academics or politicians, and I would have liked to hear from more industry experts, such as bankers.The psets improved my grasp of the content. I especially liked how they reflected present–day events, like the effects of Covid and tariffs. Through them, I applied what I had learned in class and became more confident with the material.The problem–solving sessions are an incredible resource. The CAs helped me work through the psets and understand the concepts involved. They were all nice and supportive. The unit review program is also quite valuable. By studying for them, I consolidated my understanding of the material. The feedback I got after taking them showed me how well I had learned the content and where I should focus my studying. Because the problem–solving sessions and unit review program are so useful, I would highly suggest attending themThe tests do a good job of testing our understanding and problem–solving skills. The practice tests are a very useful resource to study for them; in fact, I think some of the questions were essentially identical to the tests.
worse_comment: FOR HUMANITIES STUDENTS:If you're on the fence about this class, take it!!!!! Cannot recommend highly enough. Gives you real world knowledge you're not gonna get elsewhere. Highly, highly recommend.
description: Ec10b continues the curriculum presented in Ec10a, moving to the study of macroeconomics including the growth of the overall economy, business cycles, and economic crises. Ec10b explains what economists do and do not understand about these issues by developing analytical approaches and examining data, including studying the global financial crisis and the economic crisis caused by COVID-19. The course also explains how policy makers can dampen economic fluctuations using monetary policy (i.e., government influence over interest rates and government regulation of banks), fiscal policy (e.g., government control of spending and taxation), and financial rescues in economic crises. We will also discuss how macroeconomic policies work in an international context, including the factors that affect exchange rates, trade deficits, international capital flows, and how these link economies around the world. Like Ec10a, Ec10b introduces students to economic models and discusses both how they are supported and how they are contradicted by available data.
notes: Ec10b is the second half of an integrated sequence that begins with the study of microeconomics in Ec10a. Students may elect to take only the fall microeconomics course or only the spring macroeconomics course and receive four credits. This sequence is designed with two types of students in mind. For students who will never take another economics course, Ec10a and Ec10b provide a self-contained training to prepare them to understand and engage with economic issues. For students who end up deciding to be Economics Concentrators, Ec10a and Ec10b provide a wide-ranging introduction to the field and are required courses. The Department of Economics strongly encourages students considering concentrating in Economics to take these courses during their first year in the College. Ec10a and Ec10b are not duplicative of AP Economics courses but aim to provide a broader perspective and a deeper engagement with public policy. Ec10a or Ec10b fulfills the Social Sciences divisional distribution requirement. It is not necessary for students to take both halves of Ec10 to fulfill this requirement.

It allowed me to understand macroeconomics as a whole before deciding whether I want to explore the area in more depth. However, if you have taken macroeconomics in the past, this course might not be challenging enough. Additionally, some of Jason's lectures felt dry and dragged on a little. The content was interesting, but I think he could have presented it with greater tonal variation and expressivity.The guest lectures were incredible. When David and Jason discussed topics in class, they mentioned some of the most important research on that topic, and the guest lectures were usually part of that research! I felt lucky to be exposed to such giants in economics!However, I would have liked a more diverse range of guest speakers. Most of them were academics or politicians, and I would have liked to hear from more industry experts, such as bankers.The psets improved my grasp of the content. I especially liked how they reflected present–day events, like the effects of Covid and tariffs. Through them, I applied what I had learned in class and became more confident with the material.The problem–solving sessions are an incredible resource. The CAs helped me work through the psets and understand the concepts involved. They were all nice and supportive. The unit review program is also quite valuable. By studying for them, I consolidated my understanding of the material. The feedback I got after taking them showed me how well I had learned the content and where I should focus my studying. Because the problem–solving sessions and unit review program are so useful, I would highly suggest attending themThe tests do a good job of testing our understanding and problem–solving skills. The practice tests are a very useful resource to study for them; in fact, I think some of the questions were essentially identical to the tests.
worse_comment: FOR HUMANITIES STUDENTS:If you're on the fence about this class, take it!!!!! Cannot recommend highly enough. Gives you real world knowledge you're not gonna get elsewhere. Highly, highly recommend.
description: Ec10b continues the curriculum presented in Ec10a, moving to the study of macroeconomics including the growth of the overall economy, business cycles, and economic crises. Ec10b explains what economists do and do not understand about these issues by developing analytical approaches and examining data, including studying the global financial crisis and the economic crisis caused by COVID-19. The course also explains how policy makers can dampen economic fluctuations using monetary policy (i.e., government influence over interest rates and government regulation of banks), fiscal policy (e.g., government control of spending and taxation), and financial rescues in economic crises. We will also discuss how macroeconomic policies work in an international context, including the factors that affect exchange rates, trade deficits, international capital flows, and how these link economies around the world. Like Ec10a, Ec10b introduces students to economic models and discusses both how they are supported and how they are contradicted by available data.
notes: Ec10b is the second half of an integrated sequence that begins with the study of microeconomics in Ec10a. Students may elect to take only the fall microeconomics course or only the spring macroeconomics course and receive four credits. This sequence is designed with two types of students in mind. For students who will never take another economics course, Ec10a and Ec10b provide a self-contained training to prepare them to understand and engage with economic issues. For students who end up deciding to be Economics Concentrators, Ec10a and Ec10b provide a wide-ranging introduction to the field and are required courses. The Department of Economics strongly encourages students considering concentrating in Economics to take these courses during their first year in the College. Ec10a and Ec10b are not duplicative of AP Economics courses but aim to provide a broader perspective and a deeper engagement with public policy. Ec10a or Ec10b fulfills the Social Sciences divisional distribution requirement. It is not necessary for students to take both halves of Ec10 to fulfill this requirement.

best_comment: This is absolutely the section to take for Ec 970. Haiyang is a phenomenal instructor and very flexible when other things come up. It is going to be very work–intensive but so is every other section, so you might as well take one that is interesting with a good teacher. Also prepares you very well for a career after Harvard if you are interested in the corporate world.
description: A series of seminars taught in small sections focusing on applications of economic theory to real problems.
notes: One term required of all Economics concentrators. Enrollment limited to concentrators. Meets in assigned section.
course_requirements:
Requisite: (ECON 1010A, ECON 1011A, or ECON S-1010) AND (STAT 100, STAT S-100,
STAT 102, STAT 104, STAT 109/109a, STAT 110, APMTH 101, MATH 18b/19b, MATH 154, Econ 1123, Econ S-1123, or Econ 1126)

best_comment: This is an excellent elective. The readings are all very interesting while still being relatively manageable, and Dr. Baranga is an incredibly dedicated instructor. He provides detailed feedback on all assignments and makes class very engaging while ensuring that the material is accessible and easy to understand. I liked how the course brought in the real world — this semester was one with a lot of trade policy news, and we got a chance to discuss current events in the context of what we had learned. In sum, I'd highly recommend this option for your sophomore tutorial.

best_comment: This is a required class for the Economics Concentration, so you don't really have a choice whether to take it or not. But there are many options of topics, so you should be able to find one that is of interest to you. Besides for the final paper, the other papers are relatively short and don't take too much time. There are readings at least twice a week, but often times you can get the relevant information from the abstract/by skimming the results/conclusion sections. The final paper is definitely an intense assignment, but if you take the prospectus seriously, you will have at least a good outline going into reading week. It's a small class (no more than 8–12 people) so you can get a lot of support from your professor if you need it.

best_comment: This is a great course to learn how to understand + write Economics papers! Make sure to choose a subject that you are passionate about because everything in the class (the papers + dicussions) revolve around that specific niche. Do some preliminary research on your course head as well as you will spend signficant time with them. Finally, if you want to write a senior thesis, this course will be absolutely essential to your preparation.

best_comment: Landoni's behavioral finance tutorial is AWESOME. The material is extremely interesting and Landoni is an excellent teacher.  It is clear that he is excited about the material and is always extremely well–prepared for class. He is a unique professor, and I mean that in a good way. The right amount quirky! best_comment: Mattia is a tough grader. He is pretty fair, but I think you will find him harsher than expected, and you have to work pretty hard to improve grades. I was able to, and it did improve the quality of my work, but I think it should be a fair warning that this class IS hard. You have to spend time on your submissions and carefully think through your reasoning on what you wrote. You must do the readings and you have to think of things to say to get participation credit. Just asking questions is not enough think of something to contribute. Mattia makes you start the paper way earlier than most sections and that is the best because you can just put all your past assignements together (with some editing and expansion of course) and then your final is already done. But, be mindful that you have to as a result pick a topic early and plan ahead when you submit proposals. Simple proposals are better.

best_comment: BEST CLASS I'VE TAKEN AT HARVARD and this was due to our incredible instructor, Omar. I absolutely loved this class. Our tutorial focused on managerial decision making, and the readings that Omar selected tied into important business and technology problems and helped me to critically think about real–world business challenges. I found this to be much more applicable than many other courses I've taken here, and it's a course I feel confident will shape the way I think about business problems for many years to come. It also drastically improved my ability to read research papers, understand econometric methods, and write essays, largely because of the way that Omar broke down these topics, provided in–depth feedback, and always made expectations clear for assignments. He is incredibly knowledgeable about econometrics, business, and technology, and he knew the papers very well and helped our class think about them on a much deeper level. Not only that, but we had many engaging class activities that I really enjoyed and that helped me learn in a more hands–on way.  This course could have doubled as instruction about how the ideal class should be taught. I've never felt this sad for a course to come to an end; it was truly an amazing class and I feel very lucky to have been in it, especially with Omar as my instructor.As far as other advice, I'd recommend at least concurrently taking econometrics, as this will really help understand the methods of papers. I'm not sure if Omar will teach another tutorial, but if he does I'd highly recommend taking one with him. I'd also say to choose a topic you're interested in, as this will make it easier to get through the readings and stay engaged during the class discussions. Additionally, the PSETs provide a lot more support for Stata than R, so I'd recommend Stata if you're choosing between languages. Finally, don't underestimate the workload, as you will have to complete PSETs, do many readings, and write papers, including a very long final paper. All of this can lead to a pretty significant workload, although I don't think that any of the work ever felt like busy work which I appreciated.

best_comment: Take the Melkonian Section!! Any sophomore tutorial you take is going to be a lot of work; this one definitely had its fair share, but Melkonian is phenomenal! His rubrics are very straightforward, so if you simply do your work with the rubric, you will have success. He is accessible outside of class and understanding of needs. Strict on little points on essays but all around not an incredibly harsh grader! He wants you to succeed!! If this is offered again, you should definitely take it.
description: A series of seminars taught in small sections focusing on applications of economic theory to real problems.
notes: One term required of all Economics concentrators. Enrollment limited to concentrators. Meets in assigned section.
course_requirements:
Requisite: (ECON 1010A, ECON 1011A, or ECON S-1010) AND (STAT 100, STAT S-100,
STAT 102, STAT 104, STAT 109/109a, STAT 110, APMTH 101, MATH 18b/19b, MATH 154, Econ 1123, Econ S-1123, or Econ 1126)

best_comment: I’d recommend this class with Coly with enthusiasm. The readings can be long and dense, but I think this is in line with most sophomore tutorial classes. The papers we read are super interesting and concern the US but also more global climate economics. Assignments are very easily manageable. I was also lucky to have a great class that was very happy to discuss papers.

best_comment: I took the Economics of Homelessness with Patrick Power and I strongly recommend you to take this class! Patrick leads sections with great care, ensuring everyone truly understands the material. He also assigns relevant and interesting coursework, so I truly enjoyed taking the course. He also takes the time to meet with you in office hours to make sure you are on track for the course. The hard part of the course lies in the PSets. The Office Hours are not that frequent and the staff are not always that helpful. I struggled through the PSets, but everything else in the course was absolutely great. Patrick was very fair in his assignments and workloads, and understands we all have very busy lives. Patrick is awesome and has the best 970 Section hands down!

best_comment: Ec 970 is great because it puts your Economics degree together. First, you learn how to read a research paper in–depth, with discussions that help you understand along the way. Then, you learn how to write each individual component of a paper. Finally, you put it all together writing a paper of your own. If you can take Economics of Cities, please do. Andrés is as fantastic of an instructor as he is a person, and will help you grow and learn throughout the semester. The classroom environment he creates is extremely fun, which helps get through an otherwise–difficult economics class.

Requisite: (ECON 1010A, ECON 1011A, or ECON S-1010) AND (STAT 100, STAT S-100,

best_comment: This class is a big time commitment with many long readings each class and frequent papers but sooo worth it and rewarding. Prof Felter is absolutely amazing and so committed to each of his students individually. He also knows about literally anything law–related, making this class an amazing intro to studying law. It's really cool to see how economic concepts can be applied to law, and this class really forces you to think in a new way that combines logical reasoning, economic intuition, and the way lawyers think.
worse_comment: PLEASE DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE. I am warning you and trying to save you a semester of pain and suffering. Professor Felter and grading of this course was very subjective and frustrating. After meeting with the professor multiple times, working everyday in Lamont for long hours, getting support from additional staff members (Ec970 office hours, librarians, writing center, etc.), I received the same bad grade and extremely discouraging comments every single time. Myself and others felt we could never improve, no matter what we tried. Professor Felter chooses who he likes in the beginning of the year and sticks with it. Some people may have loved this class, but they were probably his two favorites, and the majority  of the class holds the same opinion as myself.  I also felt shut down at times as Professor Felter is not the easiest to talk to, and towards the end of semester was very booked for his office hours. Furthermore, the bar and workload of the class was way higher than any other Econ Tutorial that I know of. We had papers and PSETs due on the same day multiple times, and readings were extremely lengthy and boring. All our draft papers were letter graded as short essays, whereas I know other classes were graded as completion. Lastly, the class discussion was very mundane and you could tell no one in the class cared or was participating. As someone interested in law, this class actively disuaded me against it. I would not recommend this class to anyone. The amount of work is insurmountable, and I had nothing to show for it but a bad grade and comments that made me feel very poorly about my academic abilities. In the end, this course discouraged me immensely and was my worst class of the semester and professor I liked the least.

best_comment: This course was wonderful! Christina is very helpful and is available to answer any questions you have about the course, the readings, or economic research in general. I would say to start the papers (especially the final project) early because it is a lot of work.
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THE FINANCE AND PROGRESS SECTION. IT WAS ABSOLUTELY TERRIBLE.

best_comment: You should take your Econ 970 seminar with Professor Ulusoy. He is very child and there to help you. All of the sections will be a lot of work, but he made it so much more fun. He has some amazing stories about Turkey and the political landscape which are very interesting and engaging. WOULD HIGHLY RECOMMEND

best_comment: This was one of the most fun and interesting courses I have taken at Harvard and highly highly recommend to any ec concentrators or anyone interested in research! In core economics classes, they always throw around the term "RCT" but rarely ever look at experiments in practice. This class is super interactive because you actually get to design those experiments and think through all the logistics as if you were going to conduct them. If you love problem–solving, this course is definitely a great fit for you. You also get to know your peers as a lot of work in class is in groups, and I have made friends through that. Finally, a significant portion of this class is presentations. People get really creative with them, and they are a ton of fun to listen to! Professor Pallais and Wilbur were amazing and always made themselves available through email and office hours, so you have a ton of support too.
description: Field experiments (experiments that take place in real-world settings) are increasingly being used to analyze public policies, make business decisions, and test theories. This class will dive into how to design a field experiment and will use experiments to learn about the research process more generally. We will discuss some of the most exciting recent experimental research as well as how to frame a question so that the research informs policy, when to trust research discussed in the popular press, and how to interpret and apply results to improve decision-making.

best_comment: Take some more time to clearly plan out your research question in the beginning. If you can finish most of data analysis before winter break, your pacing will be great for the spring semester before you turn in your thesis. If possible, more regular meetings with your advisor would be ideal!
description: Workshop for seniors writing economics theses, taught in classes of approximately 12 students each. Emphasis on choice of research topics, methodology, and writing. Students are required to complete written and oral presentations of their work in progress. Part one of a two-part series; students must complete both terms of this course (parts A and B) within the same academic year in order to receive credit. This seminar is required for economics concentrators writing senior theses. Thesis writers in other concentrations writing on economics topics may take the seminar, space-permitting.
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: ECON 985A

best_comment: If you have a reasonably sized question that excites you, you should write a thesis! Though it can be (incredibly) painful in the moment, I believe the reward is worth it.

best_comment: I had an unconventional thesis timeline and my section leader was very accommodating. Make sure you have a section leader that is accommodating if you expect to be on a different timeline than most other students. Good course overall. Doesn't meet weekly.

best_comment: You have to take it if you're writing a thesis, so you don't really have a choice. But it will be a helpful way to get feedback from your classmates and especially your preceptor, who is there to really help you refine and work through your thesis, from the empirical strategy to the presentation of results. I'm glad I had this scaffolding to keep my work on track.
