best_comment: Finding an advisor who is also invested in your project is very important, second only to getting your hands on data as early as possible.  Not much accountability with this seminar in particular so it really has to be self–directed/self–motivated to stay on track.  Have fun with it!
description: Workshop for seniors writing economics theses, taught in classes of approximately 12 students each. Emphasis on choice of research topics, methodology, and writing. Students are required to complete written and oral presentations of their work in progress. Part one of a two-part series; students must complete both terms of this course (parts A and B) within the same academic year in order to receive credit. This seminar is required for economics concentrators writing senior theses. Thesis writers in other concentrations writing on economics topics may take the seminar, space-permitting.
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: ECON 985A

best_comment: Theses take up a lot of time but can be rewarding if the question you are researching is important to you in some way, you have a good advisor and thesis instructor. I was lucky to have all three and so even though doing a thesis did change the make up of my senior year tremendously I feel proud of the piece of work that I was able to produce.
description: Workshop for seniors writing economics theses, taught in classes of approximately 12 students each. Emphasis on choice of research topics, methodology, and writing. Students are required to complete written and oral presentations of their work in progress. Part one of a two-part series; students must complete both terms of this course (parts A and B) within the same academic year in order to receive credit. This seminar is required for economics concentrators writing senior theses. Thesis writers in other concentrations writing on economics topics may take the seminar, space-permitting.
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: ECON 985A

best_comment: The actual presentation of your thesis is as important as the research you are doing. If a thesis reader can't grasp exactly what it is that you've done in a quick glance, then you're setting yourself up for failure. In a perfect world, all thesis readers would take the time to read every page—but this is not the reality, especially since we have no control over who reads our work. In order to have time to work on the actual structure and writing of your argument, CONTINUE WORKING OVER WINTER BREAK! I did this, which provided a lot more wiggle room to inevitably make mistakes. Something that is little talked about is the honors exam. It creeps up quickly—unlike what you may expect, it doesn't happening during finals period. If you take spring break off to decompress from thesis writing, then you only have two weeks to study. That's simply not enough time. If you can, try to start studying earlier. That being said, this a big critique of mine of the Economics Department, and I hope that this will change soon. Good luck to all thesis writers! As long as you stay diligent, you'll make it out on the other side!

best_comment: This class is great!! Melitz is an amazing lecturer, and he is genuinely interested in teaching. He is always available to answer questions, and he makes a point to stay after lecture and talk to anybody that wants to (there is often a line, as he gives attentive responses). The class is supposedly a lot better off cycle, and I would agree. There are not as many study groups or class resources, but they post good information to use for studying and the textbook (written by the prof) is a great way to clear anything up. If you read the textbook and do the assignments honestly, you will learn the material without much outside work on your end. An A is a little tough, but can be done with attentiveness and studying for the exams. Would recommend!
worse_comment: Keep up with the material and study well in advance for the exams!! They are difficult
description: The course introduces core microeconomic models of consumers, firms, and markets, and develops their application to a broad range of economic and social issues in the real world.
notes: Students that have Equivalent Math Placement scores may enroll with instructor consent.  Simultaneous enrollment is not permitted for this course.
course_requirements: Math 1a or Math 1b or (Math Ma and Math Mb) or (Math Qa and Math Qb) or (Math Ma and Math Q) or Math 18a/21a/22b/23/25/55  or AM21a/22b or equivalent AP Scores (5 in AP AB calc or a 5 in AP BC calc)

best_comment: I LOVE THIS CLASS!!!! I am an Econ concentrator, but usually economic concepts and classes are very hard for me because I'm not too much of a STEM/numbers person. But, this was BY FAR my favorite economics class I've taken so far at this school...including the electives which is saying a lot. Professor Foote I ADORE. He was so engaging (adding jokes in between slides) and made the macro topics very relevant and applicable to real life. He was ALWAYS willing to help outside of class and answer questions (I showed up at 8:30 on multiple occasions...) and the problem sets were incredibly reasonable content–wise and length (doing them made me understand the material much better!). I love how the sections/p–sets are optional because it gives you flexibility but also resources when you need them. The midterms (which I know two can be a lot and it lowkey stressed me out, but it was beneficial in forcing me to study and review all the material throughout the course rather than all at once at the end) and final adequately reflected the teaching in the class and there were so many resources to help with preparing like office hours, practice exams, etc. TAKE THIS CLASS DON'T BE SCARED! You do just need to put in time and effort.
worse_comment: Study a lot for the exams, don't dwell on optional psets too much, just make sure to really master the practice exam questions. And pay attention to any tangent Foote goes off on, those topics are likely to show up on the exams. He is an amazing person and a great lecturer, but the course structure is quite poor. 90% of your grade being dependent on multiple choice exams means most of your knowledge won't fully be tested and you will simply struggle a lot if you are bad at MCQs (i was).
description: Theories and evidence on economic growth and fluctuations. Determination of gross domestic product, investment, consumption, employment, and unemployment. Analysis of interest rates, wage rates, and inflation. Roles of fiscal and monetary policies.
notes: Students may only take one of Economics 1010b or Economics 1011b for concentration credit.

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Professor Fryer is the most brilliant professor I've ever had. He is unbelievably smart –– but, perhaps more importantly, he is a fantastic, charismatic lecturer. The three hour class totally flew by. The midterm and the final were not hard if you studied –– it's just about memorizing a lot of content, but the tests were all multiple choice. Be aware that the class is very poorly organized. Readings were unclear, and would vary from 0  (multiple times) to 500 (twice) pages a week. Some weeks you didn't have to do the reading, some weeks it was more important. To me, the class was definitely well worth the disorganization. But if that's not for you, that's fine. But cannot emphasize enough how much I loved this class. It is so so so so worth taking this course. Please do it.
description: Examines the life and work of African-American geniuses – both historic and contemporary – in social justice, academics, the arts, and education with a particular focus on how their life and work affects economic thought and our understanding of human behavior. Profiles include: W.E.B. Dubois, Ida B. Wells, David Blackwell, Martin Luther King, Geoffrey Canada, Mary McCleod Bethune, and more. The economic topics that are highlighted include the economics of slavery, identity and social interactions, integration, health, education, and labor markets.

course_title_2025: Using Markets to Solve Social Problems 001
best_comment: Amazing class. Professor Fryer is super engaging and always makes lecture super fun! Also, the lecture topics are pretty interesting. The midterm was a little rough, but as long as you put in some effort into this class you will do great on it. Also the final project is designing a startup and it was so cool. 10/10 would recommend
worse_comment: Do NOT take this class. The structure is embarrassing to the Harvard name. No class at this institution should be so horrible organized, unfair and left up to chance. Friar is an interesting lecturer, but was entirely uninvolved in any content besides his own lecturing, in which he was quite repetitive and focused mainly on his own research. The mid–term was a dumpster fire, the content was not taught in the class and was barely addressed in the textbook. I studied everything from lecture, the singular (horrible) review session and the textbook, and it was not applicable to what they decided to test on. The test itself had content errors, typing errors and closed early causing different students to have different amounts of time on the test which was extremely unfair. Capstone project was interesting, but the presentation was extremely poorly organized as well.  The participation part of your grade is basically fake–they took attendance twice and said that asking questions during the capstone presentations would count, but then proceeded to disregard any questions that were asked.
course_title_2026: Using Markets to Solve Social Problems
description: This course will demonstrate how one can use the power of the free market to address some of the most vexing social and economic problems of our time, with a particular emphasis on issues that plague minority communities and women. The course will give students an introduction to social finance and impact investing in a manner that does not require prior coursework in Economics. It is intended not only for those interested in finance or social justice, but also for students with a disruptor spirit.   Students will study situations in which market-based approaches were used to solve problems in areas such as education, discrimination, economic mobility, crime, healthcare, food instability, and the future of work. In the context of these topics, the course will provide an introduction to basic principles in finance and for-profit enterprises, venture capital, and other alternative investment strategies. The course will include discussions with leading investors and entrepreneurs who are determined to have positive social impact and culminates in a team-based capstone project in which you build your own startup to take on an important social issue and demonstrate its commercial viability.

best_comment: Would definitely recommend this class to fulfill the theory requirement for ec. The content was super interesting even if you aren't very familiar with mainstream sports. The lectures could get boring sometimes, but overall Judd is super nice and is super helpful if you want help brainstorming project ideas or just to talk about sports. The AI policy is also super nice.
description: This course will apply economic principles from game theory, labor economics, and econometrics to analyze a wide range of issues primarily in the realm of professional sports and collegiate athletics rigorously with a focus on causality. Topics include: the hot hand; expansion and rival leagues; franchise relocation and venue construction; revenues from merchandising, broadcast rights and their distribution; free agency, arbitration, and salary caps; player development through amateur drafts and minor leagues; NCAA rules on scholarships and eligibility; in-game strategy;  and financial aspects of collegiate athletic programs. Class discussion, problem sets, and an exam will form the bulk of the course requirements. Readings will draw upon a variety of sources, including Andrew Zimbalist's Baseball and Billions, Robert Frank and Phil Cook's The Winner-Take-All Society, and newspaper, magazine and academic journal articles.

best_comment: Professor is great, and the class was very interesting and so much fun. We got to play games in class, and the prof gave us actual money when we won, that was pretty cool. He is also one of the best talkers that I have seen.
worse_comment: Keep up with the material as it scales in difficulty quickly. P–Sets take a deceivingly long time.
description: Game theory is the study of interdependent decision-making.  In the early days of the cold war, game theory was used to analyze an emerging nuclear arms race; today, it has applications in economics, psychology, politics, the law and other fields.  In this course, we will explore the “strategic way of thinking” as developed by game theorists over the past sixty years.  Special attention will be paid to the move from zero-sum to nonzero-sum game theory.  Students will learn the basic solution concepts of game theory -- including minimax and Nash equilibrium -- by playing and analyzing games in class, and then we will take up some game-theoretic applications in negotiation settings: the strategic use of threats, bluffs and promises.  We will also study the repeated prisoner’s dilemma and investigate how cooperative behavior may emerge in a population of rational egoists.  This problematic -- “the evolution of cooperation” -- extends from economics and political science to biology and artificial intelligence, and it presents a host of interesting challenges for both theoretical and applied research.  Finally, we will consider the changing context for the development of game theory today, in particular, the need to achieve international cooperation on economic and environmental issues. The course has two main objective: to introduce students to the fundamental problems and solution concepts of noncooperative game theory; and to provide an historical perspective on its development, from the analysis of military conflicts to contemporary applications in economics and other fields.  No special mathematical preparation is required.

best_comment: Definitely definitely definitely take this course! Initially, I found a lot of the course pre–requisites really scary because there's statistics, linear algebra, and multivariable calculus. However, a lot of the course material doesn't require extensive knowledge of these topics. As someone who was very curious how econometrics works from a statistical and theoretical perspective, I found this class very interesting. I had taken EC50 a year prior, so I was familiar with the R implementations for various causal inference observational studies and wanted to understand the math behind them. If you're more so interested in getting very comfortable with applying these techniques in R, then EC1123 would probably be better for you. This class goes in–depth into derivations and mathematical assumptions, which gets really interesting as you progress. Also, the material nicely builds on top of each other, and there are cool topics that the Professor will discuss without them being tested on the final, giving students an opportunity to just enjoy the material. If you are thinking about doing EC1126 vs STAT 111 and EC1123, I'd say that EC1126 does a nice job in providing all the relevant statistical insights that you need for econometrics with good pacing. The course textbook is really good, the slides are very insightful, and the sections have nice R code implementations. The homework is also very close to the lecture material, which contrasts other classes where you might need to go OH to OH to even understand what a problem is stating let alone how to approach it. Lastly, Professor Viviano is amazing and genuinely wants you to succeed. He designs assignments close to the lectures so that the focus is on understanding the core class material. The exams were all very fair, equally weighted, and you were allowed a cheat sheet, so there are definitely opportunities to succeed. TLDR: Take this class :)
worse_comment: One of the worst classes at Harvard. Only take it if you need to.
description: Topics include conditional expectations and its linear approximation; best linear predictors; omitted variable bias; panel data methods and the role of unobserved heterogeneity; instrumental variables and the role of randomization; various approaches to inference on causal relations.
notes: Only one course can count towards EC credit; either Economics 1123 or Economics 1126. Both courses can count towards college credit regardless of the order they are taken.  Students who fulfill the econometrics requirement with Economics 1126 and who intend to pursue Honors should note that the Honors exam assumes knowledge of the material covered in Economics 1123.

course_title_2025: Economics of Climate Change and Environmental Policy 001
best_comment: I’m writing from the undergrad perspective, ESPP concentrator who took EC10A and went to all lectures, sections, and review sessions for this course: For students: I found this class very meaningful, helpful, and thought provoking. Everyone wants to come out of a class feeling the course expanded their thinking, exposed them to new ideas, and that they’ve built skills and knowledge within the course useful elsewhere—I feel this way about the course. I find the afternoon lecture time hard and Professor Stavins lectures in a relatively tranquil / monotone way for most of the time so try and energize yourself before coming to the lecture as it can sometimes be hard to maintain focus — many students did not come to lecture but you should go!! Stavins has many interesting and relevan stories to share form his experiences with the content we discuss and is humorous — lecture really grew on me throughout the semester as the class got to know one another and we got a better background under us for learning more content. Microeconomics background helpful, but do not be concerned if not! You will be expected to do some quantitative problem–solving on exams, so know that it’s not entirely policy / qualitative analysis. If you haven’t looked at the syllabus, be aware this course grades almost solely on the exams so basically all your learning through the semester is graded through two tests. I will say that the exams felt more quantitate / problem solving like in comparison to lecture — I don’t think lecture prepares you for a lot of the thinking required on the exam and you build your exam abilities more through the problem sets and practice exams — lecture is more high level and qualitative. Lectures felt more like a gov class, while exams felt more like a Ec10 exam. Go to office hours with Stavins! He may seem intimidating but he’s happy to talk to you and you should take advantage of the opportunity to learn about his experiences.
course_title_2026: Economics of Climate Change and Environmental Policy
description: Provides a survey, from the perspective of economics, of global climate change and public policies to address it, including international, regional, national, and sub-national policies. The political economy and politics of alternative policies are also covered. Methodological topics that are broadly relevant for other resource and environmental issues are featured.
notes: Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as API-135.

best_comment: I'll preface this by saying that you should probably look at reviews from Spring 2024 rather than Spring 2025 if you're considering this course, as it was taught by a visiting professor (Weiling Liu) this year while Professor Gabaix was out. I think those reviews will be more representative than for this year due to the different professor, but I'll still give my views on the course this semester as most should still be applicable.This course is a very nonintimidating introduction to fundamental financial concepts (stocks, bonds, derivatives) and I think it would be beneficial to everyone, not just econ majors or those considering finance. It delves much deeper than EC 70 (personal finance) into these concepts and would be useful knowledge for everyone, as you will eventually need to decide what assets to invest in with retirement accounts and savings.The class is not terribly theoretical, much less so than the main 1010/1011ab sequences. It's mostly just applying formulas and some basic intuition and is honestly very straightforward, especially if you have a stats background (e.g. Stat 110). You really won't be too surprised by exam questions (though I think they're probably a bit harder under Gabaix than Liu). You're given plenty of practice materials, and since this is such a plug and chug class (applying formulas), the fact that you can use a cheat sheet on the exams means that you really don't have to memorize that much information and should be able to do well on the exams with not that much preparation.The homework assignments are very light and essentially graded for completion. You only have to complete 6 of the 9 to receive a full homework grade, so it's essentially a 6 pset class, which is roughly one every other week if you use all 3 of your drops. Office hours are helpful for psets, but ChatGPT can also help to explain concepts very well since the material isn't that advanced. Using ChatGPT to help on homework assignments actually taught me a lot and helped me gain a better understanding of the concepts since you can ask it to elaborate and relay your points of confusion, so I'd recommend trying that. This class shouldn't take any more than 5 hours a week if you use your resources, though this might pick up again right before the midterm and final. There are also weekly optional sections that can help you review concepts, though ChatGPT did a good enough job of helping reinforce topics to where I didn't need to go to section and I did well on the midterm and final (the curve is quite generous, by the way, though I don't know how it will be under Gabaix).Weiling was a great professor, though she probably won't return next year. I assume Gabaix is just as good, but I'd again recommend reading Spring 2024 reviews if you want the closest parallel. But I would say that any econ major should definitely take this class to fulfill their theory prereq requirement and learn quite useful and applicable information.
worse_comment: I would not really recommend taking this class without prior knowledge. Lecture is very theoretical whereas the problem sets and exams are highly mathematical/problem–solving based, and I don't think that mismatch helps students learn. If you're thinking of taking this course because you want to go into finance, save yourself and your GPA the trouble and take some other class instead (I particularly liked Corporate Finance). You really don't learn much practical knowledge relevant to whatever it is in finance you want to pursue. The professor this year was a substitute so I can't really speak for how this will be run next year, but I gathered that most students didn't really enjoy lecture as they weren't the most engaging/interesting nor were they helpful for completing the problem sets.
description: An introduction to finance. Concepts include time discounting, risk and return, market efficiency, and arbitrage. These concepts are applied to bonds, stocks, and derivatives. We cover financial crises and the role of finance in the economy.

best_comment: There are definitely easier Econ electives out there, but I personally found this class to be very interesting! You learn some of the most foundational models in urban economics (even if they appear very stylized), and just hear about a host of issues facing cities today — as well the successes of cities. Both professors bring a wealth of experience, and really made the lectures very engaging. For grading purposes, you can probably get by just by understanding the models (which the sections really help for) and nothing else, but the interesting content is all in lecture so make sure to go to lecture!
worse_comment: Fascinating class that broadly describes what makes cities great (and sometimes not so great). Not an easy A, but psets don't require too much effort and exams are very manageable if you study the models. GO TO SECTION—lectures are not good at teaching the math!
description: Why are some cities so much more successful than others?  What policies can turn places of poverty into places of opportunity?   In this course, we explore our urban world using the tools of economics.  Topics include firm and household location decisions, land use regulation, housing markets, transportation and entrepreneurship and innovation.   We particularly focus on issues related to high housing costs, poverty, crime,  the transformational role of cities in the developing world, and the future of cities in the age of Zoom and climate change.

best_comment: Loved it!!! Not too much work but is totally what you make of it. This class taught me so much about economics of discontinuous change. Not just prior discontinuous change in history, but the change that is happening all around us. Made me think so much about the world around me and loved the class experience. Was also so fun to do a specialized research study.  Meet and speak with professor freeman as much as you can. He is a great and very knowledgable guy.
description: Explores discontinuous changes and differences in socio-economic outcomes among countries, firms, and people, with attention to the four “apocalyptic” shocks that upended human lives in recent years; the Covid19 pandemic, 2008 implosion of Wall Street, Climate Change embodied in extreme weather events; and wars per Russian invasion of Ukraine; and on the possible role of “fifth horseman” of AI in helping solve these problems vs creating a new danger; and on shocks affecting academic lives: rise of student-employee unionism; student protests; and changes in knowledge and scientific ideas.   Course examines mathematical models, computer simulations, and empirical evidence on growth of social movements such as trade unions, homophily and segregation of groups, power laws in inequality, spread of ideas, where change is driven by positive feedback loops instead of the workings of markets that equilibrate through negative feedbacks.  Models include neural networks, finite automata, evolutionary stable strategies, and agent-based AI simulations.  Lots of attention on how to get evidence on key parameters in these models from big data to case studies to lab experiments  Key requirement is an independent research paper on one of the discontinuous shocks.
notes: Course grades depend largely on independent research project/paper. Professor and TF will provide guidance on topic, help in obtaining data, information from firms, etc. This course meets the concentration writing requirement, if the project is a substantive, solo-authored, original research work (not a literature review). Students should have some mathematical background, but there is no prerequisite.

best_comment: I would highly recommend the first half of the class and I would not recommend the second half of the class. In the first half of the class, I learned a lot of stuff that is very relevant for every economist. In the second half of the class, I learned very little and the material seems mostly irrelevant.
instructors: Shengwu Li, Jerry Green, Eric Maskin
description: Topics include game theory, oligopolistic behavior, asymmetric information, voting and social choice, mechanism design, and applications such as public goods, auctions, matching and contracting.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: Economics 2010A

best_comment: This course is excellent.  Some PhD theory courses have the feel of "more than you can handle, 80% material mastery is good benchmark," but not so with this course.  You really do have a chance to learn everything, and you have the materials and guidance to understand it all.  Bravo to Chris and Sam for an excellently designed and equally well–delivered course on game theory and equilibrium analysis.  The lectures are engaging, sections are also very useful, problem sets are fun, and the supplemental materials (Chris had shared draft textbook chapters that were just fantastic) bring you the rest of the way.  I recommend the course very highly, you will enjoy yourself and find challenges that are approachable, encouraging, and fulfilling to tackle.
worse_comment: Take it! You will learn a lot and become a more critical thinker.
description: A continuation of Economics 2020a. Topics include game theory, economics of information, incentive theory, and welfare economics.
notes: Offered jointly with the Kennedy School as API-112 and with the Business School as 4011.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: Economics 2010a OR Economics 2020a

best_comment: As with many graduate–level courses, I would recommend taking this class only if you have a clear sense of your research interests in economics. That said, if you are at all interested in behavioral economics, this course is a must. You’ll be learning foundational theories from the very people who helped develop them.There are certainly ways the course could be improved, but most of these feel like second–order concerns. What matters more is that the class provides an excellent platform to explore key ideas in behavioral economics and to ask meaningful questions.I highly recommend doing the readings—they are essential for fully understanding the material. I also strongly encourage students to ask questions during class. Both professors are extremely generous with their responses, and I personally learned more from their answers than from the lecture slides themselves.This course is especially valuable for students who want to build a strong foundation in behavioral modeling, and who are comfortable with microeconomic theory at the level of a solid undergraduate course.
worse_comment: Do not take a course with Matthew Rabin. I cannot emphasize that enough. He is a wonderful person and a great economist, but a bad teacher in every way. He rambles in lecture and does not explain most things clearly. His problem sets are badly designed, take too long, and have not much pedagogical value — they are often quite disjoint from lecture.David Laibson is amazing — I took this course hoping to learn behavioral economics from him, and it turned out that he was forced to give 2/3 of the course to Matthew so that Matthew could satisfy a teaching requirement. Three hour lectures of Matthew Rabin are very hard to sit through.IN SUMMARY: This is the only class at Harvard that I regret taking.
description: Studies the way that economic and psychological factors jointly influence behavior. Analyzes how to integrate insights from the choices people make in the lab and the field into economic theory, applications, and empirical work. Enriches the standard economic model by improved understanding of people's goals and tastes, as well as incorporating limits to rationality such as limited attention and memory, errors in statistical reasoning and social inference, shortcomings in self-regulation, and misprediction of utility. The course is intended for doctoral students interested in research in economics and related fields; we also strongly encourage undergraduates with appropriate preparation.
notes: Primarily for graduate students but open to undergraduates.

best_comment: This course is fantastic—I think it's the best course I've taken at Harvard. I think you should take this course if you're interested in exploring a discipline where the distance between mathematics and the world is small: i.e., if you're interested in questions about strategy, behavior, or the world, but find yourself interested in math, this is exactly the right course.I came into this course with significant mathematical background, but little economics background (only 1011a). It was approachable for me, but I was also very excited about the material, and I found myself thinking about the ideas all the time. If you're an undergraduate with some good math background (i.e. you've taken some upper level math courses), then this course will likely be accessible to you. For reference, I found the problem sets in this course harder than the problem sets than the ones in upper level undergraduate math courses (i.e. they are not relatively routine exercises), and closer on par to the graduate ones. It is really inspiring stuff, and Shengwu is a great expositor of the material, as well as a lovely person to talk to about all things economics.
description: This is a course about game theory and mechanism design. The first half covers key concepts and techniques, and the second half surveys advanced topics near the research frontier. This course is taught assuming familiarity with first-year PhD-level microeconomic theory, of the kind taught in ECON2010A and ECON2010B.
course_requirements: Prerequisite:  Economics 2010a

best_comment: As with many graduate–level courses, I would recommend this class to students who already have a clear sense of their research interests in economics. This course will be especially valuable for those interested in economic theory and formal modeling, or for those studying relationships—formal or informal—that involve issues like moral hazard, adverse selection, or contractual incompleteness.The course offers an excellent overview of core models in contract theory, and Oliver Hart is an outstanding lecturer. The lectures are delivered using chalk and board, which I found particularly effective—it allows students to follow the material step by step and helps the pace stay clear and thoughtful.I strongly recommend keeping up with the readings, as they are important for fully understanding the material. That said, the course can sometimes give the impression that the theory of contracts is largely settled. Personally, I don’t believe that’s the case. To get a better sense of current research, I’d suggest supplementing the course with some additional reading on recent work in the field.
description: Recent developments in contract theory. Includes hidden action and hidden information models, dynamic agency issues, incomplete contracts, and applications of contract theory to financial contracting, firm boundaries, public ownership, and firm objectives.

best_comment: A useful addition to your econometric toolbox, grounded in classic causal inference methods, with some exposure to frontier developments.  Not too stressful if you've taken any econometrics in the past.  More focused on application than theory.  I say this positively — and don't worry, theoretical motivation is still provided and you will run through some of the standard potential–outcomes derivations.  A useful opportunity to code a bit and think through the many assumptions incumbent with various approaches to inference.  You'll walk away with a better understanding of the bread–and–butter of economic analysis!
description: Economics 2110 and 2115 comprise a two-course sequence for first-year graduate students seeking training in econometric methods at a level that prepares them to conduct professional empirical research. Economics 2115 (spring) covers topics (different methods) in current empirical research. Faculty members from across the university will teach modules each covering a different method of causal inference, including but not limited to instrumental variables, panel data methods, and regression discontinuity and kink designs. The course will emphasize a mixture of theory and application, with problem sets focused on the replication or extension of recent papers utilizing these methods.
notes: This course is designed for PhD candidates in health policy, public policy, education policy, the Business School DBA program. Qualified undergraduates are also permitted to take the course with permission of the instructor.

best_comment: If you are required to take it, then that's that—but there are reasons to take the course even if it isn't strictly required!  It's a great opportunity to broaden your analytical and econometric horizons.  The scope of the course and variety of estimation/analytical techniques are very ambitious.  Keep a realistic mindset about what you want to take away from the course and you will be fine.
description: This course continues the first year sequence in econometrics and covers a variety of topics and ideas that are important for pursuing and interpreting empirical research in economics. The first half of the course covers core econometric approaches that are important for a wide range of applications, including identification analysis, asymptotic approximations, large sample theory for estimation and hypothesis testing, and the bootstrap.  The second part of the course examines a range of complementary topics and new developments, including reasons why canonical econometric methods may be unreliable (such as model misspecification, identification failure, and the incidental parameters problem) and extensions of and alternatives to the traditional econometric paradigm (such as partial identification, Bayesian inference, nonparametrics, and machine learning).  Economic applications will be discussed throughout. Enrollment limited.

best_comment: This class was a bit more focused on research in econometrics than I originally thought, which was initially a bit jarring as a primarily applied person. That said, Davide is a fantastic teacher and the topics covered are really interesting and feel relevant. I am really glad that I took the class, and I feel that I learned a ton that I will take with me to future problems.
description: The course covers topics in econometrics, with focus on micro-econometrics and causal inference
notes: Prerequisites are ECON2120 and ECON2140 or equivalent courses in statistics or CS (under permission of the instructor).
course_requirements: ECON 2120 and ECON 2140 or equivalent courses in statistics or CS (under permission of the instructor)

course_title_2025: Public Economics and Fiscal Policy II 001
best_comment: Worth taking to get a good understanding of optimal tax theory and seminal topics in public.
course_title_2026: Public Economics and Fiscal Policy II
description: The course covers core applied topics related to the design of public policies. It is the second course offered in the Public Economics sequence, following Econ 2450A (although taking Econ 2450A is not required in advance of this class).  The first half of the semester (taught by Raj Chetty) will cover partial equilibrium empirical methods to measure tax incidence and efficiency, behavioral welfare analysis, corporate taxation, and economic mobility.  The second half of the semester (taught by Rebecca Diamond) will focus on urban economics and local public economics, including spatial equilibrium, public goods/non-market amenities, and housing, place-based, andland-use policy. Modeling and empirical methods will be taughtconcurrently in both parts of the course.
notes: Students are encouraged to take Economics 2450a before taking 2450b. In addition to the requirements above, you are strongly encouraged to review i) labor supply concepts (Hicksian elasticity, Marshallian elasticity, income effects); ii) “dynamic programming” and “optimal control methods”; iii) constrained optimization and the envelope theorem.
course_requirements: Prerequisite:  (Economics 2010a AND Economics 2010b) OR (Economics 2020a AND Economics 2020b)

course_title_2025: Public Economics and Fiscal Policy II 001
best_comment: Worth taking to get a good understanding of optimal tax theory and seminal topics in public.

best_comment: Before taking this class, I had always thought of health economics as a primarily empirical field, focused on applying microeconometric tools to health–related questions. This course completely changed that impression. It offers a rigorous, theory–driven framework that helped me see health economics as a coherent and scientific discipline. I was constantly challenged and inspired by the material. I often stayed after class to ask questions, and the conversations—whether in person or over email—with Professor Cutler were incredibly helpful. Listening to other students—many of whom are PhD candidates—debate and dissect the material during lectures was also one of the most intellectually stimulating aspects of the course. Professor Cutler is not only a world–class economist but also a generous and thoughtful teacher who truly cares about student learning. Even as an undergraduate, I felt welcomed in this PhD–level class. If you’re willing to put in the effort, this course will not only expand your academic toolkit but also fundamentally change how you think about economics. I couldn’t recommend it more.
description: This course surveys topics in health economics. It touches on public sector issues, the industrial organization of health care markets, interactions between health and labor markets, and health in developing countries. Theory and empirical work are presented.
notes: A graduate level microeconomics class at the level of Economics 2010 or 2020 is required for enrollment.  Students unsure about the adequacy of their background should contact the instructor.

best_comment: Read the annual review paper and the JPE paper words by words and you will find the material easier. It takes a relatively large fixed cost, but don't be afraid of investing in this fixed cost!
description: Financial aspects of growth and income determination in open economies. Topics include international business cycle, monetary and exchange rate regimes, capital flows, and current issues in international macroeconomic policy.

best_comment: This is a great class, and I learned a lot about dynamic structural models. Myrto is a fantastic teacher, and the content, while difficult, is quite interesting.
description: A continuation of the graduate sequence in industrial organization, with an emphasis on the applied analysis of dynamic environments (including single agent optimization problems and the specification, estimation, and computation of dynamic games). Additional topics may include network industries, spatial equilibrium models, transportation markets, and others depending on interest. Note: topics require an understanding of materials covered in Economics 2610.

course_title_2025: Theoretical and Empirical Perspectives on Entrepreneurship and Innovation 001
best_comment: If you are at all interested in the academic side of entrepreneurship, take this course! Would especially recommend if you are a junior who is thinking about a senior thesis.
worse_comment: I'm an entrepreneur and student founder and this class was horribly run and a part of my week that I actively dreaded. The reading is interesting but lectures are dull and the TFs do not care about you. Sure, the work load is not too crazy but it's not worth sacrificing one of your classes at Harvard with this one.
course_title_2026: Theoretical and Empirical Perspectives on Entrepreneurship and Innovation
description: TEPEI explores scholarly work from economics and finance disciplines regarding entrepreneurship—the formation and growth of new firms—and its implications for innovation and growth. While work on this topic dates back to Schumpeter and even earlier, academic research regarding entrepreneurship has exploded over the last decade. The nine-week “core” component will the connections between economic theory—particularly in contract theory, organizational economics, and corporate finance--and empirical work. Among the topics that will be covered are the rationale for entrepreneurial firms, the structure of arrangements between entrepreneurs and investors, the relationship with larger entities, entrepreneurial strategy, the development of new ideas and its relationship to organizational form, and the decision to go public. We will also seek to understand key data sets for research . At the same time, these are dynamic fields, with new topics attracting academic (and real world) interest. Reflecting this dynamism, the nine core weeks will be followed by four weeks of special topics that will vary from year-to-year.
notes: Offered jointly with the Business School as 4350.

course_title_2025: Theoretical and Empirical Perspectives on Entrepreneurship and Innovation 001

best_comment: A great class for seeing how econometrics is actually used in research. The methods covered are modern and framed in the context of real–world applications, especially financial research. The course emphasizes when and why to use different tools, highlighting how messy applied work can be.That said, much of the content builds on graduate–level econometrics, so to get the most out of the class, you'll want at least a strong undergraduate metrics background. The assignments are not designed to teach the techniques from scratch. Rather, you're expected to apply them in open–ended, research–like settings: tasks like reproducing tables from papers using public datasets and libraries, writing referee reports, and completing a final paper or presentation.Even if your grad–level econometrics is rusty, the structure of the course still allows you to engage and succeed. Even if half the lectures are over your head, you'll still learn a lot and be able to complete the assignments.The workload was reasonable overall, but Assignment 3 (constructing equity factors using WRDS) was challenging, requiring a WRDS account and working with SAS code. Overall, the TA and professors were responsive and helpful, so definitely reach out if you get stuck or if the instructions aren't clear.
description: Examines empirical research in corporate finance. Covers empirical research methodology, financial institutions, and financial policy. Major emphasis is on how to do well-executed and persuasive research in corporate finance.
notes: Structured to minimize overlap with Economics 2725. Seminar format; students write referee reports and a research paper. Offered jointly with the Business School as 4220.

course_title_2025: Labor Economics and Labor Market Institutions 001
best_comment: You truly get out what you put into this course. There's much to cover and certainly not enough time to cover it all in great detail, so it will be on you to follow through with outside reading and other exploration if you're interested in learning more. That said, it's worthwhile to do, and a great course overall!
course_title_2026: Labor Economics and Labor Market Institutions
description: Examines the operation of the labor market and policies that affect labor market outcomes. Topics: static and dynamic labor supply, job search, firms and inequality, self-selection, discrimination, personnel, and education.

course_title_2025: Early Stage Research and Discussions on the Economics of Health Equity 001
best_comment: This reading group is very fun and positive! Interesting to speak to an interdisciplinary group from across the university.
course_title_2026: Early Stage Research and Discussions on the Economics of Health Equity
description: This is a reading group for students to discuss recent advances in the economics of health equity. Topics will include equity in all dimensions: race/ethnicity; gender orientation; disability status; and others. Students will read papers, present, and discuss them. Interested students should talk to Professor Alsan or Professor Cutler.

course_title_2025: Early Stage Research and Discussions on the Economics of Health Equity 001
best_comment: This reading group is very fun and positive! Interesting to speak to an interdisciplinary group from across the university.

Interested students should talk to Professor Alsan or Professor Cutler.

course_title_2025: Graduate Student Workshop in Labor Economics 001
course_title_2026: Graduate Student Workshop in Labor Economics
instructors: Lawrence Katz, Edward Glaeser, Claudia Goldin
description: Participants discuss recent research in labor economics and present their own work in progress.

course_title_2025: Graduate Student Workshop in Labor Economics 001
course_title_2026: Graduate Student Workshop in Labor Economics
instructors: Lawrence Katz, Edward Glaeser, Claudia Goldin

course_title_2025: Graduate Student Workshop in Labor Economics 001
course_title_2026: Graduate Student Workshop in Labor Economics

course_title_2025: Educational Outcomes in Cross-National and Cross-Cultural Perspectives 001
best_comment: It's a great class! It's chill but really fulfilling and sparks interesting conversations. The TFs and professor are also really cool to learn from. It is a flipped classroom though so you may need to go out of your way to hear your TFs or professors' views on certain topics. Overall, it's a fun class though!
worse_comment: Please do not enroll in this course if you are not interested in education at all. It was disappointing that some students were clearly only interested in this course because it was "easy" and it brought down the quality of discussion.
course_title_2026: Educational Outcomes in Cross-National and Cross-Cultural Perspectives
description: A great deal of thinking about the relationship between psychology and education asks what psychology can contribute to the improvement of education. For example, can psychology help to improve the way that we teach reading? Can it help to close the gap in achievement between particular groups? Do preschoolers have ideas or dispositions that help--or hinder--their progress in school? However, one can also ask about the effects of education on psychological processes. There is enormous cross-national and cross-cultural variation in the length and type of education that children receive. A major goal of this course is to help students understand the effects of such variation on the ways that people think--and feel. A secondary goal is to alert students to the ways in which those effects can be measured and to underline the contribution that different methods--experiments, large-scale surveys, and participant observation--can make to our understanding of such effects. The final goal is to underline how educational provision and its impact vary dramatically across the globe.Learning Goals:There is enormous variation in the length and type of education that children receive. A major goal of this course is to help you think about and understand the effects of such variation on the way that children end up thinking - and the values they hold. A secondary goal is to alert you to the ways in which those effects can be measured and to underline the contribution that different methods - small-scale experiments, large surveys, qualitative and observational studies - can make to our understanding of such effects. The final goal is to underline how far educational provision and its impact have varied in the course of history and currently vary across the globe.Career Focus:This course is co-listed at HGSE and The Harvard Chan School of Public Health. It is designed for masters and doctoral level students from across the University who are interested in the design, testing, and implementation of innovative, science-based strategies to promote the healthy development of young children facing adversity. Aspiring innovators and change agents with an interest in early childhood policy and practice are especially welcome.

course_title_2025: Children with Learning and Developmental Differences 001
best_comment: This class is good! It's kind of an awkward size (not lecture, not seminar), which makes participating kind of challenging. You get to do some fun activities in class (IEP simulations), the assignments are really cool, open–ended, and manageable, and Professor Gaab is really awesome!
course_title_2026: Children with Learning and Developmental Differences
description: The duration of education is a strong predictor of health and longevity, but approximately 1 in 5 children with learning or attention issues have long-lasting negative consequences related to their academic, social, mental health, vocational, economic outcomes. In the US, over 2 million students struggle with specific learning disabilities (SLD), which represents roughly 35% of all students who receive special education services under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. Children with a learning disability are less likely to complete high school or enroll in postsecondary educational programs and have a heightened risk for developing mental health problems such as depression or anxiety. Currently, SLDs are primarily identified and addressed within the education system; however, these students also receive care and support outside of school and are members of various community settings. A streamlined approach that informs the coordination of general education, special education, clinical psychology, policymaking, advocacy, caregivers, and health professionals (e.g., pediatricians, speech-and language pathologists) is often absent and hinders the design of preventive approaches, identification strategies, and service implementation. It further leads to a siloed approach for care and policymaking, lack of community supports.The course will provide a broad overview of learning disabilities and differences, including dyslexia, dyscalculia, attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, developmental language disorder, and autism spectrum disorder, as well as the relevant policies and educational documentation for these learners. It will then cover the professional stakeholders that should be involved in an evidence-based response to a learning difference, and identify their unique knowledge base, toolset, developmental timeline, and communication strategies, both in the educational/professional environment and the community. Finally, we will focus on barriers and challenges faced by children with learning differences in the academic, professional, and community settings. Throughout the course, students will be provided with both research/evidence-based content and case-based learning opportunities, practical examples, and guest speakers drawn from the community. Class activities will include both synchronous and asynchronous learning activities led by the Instructor (Prof. Nadine Gaab), along with breakout sessions overseen by the instructor and/or Teaching Fellows.This course is divided into thirds and will cover: (1) a broad overview of learning disabilities, educational policies, and service documentation; (2) stakeholders in academic and professional settings, including their unique knowledge base, toolset, developmental timeline, and communication strategies, barriers faced by children with learning differences in these settings, existing solutions to these barriers; and (3) stakeholders in community settings, barriers faced by individuals with learners in these settings, existing solutions to these challenges.

course_title_2025: Education in the East and West 001
best_comment: Very easy course that can also be very personally fulfilling. Class is long, but they try ot make it engaging. Assignments are easy and also pretty fun if you are genuinely interested in the topic. I think personal interest in the subject of education is really important for how much you enjoy and get out of this class. I had very strong personal reasons for being interesting in the subject, which I had many opportunities to explore through class assignments – that is a really valuable and hard to find opportunity!!The class definitely has an objective in mind, which is to make you more culturally sensitive. I think that's important, but if you aren't interested in learning about that, this class will be annoying to you.
course_title_2026: Education Across Cultures: Beliefs and Practices in Schools and Families
description: Education is a universal human activity, but how it is understood and practiced vary widely across cultures. When immersed in our own upbringing and educational experiences, we can easily take our beliefs and practices for granted, while overlooking cross-cultural variation and making inaccurate generalization about people from different backgrounds. That is why it is important to take a cross-cultural approach in the study of education. It not only helps us understand the diversity and universalities in educational practices around the world, but also invites us to see our own experiences in a new light and reflect on how our beliefs about learning, teaching, and parenting have been shaped by our cultural backgrounds. In this course, we will examine the interplay between education and culture, focusing on beliefs and practices in schools and families across various cultures. Specifically, we will investigate how cultural values and assumptions shape parent-child interactions, teacher-student dynamics, teaching and learning approaches, and educational systems. We will also consider how these factors impact child development, student well-being and academic achievement, and the experiences of immigrant and international students.

course_title_2025: Humanity and its Futures: AI and Human Cognition 001
best_comment: This class is super interesting! It is more philosophical than technical, but still super interesting! Homeworks are group conversations on readings and one group presentation a semester! Workload is manageable and material is super interesting!
course_title_2026: Humanity and its Futures: AI and Human Cognition
description: This course provides students with an understanding of the complexities surrounding today’s most intractable problems and helps them develop methodologies for navigating the challenges they will face. After introducing systems thinking, with a focus on interconnections and feedback loops, the course will address a significant interdisciplinary issue: Artificial Intelligence (AI) and its relationship to human cognition.The study of AI and human cognition is both timely and dynamic. This expansive domain integrates computer science, statistics, big data, cognitive science, psychology, and philosophy. As a transformative technology, AI has achieved remarkable success in understanding natural language and emulating human reasoning, making it invaluable in augmenting human cognition.Despite these advances, many questions remain about the nature of AI and its relationship with human thought. This course invites participants to explore these questions through an intellectual journey. Students will engage in discussions on systems and paradigms, the essence of intelligence, computational approaches, mind and machine metaphors, cognitive biases in AI, and the role of AI in creativity and intuition.The course emphasizes collaborative learning, with students working in teams to learn from each other, as well as from lectures and selected literature. Each lecture will be paired with research papers and books, followed by a discussion session.The topics covered in the course are listed in the syllabus. Each will include an overview of the issue and its significance. Students will apply systems thinking and a multidisciplinary approach to analyze and critique each topic. By the end of the course, students will have developed a strong framework for multidisciplinary discussions, gained a deep understanding of AI’s power, limitations, and risks, and explored its technical building blocks through hands-on exercises. Additionally, students will experience the value of collaboration and the importance of diversity while working in diverse teams.
notes: ES 26 is also offered as ES 294 (for graduate students). Students may not take both for credit.

best_comment: This class was an absolute trip, but the good outweighs the bad for the right type of person. I took this class as a prospective EE concentrator to test my interest in the different areas of EE. The class is split into two halves. Before spring break, we learned about analog circuits (taught by Gu) and after spring break, we did digital circuits and logic (taught by Reddi). The course content is very overwhelming in its pace and without a section (which would have been life changing) it is very easy to fall behind. Fortunately, Gu and Reddi are extremely accessible and helpful in office hours and answered all of my questions, even basic ones, without making me feel stupid or incapable. Get to know them if you can because they are so knowledgeable and willing to help or just chat! My experience in office hours affirmed my decision to concentrate in EE because once so many challenging concepts made sense to me, I realized that I loved learning about EE (particularly the digital side) more than anything else I have ever learned and I found the challenge very satisfying to work through. PSETs are long (as in 20+ pages) so you MUST start early.Things that could be improved:–From my understanding, the professor that normally teaches ES50 was on sabbatical so a lot of the course structure was very unorganized or changed at the last minute.–They promised us 3 weeks to work on our final projects, but we only got 2. Many, many hours were spent in the SEC getting it to work on a very rushed schedule.–I have never been mansplained to and talked down to so much in my life. It got to the point where I dreaded labs where I should have been looking forward to learning hands–on skills. If you are a woman taking this class and something bothers you, fix it right away. My biggest regret is not saying something as soon as it bothered me early in the semester. It would have been nice if resources about this were highlighted because I was not the only person with this experience.–I did ES50 without an extensive technical background or direct hands–on experience. My lab partner had already taken circuits classes and had had the opportunity to do many hands–on projects before ES50. Due to this mismatch and him wanting to do the labs as quickly as possible, I did not get as much out of the labs as I wanted to. Do not be afraid to switch lab partners. Best resources:–Mega OH on Wednesday nights–Gu and Reddi themselves (But Reddi will be the only one teaching ES50 next year)–Upperclassmen–Langa and Roderick’s OH (both graduating unfortunately)
worse_comment: I would not recommend this course as a first glimpse into EE, purely due to the teaching style and structure. Gu’s lectures were slow and inefficient—he often spent two full classes explaining what could’ve been covered in half a lecture. This left us consistently behind, making it difficult to keep up with labs. VJ was the opposite: fast–paced and concise, but sometimes too much so. He’d call something “very important” and then move on after five minutes, leaving no room for questions or deeper understanding.Exams were stressful with the new shorter time limit. The previous 6–hour format allowed for more careful work; bringing it back would reduce unnecessary pressure. Labs were hit–or–miss—partner work often meant one person dominated, making it hard to learn independently.PSETs were thorough and aligned well with exam material, but the workload was intense—20 pages in a single week is tough.The final project was a rushed endeavor and hard to power through when previous weeks were filled with PSETting and midterm studying – the midterm really put our group behind. Overall, it's the TFs who really made the course tolerable. It's a horrible course, but seek guidance from TFs who really want to help you.
description: The main course objectives are to introduce students to the exciting and powerful world of electrical engineering and to explain how gadgets that we use every day actually work. After taking ES 50, you will be able to leverage the power of electricity to build systems that sense, control and program the physical world around you. Examples include intelligent and autonomous systems (robots), audio amplifiers (e.g. guitar amp), interactive art installations, light-shows, mind-controlled machines, and so on.

best_comment: I know everyone will say that this course heavily depends on your teammates, and it is true. If you have teammates that contribute and put in some amount of work, it makes life 50x easier. I will say my year was particularly amazing because of how all the students in the class trauma bonded. I don't know if its always like that, but it would make sense if it did. I made some new friendships from this class, and made some amazing memories. I am a mathematics and electrical engineering major, but I believe this is still a useful class, as it helps you get 1. hands on experience, and 2. understand the steps that go into producing something like a robot. This is a skill I will continue to develop and definitely use in the future. The TAs are amazing(Taylor you are amazing the best Lab TA ever), they will help you with every pset, and lab work, they are very understanding. The professor is pretty good, very passionate when you get to talk to him about other things besides ES51, and is also just an amazing grader. The tests are a lot better with him grading them. You will need to lock in a little bit sometimes, especially towards the latter half of the course, but if you spend 5 to 8 hours per week on this course, it should be fine.
worse_comment: I think it is important for the student to understand that this class is very doable and you can perform well in it but there will be periods of time in which the class picks up and gives you an extreme amount of work which will be stressful.
description: An introductory course in the design, fabrication, and assembly of mechanical and electromechanical devices. Topics include: Engineering graphics and tolerances; Structural design and material selection; Machine elements and two-dimensional mechanisms; DC motors; Design methodology. Emphasis on hands-on work and team design projects using professional solid modeling CAD software and numerically controlled machine tools.
notes: Intended for first-years and sophomores.

course_title_2025: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project 001
best_comment: This course provides a good opportunity to apply the concepts learned in engineering courses, solve a real world problem, and collaborate with other engineers. Make sure to work together and stick to a well–defined timeline to ensure that the project is completed to a high level and in a timely manner.
course_title_2026: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project
description: Semester-long team-based project providing experience working with clients on complex multi-stakeholders real problems. Course provides exposure to problem definition, problem framing, qualitative and quantitative research methods, modeling, generation and co-design of creative solutions, engineering design trade-offs, and documentation/communication skills. Ordinarily taken in the junior year.
notes: Preference given to SB candidates.

course_title_2025: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project 002
best_comment: Overall, this course was deeply unsatisfactory. The teaching staff were highly disorganized—assignment deadlines were often announced the night before, and we weren’t informed about a major 100–page report until less than two weeks before it was due. It often felt like the instructors forgot we had other classes and commitments, expecting ES96 to take up our entire week.That said, I did appreciate that our section was at least able to accomplish something meaningful. I’ve heard from peers in other groups that they would sit in the SEC for hours with no direction or progress. Our industry client’s frequent visits and helpful feedback were a definite highlight and made the experience somewhat worthwhile.Still, ES96 has a well–known reputation in the department for being chaotic, and this iteration only reinforced that. The lack of structure and clear communication pushed a disproportionate amount of responsibility onto a few highly involved students, which was unsustainable and exhausting.This course desperately needs a clearer curriculum, better planning, and more respect for students' time and bandwidth.
worse_comment: Here is what I wish the teaching staff said on day 1: "Sometimes as an engineer, you are presented with a specific problem and must design a solution. That is the exercise of ES 100. Other times, however, the question is just 'how do we make more money as a company?' That latter question is more difficult in that you need to first find a problem that exists in the world or a hole in the market that you think you can fill. That is essence of ES 96: can you develop a product by first finding a question and then developing solutions. There are three phases to this process: research, making a problem statement, and prototyping a solution. But these phases are not one after the other. Instead, you will spend the first month of the class just researching problems in this specific industry. Then for the two weeks after that you will start writing problem statements AND doing research as you are developing your research. Then the last 6 weeks of the class will involve prototyping AND modifying your problem statement AND doing research. You develop a problem statement but realize it is not supported by research in which you have to modify the problem statement. You may develop a solution that works, doesn't address your problem statement, but could address another problem. So by the end you are bouncing between all three of these phases: research, problem statement, prototyping."

Our industry client’s frequent visits and helpful feedback were a definite highlight and made the experience somewhat worthwhile.Still, ES96 has a well–known reputation in the department for being chaotic, and this iteration only reinforced that. The lack of structure and clear communication pushed a disproportionate amount of responsibility onto a few highly involved students, which was unsustainable and exhausting.This course desperately needs a clearer curriculum, better planning, and more respect for students' time and bandwidth.
worse_comment: Here is what I wish the teaching staff said on day 1: "Sometimes as an engineer, you are presented with a specific problem and must design a solution. That is the exercise of ES 100. Other times, however, the question is just 'how do we make more money as a company?' That latter question is more difficult in that you need to first find a problem that exists in the world or a hole in the market that you think you can fill. That is essence of ES 96: can you develop a product by first finding a question and then developing solutions. There are three phases to this process: research, making a problem statement, and prototyping a solution. But these phases are not one after the other. Instead, you will spend the first month of the class just researching problems in this specific industry. Then for the two weeks after that you will start writing problem statements AND doing research as you are developing your research. Then the last 6 weeks of the class will involve prototyping AND modifying your problem statement AND doing research. You develop a problem statement but realize it is not supported by research in which you have to modify the problem statement. You may develop a solution that works, doesn't address your problem statement, but could address another problem. So by the end you are bouncing between all three of these phases: research, problem statement, prototyping."
course_title_2026: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project
description: Semester-long team-based project providing experience working with clients on complex multi-stakeholders real problems. Course provides exposure to problem definition, problem framing, qualitative and quantitative research methods, modeling, generation and co-design of creative solutions, engineering design trade-offs, and documentation/communication skills. Ordinarily taken in the junior year.
notes: Preference given to SB candidates.

best_comment: You should thesis. All engineers should thesis. I learned SO much about the engineering design process and anyone who studies engineering can do a great job at their thesis if they put the time into it. Chose a topic that you are passionate about and chose an advisor that is encouraging, preferably someone you have done research with. Don't shy away from new topics and softwares, but you have to be willing to put the work in. It's pretty incredible watching your friends reach their dreams as they develop their projects and realizing that you are doing the same for yourself. VERY cool opportunity to work alongside incredibly impressive Harvard staff.
worse_comment: Your thesis advisor matters a LOT. But if you're already at this point for the second semester of ES100, just make sure that you get as much done before spring break as possible to make your post–break experience a lot less miserable.
description: Individual engineering design projects which demonstrate mastery of engineering knowledge and techniques. Each student will pursue an appropriate capstone project which involves both engineering design and quantitative analysis. This culminates in a final oral presentation and final report/thesis. Students must complete both parts of this course, fall and spring, in order to receive credit.
notes: Ordinarily taken in the senior year. Students are expected to have an approved project submitted to the course by the Limited Enrollment Course Petitions deadline in the spring semester preceding actual enrollment. Formal project approval rests with the project advisor and the ES100 teaching staff. The course includes weekly required lectures (fall only) and weekly section (fall and spring).
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: ENG-SCI 100HFA
