course_requirements: Pre-requisite: ENG-SCI 100HFA

best_comment: Great thermodynamics course that can be applied across most disciplines. Thermodynamics is often perceived as a difficult topic to comprehend, but I definitely think that Scot made it seem endurable and easier to understand.  Some concepts felt a little blurry, especially when you're looking at diagrams.  However, the books and lectures are mostly helpful. Section and office hours are definitely a key component of the course because that is where most of the application occurs. Also, be prepared to present every 2–3 weeks in this course. Most presentations are around 3 minutes and not too difficult if you put in the effort to learn the topic you want to discuss. Scot also likes to use cold–calling to induce classroom engagement.  I personally learn better in smaller sections/courses so definitely take this course if you need or are interested in thermo.
description: Fundamental concepts, formalisms, and examples of conservation of energy and change in entropy as applied to energy, environmental, and biological systems.
notes: ES 112 is also offered as EPS 112. Students may not take both for credit. Undergraduate engineering students should enroll in ES 112. Total class capacity of 18 includes students in both ES 112 and EPS 112. Please see course page for lottery instructions.

best_comment: Take this course! Great way to satisfy your honors requirement, and Prof. Kuang is so amazing: he gives reassuring Dad in the best way possible! Do note that there are quite a few assignments – more so than I had anticipated, but they're all easily done with a good group (would recommend taking the class with at least 2–3 other people you know you'd work well together) and some of them are optional / count for extra credit. There are 3 major projects, two of which are group–based (with the same group) and the last is individual. In the moment, they were a little stressful, but it's actually really fun to create these modeling projects and take ownership over a small research study that you apply the concepts learned in class to. I definitely spent a reasonable amount of time on this class each week (around 7 hours, more or less depending on the week), especially for an APMTH class.
description: Abstracting the essential components and mechanisms from a natural system to produce a mathematical model, which can be analyzed with a variety of formal mathematical methods, is perhaps the most important, but least understood, task in applied mathematics. This course approaches a number of problems without the prejudice of trying to apply a particular method of solution. Topics drawn from biology, economics, engineering, physical and social sciences.
notes: Engineering Sciences 115 is also offered as Applied Mathematics 115. Students may not take both for credit. Undergraduate Engineering Students should enroll in Engineering Sciences 115.

course_title_2025: Introduction to the Mechanics of Solids 001
best_comment: This was an interesting and enjoyable class, I thought the lectures were comprehensive and understandable –– Dr. Coughlin usually derives the equations during them, but he also makes sure to do quite a few examples to show how all of the concepts are applied. The problem sets were also doable and fair; they aligned well with what was taught in class, and they were a good amount of challenging without being too frustrating. I do wish that there was some more discussion about the relationships between different concepts and how to utilize them to inform them when designing (and not to just do calculations on a given design), so that we have more of an idea of how we would apply these in the future. The exams were also fair, and they were similar to the format of the homework questions, so it was not too stressful studying for the exams, although the two midterms were a time crunch.I liked the bridge competition at the end of the semester, but it would have been nice to get more guidance on how we can make sure that we're optimizing the strength–to–weight ratio and design tricks/lessons for it. I also wish the labs were more hands–on, usually, we just watched the experiment being done and then just recorded the data. Also, the lab reports were sometimes tedious to do, but there are only two of them for the semester, so it's not too big of a deal. Overall though, ES 120 will teach you a lot, and the content will teach you a lot. Hopefully, Dr. Coughlin keeps teaching this course because he does a great job, and it's also clear that he cares about the students and wants to make sure that we understand the content.
worse_comment: Combination of office hours and textbook are absolutely necessary to completely the psets. The exams are fair but lectures are incredible unengaging and difficult to follow because Mark will oftentimes go through a problem, realize he made a mistake be really shaky about it. Only 3 office hours per week so make sure to plan your time accordingly.
course_title_2026: Introduction to the Mechanics of Solids
description: A first course in the mechanical sciences that introduces elements of continuum mechanics and explains how materials and structures stretch, bend, twist, shake, buckle, and break. Definitions of stress and strain. Strain-displacement relations. Stress-strain behavior of materials. Torsion, beam theory with applications to beam deflections, buckling, and energy methods. Statically determinate and indeterminate structures. Three laboratory sessions required. Strong emphasis on analytical skills and mathematics.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: Math 21a or Applied Math 21a (or equivalent); AND Physical Sciences 12a, Physics 15a, or Applied Physics 50a;  AND Co-requisite: Math 21b or Applied Math 21b (or equivalent)

course_title_2025: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics and Transport Processes 001
best_comment: This is a solid class. The professor is great and super good at explaining things. The problem sets are fair and there are plenty of TFs to help out. Also, something I really appreciated about this class is that the exams are manageable after reviewing the HW and provided practice exams. The computational fluid dynamics labs with COMSOL were also super fun. I really liked how this class goes over examples spanning everything from aerospace and jet propulsion to fluid dynamics in the human body. However, it is fluid mechanics so it can get pretty math heavy especially when you start solving Navier–Stokes in non–cartesian coordinate systems. Overall, this is one of the most well taught engineering classes here along with ES125.
worse_comment: Read the textbook chapter before lecture. It will help you understand what happens in lecture. Attend lecture. The examples covered in lecture are very helpful for problem sets and exams.  Start problem sets early, on your own, then go to office hours when you get stuck. Wrap up the problem sets on your own, rather than just writing down what you're told at office hours and submitting. In this way you will get a better grasp of the material, which can be confusing until you work through enough problems, setting them up by yourself.
course_title_2026: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics and Transport Processes
description: Atomistic-Mesoscale-Continuum Fluids and Flows; Dimensional Analysis; Diffusion and Heat Transfer Processes; Fluid kinematics; Eulerian and Lagrangian descriptions of Flows; Mass conservation and potential flows; Momentum conservation and the Navier-Stokes equations; Vorticity and Vortices; Lift and Drag in Aerodynamics; Flows in Pipes and Channels; Elementary concepts of Turbulent flows.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: (Applied Math 21a or Math 21a or equivalent) AND (Applied Math 21b or Math 21b or equivalent) AND (APPHY 50a or PHYSCI 12a or Physics 15a)

best_comment: This class is great, but you do have to put in consistent effort. Flavio is amazing and very supportive, but be sure that you go through all of the lecture notes and content to gain a conceptual understanding of the ideas. I think this is a great class and you will learn a lot! The grading scheme is also decently generous, with an optional final project that can boost your grade significantly. In terms of some cons, the teaching staff was not as robust as it could have been. Only having 2 TFs with limited time made it difficult to gain feedback on assignments in a fast manner and get the necessary help to learn. Definitely would have learned better having more staff and office hours. It was also difficult to study for exams without solutions to the practice exams. I think having the solutions to some of these problems would have helped immensely.
description: This course is a follow-on to ENG-SCI 155 and continues to develop the fundamentals of information systems in the real world. It focuses on the analysis and manipulation of signals in the time and frequency domains in the context of authentic applications. Topics include: the sampling theorem, convolution, and linear input-output systems in continuous and discrete time. Further, students are introduced to transforms—including Fourier, discrete cosine, wavelet, and PCA / SVD ‘transforms’—that map between vector spaces via matrix multiplication as a method to ease analysis provided conditionalized knowledge. Randomness, noise, and filtering. Waves and interference in the context of communications; antennae, phasors, modulation, multiplexing. Applications in communications and data science.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: Math 21a and Math 21b (or equivalents), or Applied Math 22a

best_comment: ES177 is a great course. Throughout the semester, you have 4 labs (each ~4 hours), 4 lab reports, and 1 final project review (or final project if you take ES277). The four–hour lab can sound intimidating, but it was honestly a good time. A lot of the time, we finished early. If we went past dinner, the class had a budget and got food afterwards as a group.This course is a great way to get ISO–5 cleanroom experience, especially with microfabrication. Getting microfab cleanroom experience is typically not offered for undergrads, so this is a great opportunity to try something new. I recommend the course!
description: The course provides introduction to micro- and nano-fabrication processes used to realize photonic, electronic and mechanical devices. Lectures will introduce the state-of-the-art semiconductor fabrication processes, including lithography, deposition of metals and dielectrics, etching, oxidation, implantation, and diffusion of dopants. The fabrication component of the course will be carried out in a state-of-the-art cleanroom in the Center for Nanoscale Systems, where students will fabricate several electronic and photonic devices, including transistors, light-emitting diodes (LEDs), lasers and optical resonators.  Device characterization will be performed in a state-of-the-art teaching labs in SEC in Allston.
notes: Course also includes a 4-hour lab session each week. Course cap is for ES 177 and ES 277 combined.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: (Applied Physics 50a OR Physical Sciences 12a OR Physics 15a) AND (Applied Physics 50b OR Physical Sciences 12b OR Physics 15b)

best_comment: Take this class if MECHE concentrator, especially if professor Wicks is teaching. Do not let the quizzes put you off. They are graded very generously and makes the studying for the midterms and finals much easier (as you already know a lot of the material already from studying for the quizzes). Also professor Wicks focuses on intuition a lot and real word application, which is great.
description: The macroscopic description of the fundamentals of heat transfer and their application to practical problems in energy conversion, electronics and living systems with an emphasis on developing a physical and analytical understanding of conductive, convective and radiative heat transfer. Emphasis will be given to problem solving skills based on applying governing principles, mathematical models and physical intuition.Topics include: steady state heat conduction in 1, 2 and 3D; transient heat conduction in 1D and 3D; introduction to convective heat transfer, forced convection as well as free convection; heat exchange analysis and design; elements of radiative heat transfer. There will be an emphasis on physical basis of heat transfer with mathematical description where appropriate, as well as using commercially available computer COMSOL software. Course includes (i) classes and problem sets, (ii) COMSOL simulations and (iii) a semester-long, multi-disciplinary team project.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: (Applied Math 21a or Math 21a or equivalent) AND (Applied Math 21b or Math 21b or equivalent) AND (APPHY 50a or PHYSCI 12a or Physics 15a)

best_comment: Going to office hours and interacting with teaching staffs and peers are very helpful. Take detailed notes and make sure you understand/remember the derivation, even though derivation is not emphasized in the class.
description: This course develops the principles of hydrodynamics from fundamental statistical and continuum viewpoints. Emphasis is placed on scaling laws, similarity solutions, singular behaviors, along with modern applications across the physical and biological sciences, from electron flows to geophysical fluid dynamics, from active matter to combustion and turbulence. Statistical mechanics and hydrodynamic emergence; Boltzmann to Navier-Stokes; Continuum mechanics and constitutive laws; Eulerian and Lagrangian descriptions; Euler’s equation, vorticity and Kelvin’s theorem; Navier-Stokes equations and boundary conditions; Stokes flows and lubrication theory; boundary layers, lift, drag, separation; similarity solutions and asymptotics; finite-time singularities; Kolmogorov theory, intermittency, law of the wall; transitions to turbulence, chaos; Instabilities; linear and nonlinear waves; GFD and shallow water theory, tsunamis; stratification, internal waves, convection; hurricanes and atmospheric vortices; viscous electron fluids, Gurzhi effect; MHD, Alfven waves; plasma hydrodynamics, Langmuir waves; combustion; Stefan problems and phase change; low Reynolds number swimming; active matter, nematodynamics, towards ML and data-driven hydrodynamics.
notes: ENG-SCI 220 is also offered as Physics 220. Students may not take both for credit.

best_comment: Do not be afraid of previous Q–guide reviews regarding this class. It is not as bad as it seems. It is indeed very time–consuming, but I found much of the work to be spent on research and/or documentation, and working with a team certainly helps a lot in terms of splitting up the workload.  If you want to go into the medical device industry, you should definitely take this class. This class is one of the closest things at Harvard that will give you exposure to what it's like to work as an engineer––– from constant feedback, collaboration, iterative prototyping, design validation/testing, working with clients, presentations to documentation. The experience and skills you gain in this class will look great to have on your resume or grad school applications. What you gain out of this class makes all the time and sacrifices spent worth it. The professors have high expectations of you, and you will sometimes have to scrap ideas and projects you were working on and start over. If you have a bad team, communicate with your teammates your expectations maturely and take some measures to improve the team dynamics immediately. You will be spending most of your semester with them.
worse_comment: Good exposure to medical device design, but it does take a lot of work, especially at the end. Bring some physical and electronics prototyping experience and you’ll be good, the difficulty lies in narrowing your design at the beginning with your team and managing your time at the end.
description: Project-based course on the design of medical devices to address needs identified by hospital-based clinicians. Students work in teams with physicians to develop a novel device. The design process includes: needs finding; problem identification; prior art searches; strategy and concept generation; estimation; sketching; sketch modeling; machine elements, ergonomics and prototyping.

best_comment: Do not be afraid of previous Q–guide reviews regarding this class. It is not as bad as it seems. It is indeed very time–consuming, but I found much of the work to be spent on research and/or documentation, and working with a team certainly helps a lot in terms of splitting up the workload.  If you want to go into the medical device industry, you should definitely take this class. This class is one of the closest things at Harvard that will give you exposure to what it's like to work as an engineer––– from constant feedback, collaboration, iterative prototyping, design validation/testing, working with clients, presentations to documentation. Bring some physical and electronics prototyping experience and you’ll be good, the difficulty lies in narrowing your design at the beginning with your team and managing your time at the end.
description: Project-based course on the design of medical devices to address needs identified by hospital-based clinicians. Students work in teams with physicians to develop a novel device. The design process includes: needs finding; problem identification; prior art searches; strategy and concept generation; estimation; sketching; sketch modeling; machine elements, ergonomics and prototyping.

best_comment: This course is a must–take for anyone interested in the energy/electricity sectors – it offers a very thorough treatment of virtually all energy–related technologies, spanning both fossil fuels and renewables, as well as other relevant topics like energy economics and power grids.  I feel like this is the one class in particular I've taken at Harvard that has best informed/reshaped my understanding of the broad landscape of energy and power.Regarding work, the textbook is the linchpin of the course and strikes an excellent balance between breadth and technical detail; the lectures largely follow the same structure as the book.  As such, my main advice is: the more time you put into reading the textbook before each class, the more you will get out of this course.  It's a lot to take in, but you won't regret putting in the legwork here.  This also goes for the final project: start early and pursue something interesting, and it will be a highly rewarding experience.  Finally, definitely go to Prof. Aziz's office hours or otherwise discuss the content/projects with him, and also definitely try to make all of the guest lectures!
description: Principles governing energy generation and interconversion. Current and projected world energy use. Selected important current and anticipated future technologies for energy generation, interconversion, storage, and end usage.
notes: This course must be taken Sat/Unsat. Cannot be used for SEAS concentration credit. Students may not take both Engineering Sciences 229 and Engineering Sciences 231 for credit. The enrollment cap is for ES 229 and ES 231 combined.

best_comment: This course is a must–take for anyone interested in the energy/electricity sectors – it offers a very thorough treatment of virtually all energy–related technologies, spanning both fossil fuels and renewables, as well as other relevant topics like energy economics and power grids.  I feel like this is the one class in particular I've taken at Harvard that has best informed/reshaped my understanding of the broad landscape of energy and power.Regarding work, the textbook is the linchpin of the course and strikes an excellent balance between breadth and technical detail; the lectures largely follow the same structure as the book.  As such, my main advice is: the more time you put into reading the textbook before each class, the more you will get out of this course.  It's a lot to take in, but you won't regret putting in the legwork here.  This also goes for the final project: start early and pursue something interesting, and it will be a highly rewarding experience.  Finally, definitely go to Prof. Aziz's office hours or otherwise discuss the content/projects with him, and also definitely try to make all of the guest lectures!
description: Principles governing energy generation and interconversion. Current and projected world energy use. Selected important current and anticipated future technologies for energy generation, interconversion, storage, and end usage.
notes: Students may not take both Engineering Sciences 231 and Engineering Sciences 229 for credit. The enrollment cap is for ES 229 and ES 231 combined.

best_comment: ES177 is a great course. Throughout the semester, you have 4 labs (each ~4 hours), 4 lab reports, and 1 final project review (or final project if you take ES277). The four–hour lab can sound intimidating, but it was honestly a good time. A lot of the time, we finished early. If we went past dinner, the class had a budget and got food afterwards as a group.This course is a great way to get ISO–5 cleanroom experience, especially with microfabrication. Getting microfab cleanroom experience is typically not offered for undergrads, so this is a great opportunity to try something new. I recommend the course!
description: The course provides introduction to micro- and nano-fabrication processes used to realize photonic, electronic and mechanical devices. Lectures will introduce the state-of-the-art semiconductor fabrication processes, including lithography, deposition of metals and dielectrics, etching, oxidation, implantation, and diffusion of dopants. The fabrication component of the course will be carried out in a state-of-the-art cleanroom in the Center for Nanoscale Systems, where students will fabricate several electronic and photonic devices, including transistors, light-emitting diodes (LEDs), lasers and optical resonators.  Device characterization will be performed in a state-of-the-art teaching labs in SEC in Allston.
notes: Course also includes a 4-hour lab session each week. Content and requirements are similar to Engineering Sciences 177, with the addition that students enrolled in Engineering Sciences 277 are given an additional project. Course cap is for ES 177 and ES 277 combined.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: (Applied Physics 50a OR Physical Sciences 12a OR Physics 15a) AND (Applied Physics 50b OR Physical Sciences 12b OR Physics 15b)

best_comment: best class in the MSMBA!
description: The MS/MBA Capstone is an intensive project-based experience that requires teams of students to apply and integrate the skills they have learned across the program curriculum. Specifically, teams will be expected to design, build (and hopefully, launch) a new technology-based product/service venture, and thereby to demonstrate mastery with respect to three fundamental areas of knowledge: Design Knowledge: The use of human-centered (and other) design methods to understand users, identify solutions to their needs, and gather feedback on solutions via rapid, iterative prototyping. Technical Knowledge: The use of rigorous system engineering methods to plan, design, develop, build, and test a complex technology-based product/service, integrating knowledge across diverse engineering disciplines. And Business Knowledge: The use of lean experimentation methods to develop and test a set of hypotheses that capture how the new product/service will create value, including business model design, customer value proposition, go to market (GTM) strategy, operating model and profit formula.The Capstone comprises two related courses. The first course – Launch Lab 1 – is an immersive course completed over a 2-week period in January of the EC year (Capstone I). In the first week, student teams learn how to structure and execute a “Design Sprint” – a rigorous process for identifying problems, brainstorming solutions and building prototypes that can be tested with users. The Sprint process has been widely adopted by startups and large corporations and is a key technique for aspiring product managers. In the second week, teams develop an “Investor Pitch” for a business model that surrounds the new product/service concept they are working on. At the end of this week, teams then pitch their venture ideas to real investors and receive feedback on their viability and feasibility.The second course in the capstone sequence – Launch Lab 2 – follows on and builds upon the work completed in January, meeting weekly in the spring term. In this course, the focus is on how to operate and run a venture after it receives funding. Lectures, cases and project work are used to help students develop operating plans for their businesses, draft job descriptions for key hires, and source potential advisors, etc. Throughout the capstone course, students must constantly decide whether to persist, pivot, or perish, with their venture ideas, though a series of defined Go/No Go milestones. Hence some students work on multiple ideas during the capstone sequence, whereas others bring one idea to fruition. Historically, several capstone ventures from each cohort receive funding from VCs.
notes: Open to MS/MBA: Engineering Sciences students only, or to others by permission of the instructor.

best_comment: best class in the MSMBA!
