description: Continued investigation of functions and differential calculus through modeling; an introduction to integration with applications; an introduction to differential equations. Solid preparation for Mathematics 1b.There will be required workshops Tuesdays.
notes: Math MB is taught in small sections throughout the day on a Monday/Wednesday/Friday schedule (9:00-10:15 am, 10:30-11:45 am, 12-1:15 pm, 1:30-2:45 pm, and 3:00-4:15 pm with sufficient enrollment). Completing your registration for Math MB is a two-step process: first, you'll enroll in the course within my.harvard, and then, you'll fill out the Math Sectioning form in your my.harvard To-Do list to submit your time preferences. Please submit time preferences before 11:59pm on Friday, 11/14. Note this To-Do list may take up to 15 minutes to appear after enrolling. If your time preferences change, you may submit the form again; only your latest submission will be used.   This course, when taken together with Mathematics Ma, can be followed by Mathematics 1b. Mathematics Ma and Mathematics Mb together cover all the material in Mathematics 1a (and more).
course_requirements: Prerequisite: Mathematics MA or Mathematics MA5

course_title_2025: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 020
best_comment: I think this is a good course! It breaks down everything really well, so though you need to REALLY understand it, I prefer that to having a surface level understanding. Go to MQC for your psets and study in advance for the tests.

course_title_2025: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 021
best_comment: I would recommend this class even if you think you are above it. Listen to the course recommendations! They know how your math knowledge will be applied to their courses better than you do. I am so happy that I took math M because I learned that I was lacking some fundamental algebra skills that I would need to make math easier for me. Learning them was more like review, but was a good refresher that made the class enjoyable and easier for me.

course_title_2025: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 030
best_comment: Assuming that you have already taken Ma, Mb is the second course of the M series. Throughout this two–part course, I have contemplated many times whether I should follow through with the M series or to switch to another math course—and I am sure a few other peers of mine were on the same boat. I chose to stick to Mb in the end, and I do not regret as it has surely given me a boost of confidence in my math skills. I believe that Math Mb was very well–taught—just make sure to take advantage of the resources provided (that is, go to office hours)!

course_title_2025: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 040
best_comment: Math MB is great. The staff and CAs are fantastic. A lot of people complain about the Math department at Harvard because they teach things differently than most people are used to, but as someone who hadn't taken a Math class in like 8 years I thought it really allowed me to understand what I was doing rather than just following a set of rules to spit out correct answers. Like any other Math class it's 3 PSETs a week. Yeah it kind of sucks but most of the time they take like 1–2 hours and if you do it right after section it's not so bad. There's 3 skills checks and 2 mid–terms. None of them are particularly difficult as long as you've payed attention in class and done your PSETs. That's the really nice thing about Math here is there's no real way to fall behind as long as you're doing the bare minimum. If you have already taken Math MA then you're probably choosing between MB and Math LS, Q, etc. If you plan on or are even considering concentrating in anything that requires a higher level math course (1b, 21a, etc.) take this course. If you're Econ or Pre–Med and you don't need more Math take Q or LS respectively. You learn a lot of the same concepts but they get applied to your actual field of study rather than being straight math classes.
worse_comment: PLEASE AVOID AT ALL COSTS UNLESS YOU ARE FORCED TO TAKE THIS CLASS. IF YOU ARE FORCED TO TAKE THIS CLASS, SERIOUSLY CONSIDER CHANGING CONCENTRATIONS!

course_title_2025: Quantitative Analysis for Economics and the Social Sciences I 000
best_comment: I would tell students that the class is run much better thn Ma, taught at a great pace with learning base blocks and building. This course is very challenging at times with having to figure stuff out on your own as designed, that did enhance my skills overall. The teaching team led by Brendan is incredible and he cares so much about the student and their individual learning needs.
course_title_2026: Quantitative Analysis for Economics and the Social Sciences I
description: This course develops a portable toolkit of quantitative skills that supports students' strategic thinking. At the center of the course is a set of case studies that require comprehensive quantitative analysis to properly diagnose and address the broad range of problems presented. After taking this course, students' strategic thinking will be bolstered by the ability to develop mathematical models, apply core ideas from differential and integral calculus and statistics to solve problems in economics and social science, and make use of spreadsheets and the R statistical package to carry out data analysis. Each analytical tool comes to life in an authentic application. The course focuses not just on how to carry out the analysis, but how to communicate results to a non-mathematical audience in simple functional language. This course should be seen as an applied alternative for Math Ma/Math Mb or Math 1a for students interested in Economics and the Social Sciences. Students completing Math Ma and Math Q will satisfy the Math 1a requirement for the Economics Concentration. Students who want to take Math 1b should instead enroll in Math Mb.
notes: Math Q is taught in small sections throughout the day on a Monday/Wednesday/Friday schedule (9:00 am, noon, and 1:30 pm). Completing your registration for Math Q is a two-step process: first, you'll enroll in the course within my.harvard, and then, you'll fill out the Math Sectioning form in your my.harvard To-Do list to submit your time preferences. Please submit time preferences before 11:59pm on Friday, 11/14. Note this To-Do list may take up to 15 minutes to appear after enrolling. If your time preferences change, you may submit the form again; only your latest submission will be used.

course_title_2025: Quantitative Analysis for Economics and the Social Sciences I 020
best_comment: Take this class but be aware of the fact that it is newly established and has less resources than other math courses. I didn't hate my time in this class and feel that it is the best option for those that need to fulfill it for Econ or anything else, but be prepared to spend at least 5 hours on PSETs when you have a coding component, if not more. You are expected to write code on your own which is incredibly difficult without decent exposure to it in class. Brendan and Matt are great, but they have limited office hours and CAs are only helpful if they have had coding experience before and can actually explain it to you. Make sure to know EVERYTHING in detail for quizzes and the final exam. This course is a good alternative if you want to avoid more intense math, but be aware that it is actively being shaped. GO TO OFFICE HOURS.

course_title_2025: Quantitative Analysis for Economics and the Social Sciences I 030
best_comment: As someone who had no prior experience with data analysis, I was a little apprehensive about taking Math Q at first but I loved it! Granted, this was the first year that it was being taught in this format so some parts of the course were a bit disorganized but the course logistics will definitely smooth out over its next couple of iterations.If you’re at all interested in data analysis or a future in finance then I would highly recommend taking this course; I found that it provided a pretty low stakes introduction to coding and working with spreadsheets. Like many of the other introductory math courses, there are ample resources available for Math Q. I spent a lot of time in MQC and office hours over the semester which paid off when we had to come up with projects based off the work that the we did in class and on PSETs. It’s definitely possible to skate by without using those resources but  I think that if I didn’t understand the code or basic concepts that we learned in class, it would have been much harder to come up with a unique project. Learning how to code in Google Colabs was definitely the most challenging part of the course. There were MANY problem sets with coding elements that I wouldn’t have been able to figure out on my own unless I went to MQC or office hours. That being said, we were allowed to use the AI helper in Google Colabs on tests and quizzes which definitely saved me multiple times during the semester. The quizzes and final were extremely fair and, in my opinion, very manageable given the way that they’re structured (each quiz corresponds with a unit and the final was broken up into the four units). Lastly, I just wanted to highlight that Matt and Brendan, the two course heads, are probably the most caring and genuine teachers that I’ve met at Harvard so far. They clearly want to see their students succeed (two examples: staying longer than their scheduled office hours and curving a quiz when nobody finished on time), are excited about the course material, and are extremely receptive to feedback. Although some parts of the course were challenging, I ended the semester with a newfound interest in data analysis and familiarity with basic coding and modeling in spreadsheets. TL;DR: If you’re deciding between Math Mb and Math Q, take Math Q!!! ESPECIALLY if you already took calculus in high school.
worse_comment: It is a great course to learn real world mathematics, but the coding is difficult and the class is poorly organized.

best_comment: It's definitely not as bad as people say. That being said make sure you actually understand why things work the way they do. The concepts build gradually on top of each other, so if you have that understanding makes the class very doable, if you don't I can see how it can be very hard to stay on top of things. The 3 PSets can be a lot because there is always something to do for the class, but they also make sure that you stay engaged with the content. Before exams, take all of the practice exams and go step by step through the solutions to make sure you understand what you are doing right and what you are doing wrong. Don't let negative comments about this class discourage you from taking it, I wish I had taken it earlier and had the potential to take further maths courses. Amadeus is also amazing! Very understanding and helpful course had and section leader who always has the best interest of his students in mind.
description: To see how calculus applies in practical situations described by more than one variable, we study integration over curves, surfaces, and solid regions using different coordinate systems; parameterization of curves and surfaces; vectors, lines, and planes; partial derivatives and the gradient; constrained and unconstrained optimization; divergence and curl of vector fields; and the Green's, Stokes's, and Divergence Theorems.There will be required workshops Tuesdays.
notes: Math 21a is taught in small sections throughout the day on a Monday/Wednesday/Friday schedule (9:00-10:15 am, 10:30-11:45 am, 12-1:15 pm, 1:30-2:45 pm, and 3:00-4:15 pm with sufficient enrollment). Completing your registration for Math 21a is a two-step process: first, you'll enroll in the course within my.harvard, and then, you'll fill out the Math Sectioning form in your my.harvard To-Do list to submit your time preferences. Please submit time preferences before 11:59pm on Friday, 11/14. Note this To-Do list may take up to 15 minutes to appear after enrolling. If your time preferences change, you may submit the form again; only your latest submission will be used.   In order to receive your section assignment, you are required to take the Math 21A skills check. Please see the course's Canvas site for more information.
course_requirements: Anti-requisite: Cannot be taken for credit if Math 18A or Math 22B already complete.

best_comment: Great class! Fun concepts and great real–world connections and applications of the content. The 3 psets per week can be a little overwhelming, but go to MQC and ask your friends for help.
description: To see how calculus applies in practical situations described by more than one variable, we study integration over curves, surfaces, and solid regions using different coordinate systems; parameterization of curves and surfaces; vectors, lines, and planes; partial derivatives and the gradient; constrained and unconstrained optimization; divergence and curl of vector fields; and the Green's, Stokes's, and Divergence Theorems.There will be required workshops Tuesdays.

If your time preferences change, you may submit the form again; only your latest submission will be used.   In order to receive your section assignment, you are required to take the Math 21A skills check. Please see the course's Canvas site for more information.
course_requirements: Anti-requisite: Cannot be taken for credit if Math 18A or Math 22B already complete.

best_comment: This course is intense. By the end of the semester, you'll eat, drink, and speak math. PSets and worksheets keep you busy daily, as do AI assignments. The quantity of material covered is so much that it might seem (and it is true) that at times the material is not being learnt too efficiently, but that is okay once you get to exams. Exams (4 of them throughout the semester) are a way for you to go over all the material you covered in class, so by doing the practice tests (i.e. doing them in a timed environment, checking answers, reattempting them) you'll learn everything. It always strikes me that unfortunately, at Harvard, course support is decreasing in difficulty of the course itself. That is to say, this course has a ton of support material, MQC, office hours, fun TFs that are very good at explaining, so you'll never run out of options to consider when doing work for the class. But this is jus because this class is introductory. Overall, the course is well–structured, intense, and prepares you well for courses in other concentrations that you might approach in your time at Harvard, so I recommend this (especially over 22B. I took 22A and it was just the worst experience I've had at Harvard).
worse_comment: I wouldn't take this course unless you are unbothered by constant PSETs or it is a requirement. You get a PSET every couple days so there's no way to get ahead, which is tough if you have a busy schedule.
description: To see how calculus applies in practical situations described by more than one variable, we study integration over curves, surfaces, and solid regions using different coordinate systems; parameterization of curves and surfaces; vectors, lines, and planes; partial derivatives and the gradient; constrained and unconstrained optimization; divergence and curl of vector fields; and the Green's, Stokes's, and Divergence Theorems.There will be required workshops Tuesdays.
notes: Math 21a is taught in small sections throughout the day on a Monday/Wednesday/Friday schedule (9:00-10:15 am, 10:30-11:45 am, 12-1:15 pm, 1:30-2:45 pm, and 3:00-4:15 pm with sufficient enrollment). Completing your registration for Math 21a is a two-step process: first, you'll enroll in the course within my.harvard, and then, you'll fill out the Math Sectioning form in your my.harvard To-Do list to submit your time preferences. Please submit time preferences before 11:59pm on Friday, 11/14. Note this To-Do list may take up to 15 minutes to appear after enrolling. If your time preferences change, you may submit the form again; only your latest submission will be used.   In order to receive your section assignment, you are required to take the Math 21A skills check. Please see the course's Canvas site for more information.
course_requirements: Anti-requisite: Cannot be taken for credit if Math 18A or Math 22B already complete.

best_comment: This course is intense. By the end of the semester, you'll eat, drink, and speak math. PSets and worksheets keep you busy daily, as do AI assignments. The quantity of material covered is so much that it might seem (and it is true) that at times the material is not being learnt too efficiently, but that is okay once you get to exams. Exams (4 of them throughout the semester) are a way for you to go over all the material you covered in class, so by doing the practice tests (i.e. doing them in a timed environment, checking answers, reattempting them) you'll learn everything. It always strikes me that unfortunately, at Harvard, course support is decreasing in difficulty of the course itself. That is to say, this course has a ton of support material, MQC, office hours, fun TFs that are very good at explaining, so you'll never run out of options to consider when doing work for the class. But this is jus because this class is introductory. Overall, the course is well–structured, intense, and prepares you well for courses in other concentrations that you might approach in your time at Harvard, so I recommend this (especially over 22B. I took 22A and it was just the worst experience I've had at Harvard).
worse_comment: I wouldn't take this course unless you are unbothered by constant PSETs or it is a requirement. You get a PSET every couple days so there's no way to get ahead, which is tough if you have a busy schedule.

best_comment: If you take this course, go to MQC and Office Hours – even if you understand the content. These are great resources to discuss broader course concepts and to get exam advice from CAs and TFs. This is a difficult course, but it is completely manageable. The 3 PSets a week are difficult (especially if you are taking other PSet classes), but they are good prep for exams. Put forth your best effort, and you will do well in this course.

best_comment: I originally took Multivariable Calculus at my local community college in high school and found the course here to be significantly better. Taking Math 21a allowed me to have a solid understanding of the content, and I appreciate the amount of effort put into teaching the material. It meets 3 times a week in small class sections, which is by far the best part of the course. Your TF will lecture, and you solve problems with others at your tables or on the chalkboards in small groups – repeating this with the next iteration of new content multiple times in each lecture. This makes it helpful to follow and understand the material. I think you only need AP Calculus AB (or Math 1a) and some self–studying of integration by parts to take this course. It is not hard as long as you take the time to understand the material before the next lecture. The most important piece of advice I have is to not fall behind!The midterm exams were very fair. I never left feeling like I had not studied enough. However, the PSETS and AI Assignments, which I believe were new this semester, were my least favorite part of the course. I am very detail–oriented and try to understand everything for an easier study period when exams come up. As a consequence for me, I spent 4–5 hours on average for most of the PSETS in this course. Some people I know were able to get them done faster. The AI assignments were problematic because the AI tutor simply refuses to tell you if you are on the right track with your answers.Overall, this course is great!

best_comment: if you have taken math 1b, math 21a will feel like a natural continuation. to me, it felt even easier, given that, by then, I was used to the way math is taught at Harvard. if you like rigor and proofs, don't take the class, you will find neither. but the class does well what it promises: a good overview of multi for stem (non pure math) concentrators. as you will know, the experience in the class will depend largely on your TF. Eva was great and made every single section very enjoyable and engaging. exams were super fair, definitely easier than practice tests.
worse_comment: This course gets so confusing and the tfs aren't teaching you how everything connects, which makes it so hard to actually understand. Also, we just speed through everything and barely get through half the worksheet in class so then you are lost on the pset. Only take this class if you are proficient in math and ready to spend hours on it each week.

best_comment: Take this class! It's taught very well (depending on your TF). Amadeus is really great, and I think the content is actually really interesting and fun to learn. Sections were super effective and although it's 3 psets a week, you can finish one in less than 2 hours. If you want to learn multivariable calculus, this is such a great class. Definitely take advantage of all the practice materials when exams come around. The first midterm was pretty chill and the second one was slightly harder. Start studying relatively early and take all the practice exams, and you will be fine.
worse_comment: This class made me love math. I thought math was my least favorite subject and was dreading taking this class, but I genuinely enjoyed this course so much that I enrolled in two more math classes next semester. If you are scared to take it because you feel that your calculus skills aren't good enough, they are more than likely sufficient. I took Calc BC in my senior year of high school, and took this course my sophomore spring as my first math class at Harvard. I was terrified and was confident that I would need to drop down to Math 1b; however, the content is taught so incredibly that I did really well in the class. I am not amazing at math, and, honestly, I am probably a little bit worse than the average Harvard student, but I am finishing the class with a good grade and a new interest in math. I can't recommend this course enough.

best_comment: I loved this course. Even though you will likely not have a choice as to whether you take it or not, it is a great class that you should be excited to take either way. If you can see which TF takes which section before enrolling, pick Jonier's section! You will meet lots of new people so it is a brilliant course for first years in my opinion too. The psets really aren't too bad, and they are very fair with grading and midterms.
worse_comment: WARNING ⚠️! This class is SO HARD. Especially if you do not come from a math–intensive background. A lot of people in these QReports will say that it is fine and that the class was manageable, but these are people who have already taken multivariable calculus in the past. There are two clear distinctions of people in this class: (1) those who are doing well and do not study much for the exams and still ace them vs. (2) those who have not taken multivariable calculus before and are struggling. My biggest advice is to find friends and understand that you will struggle. You will feel lost but push through it because I am assuming you don't plan on taking this class just for fun but you need it for your major. Talk to your TF (and make sure you like them and they like you) and ask your friends to study with you so you can all solve problems together. The exams can also be extremely difficult. Midterm 2 for us was so bad. Most of me friends and I got horrible grades (aka < 60%) but it's consistently this trend of people who already know the material getting A's and us who studied for weeks (genuinely) and getting screwed over with the unrealistic expectations. I am writing this at a time where I haven't taken the final yet, but this class has been MISERABLE and it will be MISERABLE if you are like me, coming from a non–math extensive background and a high school with limited resources. Know you are not struggling alone and take up all the resources there are. Goodbye MATH 21A, I hated you.

best_comment: Background: Freshman who took 22a in the fall, and decided to take 21a in the spring. In HS, did AP Calc BC in Junior Year & Multi/Linear Algebra in Senior Year.Thoughts: Very solid class. Excellent teaching staff and environment. You learn a decent amount but it's super reasonable. PSETs aren't too hard. [ALSO] I made the decision to take 22a in the fall because it was 1 pset and was more challenging than some classes I thought were a little easy. 22a was taught poorly so I made the switch to 21a. The 3 psets aren't bad. In fact, I spent more time in 22a doing a pset than maybe like 4–5 psets in 21a.

course_title_2025: Vector Calculus and Linear Algebra II 001
best_comment: This class was great! 22a got a lot of hate last semester, but keep in mind that was Prof. Wood's first time teaching the course. That being said, he made a significant number of improvements based on feedback. Here are a few; there are not longer random extra days of class, section is optional now, lectures feel better paced with a bit more time for problems, attendance sheets were simplified and make more sense, the random extra coding/math projects are gone, and so on. It is also clear from the syllabus that Prof. Wood read through the Q guide, identified resources that were particularly helpful to students last semester, and emphasized them this semester. Perhaps the only note I have about this course is that students should really take 22a first, as a lot of 22b draws on concepts from 22a (especially at the beginning of class).  It helps to brush up on 22a materials also, especially if you may have forgotten over winter break or took 22a longer than a semester ago. Other than that, this course is pretty straightforward – grading is to your benefit, classes are easy to follow, and the prof cares a lot and so makes the material interesting (therefore making it easier to learn). This course has 3 midterms (they weren't bad, were graded pretty leniently and the questions made sense). It is proof based, so much of the homework involves writing proofs instead of explicit calculation. Especially compared to 21, this class has only one pset and one brief online assignment per week, making it by and far less stressful (source; the pained looks on the faces of my friends in 21). Teaching staff are nice and available when needed. I felt that I took a lot away from this course, and I would definitely recommend it! (Bonus note; if you are free, the best office hours to go to are Wood's own – he explains stuff better (more effectively and more efficiently) and is super nice. I had classes during his OH this semester, but if you can, definitely go and say hi)
worse_comment: You'll come away from this class proficient in applying Stokes' Theorem, but without much understanding of why we're using said theorem or why we took a certain approach to prove it. You'll learn to perform the calculations, but not truly understand the structure governing multivariable calculus — which is concerning, considering that this is a proof–based course (for reference, I attended every lecture and kept up with the material; I still felt somewhat lost as to the "why"; maybe also because there are almost zero real–world application problems to see theorems in action). There are also issues with organization. Problem sets have little to nothing to do with exam material, and often require leaps of thinking that necessitate going to office hours to find a very specific approach. Points are also taken off arbitrarily by CAs who were perhaps grading carelessly — but if you confront Dr. Wood about a possible grading mistake, he's extremely unlikely to change it (he'll just try to retroactively justify why the choice was made, even when it's clear that it was a mistake). Exam practice materials are posted extremely late and often come with no solutions and many errors.With that said, the course pack structure — in which Dr. Wood lectures and students follow along in a set of notes containing theorems and practice problems — works well, and the exams aren't unreasonable. A decent option for those looking for a somewhat more rigorous approach to multivariable calculus but aren't interested in spending 20 hours/week on Math 25 or 55.
course_title_2026: Vector Calculus and Linear Algebra II
description: A continuation of Mathematics 22a
course_requirements: Anti-requisite: Cannot be taken for credit if Math 18A, Math 21A, or AM 22B already complete.

course_title_2025: Theoretical Linear Algebra and Real Analysis II 001
best_comment: Wes is THE GOAT. He is a phenomenal lecturer who is capable of explaining complicated material in a very accessible way. His enthusiasm and devotion to his class and the students in it are very inspiring. That being said, 25b is a hard class, definitely harder than 25a and one that is likely to kill your GPA, but you come of it with increased mathematical maturity and independence as well as proof stamina. Personally, I preferred the content of 25a, but I am more of an algebra guy, so take this as you will. If you're on the fence between 25b and 55b, I would definitely shop both especially given that next year's 25b will be taught by a different instructor. But personally, I feel like I gained a better understanding of real analysis in 25b than I would have in 55b. All in all, this was a great class with a fantastic community and an incredible instructor.
course_title_2026: Theoretical Linear Algebra and Real Analysis II
description: A rigorous treatment of basic analysis. Topics include: convergence, continuity, differentiation, the Riemann integral, uniform convergence, the Stone-Weierstrass theorem, Fourier series, differentiation in several variables. Additional topics, including the classical results of vector calculus in two and three dimensions, as time allows.
notes: Expect to spend a lot time doing mathematics.
course_requirements:
Anti-requisite: Cannot be taken for credit if Math 18A, Math 21A, Math 22B, Math 101, Math 112, or AM 22B already complete.
	
Prerequisite: Mathematics 25A OR Mathematics 55A

course_title_2025: Studies in Real and Complex analysis 001
best_comment: PLEASE TAKE THIS CLASS! If you're reading this, you probably took 22a or 25a last semester, and considering moving up because of whatever. If so, please please please take the class. I was in the exact same situation having not taken 55a last semester, and wanted to challenge myself further with more math. Switching to 55b was probably the absolute best decision I made this semester and I have absolutely zero regrets about doing so. Yes, the workload was pretty insane at points (prepare for a LOT of all nighters), but you will definitely get through it. You also won't need much content from 55a. There's a bit of algebra when it comes to algebraic topology, but it is completely learnable when you get to that point. There was an in person midterm which was pretty brutal, but it was a small percentage of the grade so it really didn't matter in the end. Most of your grade will be from psets, so if you invest a lot of time into those and find a good group of friends to work on them with, you will be absolutely fine. Prof. Auroux gives really good lectures, and I would try go to them as much as possible, but the lecture notes are also a very very good resource (pretty much all I used).Basically, if you took 22a or 25a and want more, just take the class and don't think about it anymore. The first few weeks might be a bit rough as you get used to the workload and find people to work with, but once things settle down, it will probably end up being your favorite class, as this is exactly what happened in my case.  Taking the class allowed me to meet who I now consider my best friends, so I owe so much to the class for that.Just try it! You won't regret it!
worse_comment: Take the class if you really love pure math. If not, you might end up disliking some parts of pure math by the end. Personally, I really liked the analysis section but disliked the algebra section from 55a. Be ready for a lot of homework. The problem sets can be a drag and some problems might have proofs that span several pages.
course_title_2026: Studies in Real and Complex analysis
description: A rigorous introduction to real and complex analysis.  This course covers the equivalent of Mathematics 25b and Mathematics 113, and prepares students for Mathematics 114 and other advanced courses in analysis.
notes: Mathematics 55b is an intensive course for students having significant experience with abstract mathematics.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: Mathematics 55A

course_title_2025: Reading Course for Senior Honors Candidates 001
best_comment: This is a great class if you want a lighter course load to concentrate on your math thesis.
course_title_2026: Reading Course for Senior Honors Candidates
description: Mathematics concentrators in their final two undergraduate semesters can take this course to work individually on their senior thesis.
notes: Limited to candidates in Mathematics who obtain the permission of both the faculty member under whom they want to work and the Director of Undergraduate Studies.  May not count for concentration in Mathematics without special permission from the Director of Undergraduate Studies.  Graded sat/ unsat only.

best_comment: If the 99r has an interesting topic, by all means take it! Our year there were completion–graded weekly PSets to help you along.The paper isn't too stressful.Another major benefit is that the grad students are very available outside of class, and are very kind and receptive to questions about anything math related!(and Wyatt was amazing this year)
worse_comment: My one recommendation is don't just think 99r classes are going to be a joke. 99r are different every year but this iteration was a very serious math class covering content no other undergraduate course covers. We covered more material per lecture than any other class I had been in.
description: Supervised small group tutorial.  See the course website for the relevant semester’s version of Math 99r to learn more about the tutorial and to see that semester’s topic(s).
notes: May be repeated for course credit with permission from the Director of Undergraduate Studies. Only one tutorial may count for concentration credit.

best_comment: This will be said again and again, but math department courses HEAVILY DEPEND ON YOUR INSTRUCTOR!! If they have unfavorable reviews in past courses, it's not likely that there will be significant change later on. This review is only applicable to you if you're being taught by Park in a future class (I'm not sure how much longer he's in the dept. since he's a post doc). In this class, everyone I talked to was confused and didn't know what was going on. The content isn't necessarily the most riveting thing on Earth, but it certainly can be taught with enthusiasm. There was no enthusiasm from anyone in this class. I'm glad I took it to get my analysis req. out of the way, but certainly taking a more interesting class would have done me better. Grading wise, since the class is literally 70% Psets, don't worry about that. Instead, worry about your own intellectual vitality. And be wary of the instructors at this school who will snuff it out.
worse_comment: Math 112 may suck, it may be great. Likely it will suck. It all depends on what new grad student the math department dredges up to teach the course—they find a new one every. single. semester. My semester, the grad student—through no fault of his own—wasn't a good teacher, so the course wasn't good. The previous semester, the grad student was a good teacher, so the course wasn't good. If you have to take the class, you have to take the class. In retrospect, however, it might have been wiser to drop the class after the first few lectures, and hope that the randomly selected grad student was a better teacher next semester.
description: An introduction to mathematical analysis and the theory behind calculus. An emphasis on learning to understand and construct proofs. Covers limits and continuity in metric spaces, uniform convergence and spaces of functions, the Riemann integral.
course_requirements: Anti-Req: Not to be taken in addition to Mathematics 23a,b or 25a,b or 55a,b.

best_comment: Complex analysis is very cool class, at least the first half of it was cool. As we got toward the end of the semester, it lowkey became a real analysis class—we talked about infinite series and products for weeks, and I didn’t find that very fun. We could’ve learned so many more cool theorems in complex analysis than spending too much time on things we could’ve learned in real analysis. But what this meant was that the PSets were very easy in the second half of the semester. As long as you get through the pretty tricky proof questions as the course starts, things get significantly more straightforward at the end. The professor was also very relaxed with giving assignments. We had a lot of breathing time—sometimes we wouldn’t have PSets for a week, sometimes we would have an extremely short PSet. I think people should take this class for sure because it still gives you the mathematical vocabulary that you wouldn’t otherwise know.  Complex analysis is pretty thought–provoking and I hope in the future, it could use time better to teach more interesting results in the complex world.
worse_comment: I took this course without any experience with topology or real analysis, and found it very challenging. Would recommend taking 112 and / or 131 beforehand. I ultimately did fine, but there were many problem sets that took me several hours longer than they would've had I been able to apply some basic theorems from topology.
description: Analytic functions of one complex variable: power series expansions, contour integrals, Cauchy's theorem, Laurent series and the residue theorem. Some applications to real analysis, including the evaluation of indefinite integrals. An introduction to some special functions.

course_title_2025: Probability and Random Processes with Economic Applications 001
best_comment: It's an interesting class that has some interesting content, but a lot of it is very similar to some other stat courses (110 and 210 mostly superset the material in the class, aside from the stuff about Black–Scholes). There are some special concepts like hedging that you won't see in the other stat classes, but they're pretty simple and you could probably understand some of them in about ten minutes—probably not worth taking an entire course for. It's also unclear if this class will be run in the future by a different professor, since I think Bamberg is retiring soon (?) so maybe it'll be less scuffed in the future.
course_title_2026: Probability and Random Processes with Economic Applications
description: A self-contained treatment of the theory of probability and random processes with specific application to the theory of option pricing. Topics: axioms for probability, calculation of expectation by means of Lebesgue integration, conditional probability and conditional expectation, martingales, random walks and Wiener processes, and the Black-Scholes formula for option pricing. Students will work in small groups to investigate applications of the theory and to prove key results.

best_comment: This course is great! And Gage is an amazing lecturer.
worse_comment: Gage Martin is a very nice person and was lovely to get to know, but I would not recommend this class if she is teaching it. For reference, I have not ever learned any kind of proofs. She used all of the materials from the previous professor(Dr. Chen) and there are things on the syllabus that are not offered like "problem sessions". She posted Dr. Chen's syllabus, but never her own. Even worse, the homeworks reference worksheets sometimes in problems. I had to skip over a problem because you needed the worksheet reference to do it. Gage used these worksheets to structure her classes, but never handed them out to us or even posted them on canvas. I just do not understand why. Having something to look at and follow along with keeps me engaged in the class and it also gives me another thing to go over when studying and doing assignments. When I asked about the worksheets, I was told that she could send me the ones that I asked for instead of offering to just post them. Overall, I do not think that the teaching style was for me. It was very disorganized and all over the place. You don't really have to go to class. I tried to because I was a little lost, but it did not help at all.
description: This is a second course in linear algebra, with an emphasis on understanding linear algebra at a more abstract level and learning to read and write proofs. Topics include real and complex vector spaces, linear transformations, and eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
course_requirements: Anti-req: Not to be taken in addition to Mathematics 22a, 23a or 25a or 55a.

best_comment: This was a very solid geometry course. Very intro friendly, and the professor was a good lecturer.
worse_comment: Straightforward class, not very problem–solving focused, mostly follows textbook
description: Presents several classical geometries, these being the affine, projective, Euclidean, spherical and hyperbolic geometries. They are viewed from many different perspectives, some historical and some very topical. Emphasis on reading and writing proofs.

best_comment: Oliver is a true joy. He's an amazing person and a great lecturer (he just knows). However, the lectures in this course cover a lot of content in a short amount of time so it can be overwhelming and hard to follow at times. I think that I could have gotten more out of this course if I studied more outside of class. It goes into much more content than stat 110 but with much less rigor. I considered it as more of a survey of probability and measure theory than an in–depth course. The psets are either easy and unrelated to the core concepts of the lectures or extremely hard and related.
description: An introduction to probability theory. Discrete and continuous random variables; distribution and density functions for one and two random variables; conditional probability. Generating functions, weak and strong laws of large numbers, and the central limit theorem. Geometrical probability, random walks, and Markov processes.

best_comment: If you want a chill math class this is a pretty good one. You still have psets so it is harder than many humanities but if you know math they are all easy. If you are looking for a serious course obviously you wouldn't be on the page so this class is pretty much what you would expect.
worse_comment: The course is essentially quant interview prep: number theory that's essentially logic puzzles, probability in the style of Stat 110, combinatorics. There was a weirdly large amount of information theory. The concepts don't take a lot of effort to understand, and most of them will be familiar if you're a mathie. Some of the weekly problem sets can take a while... the later ones took me upwards of 12 hours.
description: An interactive introduction to problem solving with an emphasis on subjects with comprehensive applications.  Each class will be focused around a group of questions with a common topic: logic, information, number theory, probability, and algorithms.
notes: Taught by members of the department

best_comment: I think you should take this class if you are interested in game theory and have a project idea in mind. Martin is the goat of this field and is a great lecturer so it is very enjoyable. I think the lectures themselves are kind of scattered and often unrelated to specifics. Its really a project course kind of like a sandbox to try some research/project.
worse_comment: Future students should be aware that this course is extremely unstructured, with minimal guidance, few assignments, and very limited instructor involvement. There are no weekly problem sets, and lectures often end early. Grades are based largely on a final project and class participation, with very little substantive feedback provided. If you are looking for a rigorous, supportive environment to deeply learn evolutionary dynamics, you may find this course disappointing. If you are looking for a low–intensity course requiring minimal ongoing work, it may meet your expectations.
description: Research seminar on evolutionary dynamics, spanning mathematical and computational models of evolution in biological and social systems. Students attend a weekly lecture and conduct an original research project.

best_comment: It is super helpful to have an excellent grasp on scientific literature prior to beginning this course. There are a lot of assigned readings and they can get lengthy and complex, so having a general understanding of the layout and rhythm of scientific papers beforehand will allow for more efficient learning. Also, pay attention to what the professor highlights about each reading in the weekly email. The themes he emphasizes often appear on the quizzes, worth a large portion of your final grade. That being said, as long as you read each reading in full and understand their implications, you will do well on the quizzes. There are no tricks.
description: This course serves as an introduction to the behavioral pharmacology of psychoactive drugs (e.g., stimulants, cannabinoids, opioids, psychedelics, anxiolytics, antipsychotics).  It is organized in a seminar format with emphasis on behavioral methodology (i.e., model and assay development) and pharmacological analysis (i.e., receptor selectivity and efficacy).  Special attention is paid to the behavioral processes involved in tolerance, drug dependence, addiction, and treatment.

course_title_2025: Principles of Drug Action in People 001
best_comment: Take this class!!! The first few weeks are a bit rough because you're focused on the fundamentals of small molecules (Kd, experimental assays, etc), but the class really builds into an amazing survey of key high need areas in drug discovery. The speakers are super cool, and most are willing to chat with you after class or go for a coffee. I wish I had taken this class earlier!
worse_comment: This class has the potential to be very good and some lectures are very interesting and well delivered. However, most lecturers are not effective and the course itself is very poorly run. At the time of writing this, only 1 of 3 problem sets have been graded. We also received only 5 days warning to prepare a final (group) presentation during the last week of class. I would not recommend taking this class unless you have to.
course_title_2026: Principles of Drug Action in People
description: This course will discuss principles of early drug discovery, drug modalities, and drug pharmacology. In the first part of the course, fundamental aspects of receptor and enzyme targeting agents, drug mechanism, drug metabolism, pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics will be described. Selected examples of small molecule drugs, biologics, gene and cell therapies will be utilized through the course. In the second part of the course, the pharmacology of therapeutics that act on selected human physiological systems, specifically the cardiovascular, immunologic, and central nervous systems, will be covered. The course will include frontier lectures delivered by experts at Harvard and in the Biopharmaceutics industry. A range of speakers enlisted from the Harvard faculty and pharmaceutical scientists will participate in teaching throughout this course.
notes: Please note that all sessions will be held in person. All course materials including lecturers PowerPoint presentations will be posted on the course website. Attendance to all in class activities, discussions and journal clubs is mandatory, not attending these without an excused absence can lead to an incomplete grade for the course.

course_title_2025: Principles of Drug Action in People 001
best_comment: Take this class!!! The first few weeks are a bit rough because you're focused on the fundamentals of small molecules (Kd, experimental assays, etc), but the class really builds into an amazing survey of key high need areas in drug discovery. The speakers are super cool, and most are willing to chat with you after class or go for a coffee. I wish I had taken this class earlier!

notes: Please note that all sessions will be held in person. All course materials including lecturers PowerPoint presentations will be posted on the course website. course_title_2025: Biophysical and Biochemical Mechanisms of Protein Function 001
best_comment: I would say that if you are interested in performing biophysical studies in the future this course acts a good primer to introduce you to concepts and topics in that field.
course_title_2026: Biophysical and Biochemical Mechanisms of Protein Function
description: Biophysical and Biochemical Mechanisms of Protein Function focuses on the molecular mechanisms that underlie essential biochemical processes such as signal transduction.  Major topics include biochemical thermodynamics and conformational equilibria, protein structure and folding, receptor pharmacology, allostery, and enzymatic mechanisms of signaling.  The course includes both content lectures and research frontiers seminars focused on current research in biochemistry with an emphasis on signal transduction in therapeutically relevant pathways.

course_title_2025: Biophysical and Biochemical Mechanisms of Protein Function 001
best_comment: I would say that if you are interested in performing biophysical studies in the future this course acts a good primer to introduce you to concepts and topics in that field.
course_title_2026: Biophysical and Biochemical Mechanisms of Protein Function
description: Biophysical and Biochemical Mechanisms of Protein Function focuses on the molecular mechanisms that underlie essential biochemical processes such as signal transduction.  Major topics include biochemical thermodynamics and conformational equilibria, protein structure and folding, receptor pharmacology, allostery, and enzymatic mechanisms of signaling.  The course includes both content lectures and research frontiers seminars focused on current research in biochemistry with an emphasis on signal transduction in therapeutically relevant pathways.

best_comment: I would say that if you are interested in performing biophysical studies in the future this course acts a good primer to introduce you to concepts and topics in that field.

best_comment: Definitely do not take this course unless you are IN LOVE with developmental biology. It is a lot of work and not a good learning experience.
description: This class is evenly divided between lectures and conference sessions which cover the principals that guide vertebrate development and stem cell maintenance in various renewing tissues; in addition, we discuss how these principals can be leveraged to generate cells/tissues for regenerative biology or disease modeling in vitro. Specific topics include a molecular dissection of  the signaling pathways, gene regulatory networks, and epigenetic mechanisms that control primary axis formation and regional specification, establishment of cell fate, homeotic genes and patterning, cell migration and cell-cell signaling, organoid models of nervous system development and their application, axon development and regeneration, neuromuscular development and mechanistic insights for human birth defects, skeletal muscle stem cells in aging and disease, morphogenesis of branched tubular systems, vasculogenesis, biomechanical regulation of developmental processes, skeletal patterning and development, stem cell maintenance in various renewing tissues, germ cells and pluripotency, and directed differentiation of ES and iPS cells for regeneration and disease modeling.  We will discuss how state of the art technologies in iPS organoids, cell lineage labeling, genetic manipulation, and genome wide epigenomic/transcriptomic analyses can be employed to study organ development, stem cells and regeneration.    Students employ the knowledge gained by lectures and conference sessions to identify interesting new research goals in either vertebrate development, stem cell, or regenerative biology and present research proposals to achieve these goals. Thus, the goals of this course are for students to both learn about the molecular tool-kit that evolution has endowed to vertebrates (and other multicellular animals) AND to learn how to synthesize the literature to come up with their own novel research ideas, and develop a strategy to investigate their hypotheses.
notes: This course is offered as CELLBIO207 and also as DRB207. Includes lectures and conference sessions in which original literature is discussed in depth. A short research proposal is required in lieu of exams.

best_comment: Definitely do not take this course unless you are IN LOVE with developmental biology. It is a lot of work and not a good learning experience.

description: This class is evenly divided between lectures and conference sessions which cover the principals that guide vertebrate development and stem cell maintenance in various renewing tissues; in addition, we discuss how these principals can be leveraged to generate cells/tissues for regenerative biology or disease modeling in vitro. Specific topics include a molecular dissection of  the signaling pathways, gene regulatory networks, and epigenetic mechanisms that control primary axis formation and regional specification, establishment of cell fate, homeotic genes and patterning, cell migration and cell-cell signaling, organoid models of nervous system development and their application, axon development and regeneration, neuromuscular development and mechanistic insights for human birth defects, skeletal muscle stem cells in aging and disease, morphogenesis of branched tubular systems, vasculogenesis, biomechanical regulation of developmental processes, skeletal patterning and development, stem cell maintenance in various renewing tissues, germ cells and pluripotency, and directed differentiation of ES and iPS cells for regeneration and disease modeling.  We will discuss how state of the art technologies in iPS organoids, cell lineage labeling, genetic manipulation, and genome wide epigenomic/transcriptomic analyses can be employed to study organ development, stem cells and regeneration.    Students employ the knowledge gained by lectures and conference sessions to identify interesting new research goals in either vertebrate development, stem cell, or regenerative biology and present research proposals to achieve these goals. Thus, the goals of this course are for students to both learn about the molecular tool-kit that evolution has endowed to vertebrates (and other multicellular animals) AND to learn how to synthesize the literature to come up with their own novel research ideas, and develop a strategy to investigate their hypotheses.
notes: This course is offered as CELLBIO207 and also as DRB207. Includes lectures and conference sessions in which original literature is discussed in depth. A short research proposal is required in lieu of exams.

best_comment: Definitely do not take this course unless you are IN LOVE with developmental biology. It is a lot of work and not a good learning experience.

Specific topics include a molecular dissection of  the signaling pathways, gene regulatory networks, and epigenetic mechanisms that control primary axis formation and regional specification, establishment of cell fate, homeotic genes and patterning, cell migration and cell-cell signaling, organoid models of nervous system development and their application, axon development and regeneration, neuromuscular development and mechanistic insights for human birth defects, skeletal muscle stem cells in aging and disease, morphogenesis of branched tubular systems, vasculogenesis, biomechanical regulation of developmental processes, skeletal patterning and development, stem cell maintenance in various renewing tissues, germ cells and pluripotency, and directed differentiation of ES and iPS cells for regeneration and disease modeling.  We will discuss how state of the art technologies in iPS organoids, cell lineage labeling, genetic manipulation, and genome wide epigenomic/transcriptomic analyses can be employed to study organ development, stem cells and regeneration.    Students employ the knowledge gained by lectures and conference sessions to identify interesting new research goals in either vertebrate development, stem cell, or regenerative biology and present research proposals to achieve these goals. Thus, the goals of this course are for students to both learn about the molecular tool-kit that evolution has endowed to vertebrates (and other multicellular animals) AND to learn how to synthesize the literature to come up with their own novel research ideas, and develop a strategy to investigate their hypotheses.
notes: This course is offered as CELLBIO207 and also as DRB207. Includes lectures and conference sessions in which original literature is discussed in depth. A short research proposal is required in lieu of exams.

best_comment: This class is great for "big idea" scientists, who want to know how disease impacts the body and what that looks like. It provides a great launching pad to new questions. I was able to get something out of every class, even those of topics I wouldn't originally think I'd be interested in.  The course directors really care for the course and our learning, and it has been one of my favorite classes so far.
worse_comment: Excellent course on pathology! Hands–on labs expose you to interpreting gross specimens and stained slides. A different guest lecturer speaks every course. Minimal workload with three problem sets and a short final presentation on a topic of your choice. The course largely follows case studies from the perspective of a pathologist trying to diagnose a patient and provide a treatment plan.
description: This course provides a comprehensive overview of human pathology with emphasis on mechanisms of disease and modern diagnostic technologies. Topics include (1) general mechanisms of disease (inflammation, infection, immune injury, host response to foreign materials, transplantation, genetic disorders and neoplasia), (2) pathology of major organ systems, and (3) review of diagnostic tools from invasive surgical pathology to non-invasive techniques such as diagnostic imaging and molecular pathology. The objectives of this course are achieved through a set of integrated lectures and laboratories, as well as a student-driven term project leading to a formal presentation on a medical, socioeconomic, or technological issue in human pathology.
notes: Enrollment may be limited.

best_comment: I would recommend this class if you are interested in delving into the clinical side of immunological research.
worse_comment: The course is very cancer immunology heavy
description: IMMUN 202 builds on IMMUN 201 and explores fundamental principles of immunology in the context of immune and inflammatory diseases. Through a series of lectures and discussion, students will survey a broad range of diseases in which the immune system is essential. Topics will include not only diseases that mobilize classical immunity but also conditions to which we now know the immune systems contributes. Students will use oral (paper discussions) and written exercises (problem sets) to learn how to critically evaluate and synthesize major concepts and tools essential for the study of immunology.

best_comment: This class doesn't have too many assignments from week to week with just a paper discussion every week. I think this is a class that you get what you put in. If you engage with the readings and lecturers, you'll be able to come away with a lot of cool insights into the immunology research done in the Harvard community. There is just one major assignment which is a grant–style specific aims page due at the end of the semester. This can feel a bit unapproachable if you don't have any experience with writing grants. I would start early so you can start brainstorming ideas and reading papers. You'll need to do a lot more reading than you think to land on a topic – if you found a lecture particularly interesting that is a good place to start. Do not hesitate to reach out to the course director if you need more direction.
description: Semester long course, intended for graduate students at Harvard and MIT, jointly taught by Harvard and MIT faculty members at the Ragon Institute of MGH, MIT, and Harvard.

Original research articles from fields including immunology, biochemistry, genetics, and cell and developmental biology will be critically analyzed in an intensive small group format. Grading will be based on class participation and oral presentations.
notes: Required for first-year immunology students, open to second-year immunology students. No auditors.

course_title_2025: Neuroimmune interactions in health and disease 001
best_comment: This is a fantastic course! Each class session starts with a lecture by a different guest speaker professor and then concludes with a paper presentation/discussion. The lectures by the guest speakers are all really interesting and each cover a different area of neuroimmune interactions in health and disease, together providing a varied and broad look into this area. The paper presentations are also interesting for reading in detail about particular examples of studies in the areas described in the lectures. Overall this course was very interesting and informative. Definitely a great course to take if you are interested in neuroimmune interactions in health and disease!
worse_comment: This class is an interesting overview for a few key takeaway points, but it is more of a seminar series than a rigorous course with expected high understanding of foundational concepts.
course_title_2026: Neuroimmune interactions in health and disease
description: Bidirectional communication between the nervous system and the immune system plays a significant role in homeostasis and disease. Neurons and immune cells crosstalk within the central nervous system and in peripheral tissues, mediating homeostasis, barrier protection, and host defense. This course will investigate current topics in neuro-immunology such as: Neuron-glia interactions, CNS development, microglia, brain border tissues, pain, neurodegeneration, cytokines and behavior, autoimmunity, and host defense. Dysregulation in neuroimmune communication underlies both neurological and immunological diseases. Guest lecturers will give seminars on each topic in neuroimmunology, followed by class discussion on papers in the field.
notes: Each class will cover a specific topic in neuro-immunology. Students should be prepared to lead discussions on pre-selected papers for each session.

course_title_2025: Microbial Sciences: Chemistry, Ecology and Evolution 001
best_comment: This course is not very easy to come to for most undergrads, except for those few who have taken OEB or microbiology classes before. There's a lot of new information to absorb each week, as the course is structured to have a different guest lecturer with a different expertise each week.  Also, you are expected to participate at least 2x a class (they count by ticking your name off next to your photo in the course roster), which is very hard to do if you are just learning things for the first time in the class. Weekly, you are expected to read two (usually dense/difficult) papers, and answer participation questions on them. One time during the semester, you are to present a paper to the class, a journal club of sorts. The semester paper is a research proposal focused in microbiology, but you have plenty of time to work on that and get plenty of feedback. Overall, I would recommend this course but would definitely suggest being mindful of how confident or willing you feel in wanting to learn so much on your own each week!
course_title_2026: Microbial Sciences: Chemistry, Ecology and Evolution
description: This is an interdisciplinary graduate-level and advanced undergraduate-level course in which students explore topics in molecular microbiology, microbial diversity, host-microbe associations in health and disease, and microbially-mediated geochemistry in depth. This course will be taught by faculty from the Microbial Sciences Initiative. Topics include the origins of life, biogeochemical cycles, microbial diversity, and ecology.
notes: Offered as OEB 290 and MICROBI 210

course_title_2025: Microbial Sciences: Chemistry, Ecology and Evolution 001
best_comment: This class was really fun and a good way to spend my Friday mornings. We read some really interesting papers and the rotating weekly speaker setup gave us the opportunity to hear from so many amazing microbiologists/adjacent–scientists.
course_title_2026: Microbial Sciences: Chemistry, Ecology and Evolution
description: This is an interdisciplinary graduate-level and advanced undergraduate-level course in which students explore topics in molecular microbiology, microbial diversity, host-microbe associations in health and disease, and microbially-mediated geochemistry in depth. This course will be taught by faculty from the Microbial Sciences Initiative. Topics include the origins of life, biogeochemical cycles, microbial diversity, and ecology.
notes: Offered as OEB 290 and MICROBI 210

course_title_2025: Microbial Sciences: Chemistry, Ecology and Evolution 001

course_title_2026: Microbial Sciences: Chemistry, Ecology and Evolution

best_comment: Be open minded, participate in class discussions, and bring enthusiasm to every class. You get out of this course what you put into it, and there is a great opportunity to grow in your knowledge and preparation to tackle your own project if you invest time early on into learning the basics and more importantly, figuring out who you can ask for help and advice if the basics escape you or if you want to try something new.
worse_comment: It’s gonna be hard and long, but it will payoff
description: This course will endow students with the broad conceptual fluency in the discipline of neuroscience required to relate genes to circuit function, metabolism to neurological disease, and cell biology to neural computations. Through a combination of lectures and discussions, students will learn to design, quantitatively analyze, and interpret experiments that address a variety of questions spanning molecular to systems neuroscience. During the first semester (NB215A), students will think critically about the fundamental units of the nervous system within the context of cellular function, electrical conduction, and chemical signaling. The second half of the course (NB215B) builds upon this foundation to focus on broadly defined “networks of neural function” as related to coordinated neural activity, the concerted execution of genetic programs, and anatomically defined structural networks. The course culminates with students writing a grant proposal in the style of the NIH NRSA.
notes: Full year course. Students may not enroll for the second semester unless they have completed the first semester; however, students may elect to take just the first semester. Please note that Program in Neuroscience (PiN) students must take both semesters to fulfill the requirement.
course_requirements: Must complete NEUROBIO 215A

best_comment: Proposal writing is a fun opportunity to explore a fun topic, take advantage to think about ideas early on!
description: The course focuses on the following areas of virology: (i) RNA and DNA virus replication mechanisms, (ii) innate responses to viral infection (iii) adaptive immune responses to viral infection, (iv) viral latency and reactivation, (v) inhibition of viral infection. The course will comprise lectures as well as reviewing literature that describes fundamental breakthroughs relevant to these areas. Within those areas, the class will read and discuss papers dealing with virus structure, replication, pathogenesis, evolution, emerging viruses, chronic infection, innate and adaptive immunity, anti-viral drugs/vaccines. Special emphasis will be placed on preparing students to critically evaluate the literature, formulate hypotheses and design experiments.
notes: Course format will be lectures, literature-based critical reading and discussion. Prepare and defend a written research proposal.

course_title_2025: Poverty, Wealth, and Religion in the Middle Ages 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!! COULD NOT RECOMMEND MORE!!1) Prof. FitzGerald is so kind, and his knowledge on the subject is so incredibly deep. Each class we would pepper him with random questions on the middle ages, and he always had an informed answer 2) the material is super interesting, I KNOW IT SEEMS NICHE, but I feel like I have a totally new understanding of not only the Catholic church but religious history in general and how it interacted with the economy. You could almost call this course "The Economy and Religion in the Middle Ages" because you learn so much about how money and religion were intertwined. 3) It expanded by world view in a huge way...I am not religious at all, but many of my classmates were, and I think I grew a lot as a person and students listening and engaging with students who have very different approaches to the world than I do 4) You should expect to do 85%+ of the reading, but if you're someone who enjoys seminar courses, this is a great class for you. The entire time is spent debating topics related to the readings, and I think Prof. FitzGerald does an amazing job facilitating interesting discussion5) Prof. FitzGerald is SUPER supportive and engaging and interested, and I feel very lucky to have gotten to take a course with himTLDR: take this course, i know it seems random, but it is so interesting and I promise you will not regret it
course_title_2026: Poverty, Wealth, and Religion in the Middle Ages
description: This seminar considers the ethical, political, and spiritual questions arising from the existence of wealth and poverty, the rich and the poor, in medieval European culture. What was the relationship between Christian charity and economic activity in the Middle Ages? How did the religious values of a simple, austere life inform or conflict with changes in both Church and society? Drawing on saints’ lives, theological treatises, art and architecture, and the work of authors such as Augustine, Aquinas, Thomas More, and Martin Luther, the course will examine how the interaction of spiritual ideals and material realities shaped cultural developments and affected beliefs and practices from late antiquity to the Protestant Reformation.

course_title_2025: Neuroscience of Music: Clinical Applications across the Lifespan 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!! First and foremost, Dr. Maria Pranjic is just the most wonderful teacher: she is so incredibly versed in neuroscience of course, but as a musician herself she brings a unique and holistic perspective to this course (which has made it such an incredible experience).  She is kind and cultivates community, as well as making sure class runs efficiently and seriously – I have gone from essentially a neuroscience beginner to generating multiple projects and a final paper within one semester because of her investment in my learning. Secondly, this topic is so very important, and Harvard having this discipline (music/arts/creativity and the brain) as a course in the MBB department is absolutely essential. Come prepared to work hard and you will reap the benefits of this amazing course! I sincerely hope the MBB department will continue adding and supporting more courses like this one (for everyone's sake, but selfishly so I can take them too!) :)
course_title_2026: Neuroscience of Music: Clinical Applications across the Lifespan
description: With the advent of modern neuroimaging technology, there has been a rapid expansion of neuroscientific research on music and its biomedical applications. The burgeoning field of music neuroscience investigates how the brain perceives, processes, and responds to musical stimuli, and how musical training and music-based interventions influence brain and behavior across the lifespan. This course will delve into the state-of-the-art research in both basic and clinical auditory neuroscience. Students will learn about brain plasticity associated with musical training and the therapeutic potential of music in clinical contexts, ranging from neurodevelopmental to neurodegenerative conditions. The course will be interdisciplinary, blending research from psychology, cognitive neuroscience, and medicine. The class will also take a trip to Dr. Arnett’s laboratory at Boston Children’s Hospital to see a demonstration of how electroencephalography (EEG) is used to measure brain activity during auditory-perceptual paradigms in children. By the end of the course, students will have developed critical thinking skills and the ability to evaluate scientific findings related to the therapeutic applications of music. They will gain a deeper understanding of experimental methods and the contentious theoretical issues and debates in music neuroscience and therapy. These topics will be explored through a mix of student- and faculty-led presentations, written critiques, and class discussions.

best_comment: This was one of the most interesting courses I’ve taken at Harvard! Dr. Milberg is a true expert in neuroscience, and his personal experience with some of the patients discussed in class makes the lectures especially engaging. The second half of the course (where students present on landmark cases) is particularly fascinating. You gain a much deeper understanding of patients you may have only briefly encountered in introductory psychology courses.That said, the first portion of the course could benefit from a bit more structure and clarity. I understand it’s challenging to condense an entire neuroscience curriculum into just a few weeks, but it might help to focus primarily on the most essential concepts (such as brain areas and their functions) that are necessary for understanding the cases. Providing more visual materials (maybe through slides or supplemental readings) would also be helpful, especially since students come into this course with varying levels of background. Lastly, a short 5–10 minute break during the two–hour lectures would go a long way since maintaining focus through dense material can be quite tough.Overall, it’s an excellent, low–workload class led by a fantastic professor!
best_gem_comment: Take this class for sure if you’re thinking about doing a MBB secondary (or concentration). It’s definitely a gem. Professor Milberg is great, full of knowledge, and super chill. Loved it!
description: This course seeks to reconcile the complicated and messy problems of patients with brain disease with the concise analysis of precisely defined cognitive functions in normal subjects. Students will learn to overlap cognitive functions on to the brain in disease - at the gross dissection and imaging levels - and to understand some of the complex interactions of individual cognitive operations in disease using the examples of famous landmark cases in the literature (e.g.Broca’s Monsieur Leborgne, Phineas Gage, HM and others). The course will include a dissection of a human brain, an examination of how the actual brain maps onto two dimensional neuroimages, and discussions of how the classic lesion based maps of cortical function are related to contemporary maps based on functional neuroimaging.

course_title_2025: Functional Neuroimaging of Psychiatric Disorders: Insights into the Human Brain-Mind 001
best_comment: Amazing class with great discussions! You will learn about what neuropsychiatry itself is, and the current advances in the field as well as the history of how this field emerged. Be prepared to share your thoughts on the readings.
course_title_2026: Functional Neuroimaging of Psychiatric Disorders: Insights into the Human Brain-Mind
description: Functional brain imaging has revolutionized the study of systems-level behavioral neuroscience and psychiatric disorders, through the ability to localize and characterize distributed brain activity directly associated with perception, cognition, emotion and behavior in disorders where there are not gross brain lesions.  This seminar will introduce students to translational neuroimaging methods at the interface of neuroscience, psychology and medicine.  It will cover recent and ongoing advances in our understanding of fronto-limbic-subcortical brain circuitry across the range of psychiatric disorders (e.g. mood disorders, anxiety disorders, psychotic disorders, personality disorders, addictions).  It will discuss new, emerging biological (as opposed to descriptive) taxonomies and conceptualizations of mental illness and its treatment.  It will explore the implications of such knowledge for issues such as consciousness, meaning, free will, emotion, resilience, and religiosity.  It will incorporate clinical observations, scientific data and readings, and examine future directions in brain-mind medicine.

course_title_2025: Translational Neuroscience: Limits of Adaptation from Extreme Environments to Clinical Practice 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE! It is incredible if you love space, space medicine, and/or astronomy. Also, if you like emergency medicine or any thing else extreme, this course will cover it!
course_title_2026: Brain and Behavior in Extreme Environments: Space Exploration, Sports, and Clinical Applications
description: What can we learn about the limitations of human neurobehavioral function through exposure and adaptation to extreme environments, as well as readaptation to “normal” environment, or onset of neuropsychiatric disorders? Within the translational neuroscience paradigm, this course explores the concepts of neurobehavioral adaptation, stress, resilience, and neuropsychiatric disorders, in relation to the underlying neurophysiologic mechanisms that regulate them. We will explore adaptations to extreme activities such as spaceflight, expeditionary (polar, underwater, desert exploration, military deployments), emergency response services (e.g. firefighting), and impact sports (e.g. football). These will be discussed in the context of mental and occupational health, gender differences, and understanding the etiology of neuropsychiatric conditions such as, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), traumatic brain injury (TBI), Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE), intracranial hypertension, etc. This course may be particularly interesting to Mind Brain and Behavior students pursuing careers in translational neuroscience, psychology, medicine, and related fields. features expert guest lecturers (e.g. NASA researchers, Antarctic expeditionary physicians, underwater explorers, etc.), demonstrations of unique experimental methodologies and equipment (e.g. ambulatory brain and physiologic monitoring) used in extreme environments, and potential visits to field / operational facilities.

course_title_2025: Translational Neuroscience: Limits of Adaptation from Extreme Environments to Clinical Practice 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE! It is incredible if you love space, space medicine, and/or astronomy. Also, if you like emergency medicine or any thing else extreme, this course will cover it!
course_title_2026: Brain and Behavior in Extreme Environments: Space Exploration, Sports, and Clinical Applications
