course_title_2025: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Genetics, Genomics, and Evolution 001
best_comment: Ls1b is pretty solid! It is a bit of a travesty that Andrew Berry will no longer be teaching the course, as he kind of made it what it was. But honestly, I personally thought the class was deeply interesting, and a lot less rigorous than Ls1a, but I am also not a pre–med like I am sure a large portion of the readers of this Q–report are, so I may not be the right person to ask. You absolutely do not need to have taken Ls1a to do well in this class –– LPSA (or neither!!!) is totally fine, as not much background is really needed for the course. But a background in Ls1a definitely does help for the first 6 or so lectures. I found the class to be nowhere as conceptually challenging as Ls1a, but still deeply interesting. Most importantly, to me at least –– if you are not good at focusing on the lectures, it is sorta fine, because they kinda are hard to listen to and focus in on for the whole time. And it is really fine overall ––– Section has incredible reviews of the learned content, there are like a million office hours, and they always post the lecture slides and deeply, deeply useful lecture notes THAT I STRONGLY RECOMMEND YOU USE TO STUDY FOR PIES!!! The pies also were honestly not too bad, and I think it was super helpful to have those smaller tests that helped you review and ultimately made sure you aren't totally cooked for the final. Overall, take Ls1b! I think its pretty solid and is super interesting if you are into genetics, ecology, and/or evolution.
worse_comment: This is nothing like LS1a. SO expect a lot of new things that disguise as familiar things like the PIES. You have to be very very quick with the time, there is not enough time on the exam, infact a lot of people did not finish the final as well. A lot of information dump is done in every lecture ––– the most helpful resource is reading the lecture notes! They are insanely helpful and saved me. ANother resource I recommend for studying that helps for PIEs is the Lowdown videos as well as Practice Problems. The main problem with the course is that the exams are nothing like the psets, I was great with the psets but on the exams, I struggled! The only way to get a sense of what type of questions the pies would have is practice problems. Make sure you don't fall behind on information, try to pay attention! Labs are a little unhelpful cause they dont have a lot of problems on section worksheet. ALSO, if you ahve heard ls1b has insane cutoffs for an A like 96, i assure you, it does not. tl;dr : Start for PIEs early like actually early. Keep working, keep on track, read the lecture notes and do the practice problems, go quickly through the pie and the exam, expect exams to much longer than the practice ones.
course_title_2026: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Genetics, Genomics, and Evolution
instructors: Terence Capellini, Janet Song, Robin Hopkins, Monica Boselli, Maria Ostapovich
description: How are observable characteristics of organisms influenced by genetics? How do genomes change over time to produce the differences we see among species? This course takes an integrated approach, showing how genetics and evolution are intimately related, together explaining the patterns of genetic variation we see in nature, and how genomics can be used to analyze variation. In covering Mendelian genetics, quantitative genetics, and population genetics, this course will emphasize developments involving our own species.
notes: This course, in combination with Life Sciences 1a, constitutes an integrated introduction to the Life Sciences.

course_title_2025: Experimental Research in the Life Sciences 001
best_comment: This class is amazing and fulfills research requirements for MCB, etc. It is structured as once a week whole group meetings, with the rest of the class operating through planning  within the research groups. You get to work around your group's own availability and delegate your work (and how much time you need to spend in the lab to complete your experiments) on your own and it's great. Please do not take this course if you are going to not participate in your group, because your grade really is just dependent on showing up, learning, and a final grant proposal paper. You will not get an A if you cannot even do that and show up, plus it drags your team down! Overall, very light load, and very great introduction to research. My TF was lovely and is a very accomplished researcher, and Alain is also a sweetheart and very passionate about his students. the projects were very interesting and I learned so much about lab work, given I had zero lab exposure prior. Must take!!
course_title_2026: Experimental Research in the Life Sciences
description: A laboratory course that immerses students in a dynamic project-based research environment. Participate in experimental projects directly linked with ongoing faculty research. Students select a project from the following research tracks: neurobiology, microbial sciences, cell biology, and synthetic biology. New projects, including some in other research fields, are offered every term. In a highly collaborative atmosphere, students form a fully-functional and diverse research group based on the sharing of ideas and progress reports between projects. The spring microbiology project is part of the "genomes to Biomes" series. This course cannot be taken concurrently with LifeSci 100.
notes: Location of the first meeting will be announced on the course website. Open to freshmen, sophomores, juniors, and seniors, regardless of concentration, and suitable for students either with or without extensive laboratory experience. The course may only be repeated once and the second enrollment must be approved by the instructor.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: LPS A OR LS 1a

best_comment: To future students taking FAS–MCB 68, be prepared for a challenging but rewarding experience. The course provides a great balance of theory and hands–on learning, especially through the lab sessions where you’ll work with advanced microscopy tools like confocal and fluorescence microscopes. These tools are key to understanding cell biology at a deeper level, so make the most of your time in the lab. Stay engaged with the material, ask questions when you’re unsure, and take advantage of office hours and peer discussions. The course is fast–paced, but it’s also a fantastic opportunity to develop skills that are essential for future research. Don’t be afraid to troubleshoot and experiment—it’s all part of the learning process!
instructors: Ethan Garner, Douglas Richardson, Emma Nagy
description: MCB 68 explores three fundamental fields of eukaryotic cell biology: chromosome segregation, cell motility, and neuroscience. Each topic is approached from a historic and technical perspective. Students will discover these systems as the scientific field did, learning how each successive advance in microscopy revealed new biological details. Students will come away with a theoretical and hands-on understanding of microscopy as well as a grasp of the biological findings each technology revealed.
notes: An additional introductory course in biology (e.g., MCB 60, MCB 80 or SCRB10) is recommended but not required. The course design, level, and content is best suited for students in their sophomore year.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: LS 1a OR LPS A

course_title_2025: Experimental Research in the Life Sciences 001
best_comment: This class is amazing and fulfills research requirements for MCB, etc. It is structured as once a week whole group meetings, with the rest of the class operating through planning  within the research groups. You get to work around your group's own availability and delegate your work (and how much time you need to spend in the lab to complete your experiments) on your own and it's great. Please do not take this course if you are going to not participate in your group, because your grade really is just dependent on showing up, learning, and a final grant proposal paper. You will not get an A if you cannot even do that and show up, plus it drags your team down! Overall, very light load, and very great introduction to research. My TF was lovely and is a very accomplished researcher, and Alain is also a sweetheart and very passionate about his students. the projects were very interesting and I learned so much about lab work, given I had zero lab exposure prior. Must take!!
course_title_2026: Experimental Research in the Life Sciences
description: A laboratory course that immerses students in a dynamic project-based research environment. Participate in experimental projects directly linked with ongoing faculty research. Students select a project from the following research tracks: neurobiology, microbial sciences, cell biology, and synthetic biology. New projects, including some in other research fields, are offered every term. In a highly collaborative atmosphere, students form a fully-functional and diverse research group based on the sharing of ideas and progress reports between projects. The spring microbiology project is part of the "genomes to Biomes" series. This course cannot be taken concurrently with LifeSci 100.
notes: Location of the first meeting will be announced on the course website. Open to freshmen, sophomores, juniors, and seniors, regardless of concentration, and suitable for students either with or without extensive laboratory experience. The course may only be repeated once and the second enrollment must be approved by the instructor.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: LPS A OR LS 1a

course_title_2025: Creativity, Innovation, and Entrepreneurship in the Life Sciences 001
best_comment: *******Alain is an incredibly lovely person and the speakers he brought in every week were truly very helpful and insightful about venturing into biotech and all the different ways in doing so. I highly highly recommend  this class if you are interested in biotech and want dedicated time to listen to speakers, create a project, and have the support of a very lovely professor in doing so and understanding if this is for you.
course_title_2026: Creativity, Innovation, and Entrepreneurship in the Life Sciences
description: The liberal arts were initially meant to express the broadest swath of human thought and experience. Yet, somehow, the workplace's skills and habits of mind gradually separated from this curriculum. This left students to tackle each domain in sequence: first, the liberal arts and then workplace skills. This unnecessary sequencing has contributed to the so-called skills gap. The course will aim to fill this gap. You will learn to identify life sciences problems, develop essential skills in innovation, creativity, and entrepreneurship, and apply them to life science challenges of your choice. The course will emphasize the development of actionable proposals by students that address current challenges and create social and economic value for society. This course will use activity-based learning, guest speakers, and a group of life sciences and business experts providing students with bespoke mentoring. Throughout the term, you will interact with students within the Harvard innovation community, including members of the Lemann Program in Creativity and Entrepreneurship (LPCE) and the Harvard HealthLab accelerator (H2A). At the end of the term, you will present your projects to your peers and mentors at the LPCE’s Founder Crush event.

course_title_2025: The pharmacy of life – exploring the function and biochemistry of natural products 001
best_comment: All the feedback being given must be taken with a grain of salt because the TFs and CAs were very aware all throughout of the semester of how much our feedback as first time class takers would influence the course's overall structure. Kudos to them for being very open minded about it and really wanting students to give their feedback. They adjusted PSET length mid–semester which was very fair and they were all overall very open to suggestions even within the course's syllabus. Overall, great teaching coming from Ryan, Hisham, and Jaime.Grading scheme: Loved that there were no exams, making the class very enjoyable and light. Especially if you want to explore something so nuanced and difficult like natural products, not having exams was great. The part about graded on effort I thought was a bit inconsistent with some of the grades I had friends getting given we did the PSETs together and put in the same effort. I think you have to be very clear if it is graded on effort or correctness and if its by effort, have very good feedback so that student understands they got the point for doing the question but have room to understand where they can grow. Also grading highly varied among CAs which is always difficult to understand and unfair, so finding a way to make that more standard is essential, especially if taking the effort–based route because then it just doesn't make sense if the same effort was placed on all PSETs that they wouldn't receive the similar grades.PSETs: The exposure to Pymol and Alphafold is super fun and those PSETs were very enjoyable, whereas the others just seemed very long and tedious. I feel like there are better ways of engaging with the course content than those 10 page PSETS. They did slowly change this up during the semester and condensed into more thought out questions which was great (perhaps just not the last PSET that had 20 pages and most people just dropped it especially because of final project presentations and other finals). I honestly think having more Pymol and Alphafold PSETs would've been a super enjoyable route and very rewarding too building those skills nowadays. Lectures: They leaned much more towards chemistry than bio which would make sense given it says pharmacy in the name of the course but I expected a perhaps more higher overview of the content on the chem side. A focus on understanding why certain plants are explored, their compound effect on the body, classes of plants to explore, etc was what I expected vs learning about terpenoids etc. I think these kinda do walk hand–in–hand so I'd just add that Chem27 is also a pre–req for the class because then the chem part isn't overwhelming and taking away from the experience, despite not having Chem27 hindering my experience completely.  Some of the first PSETs had questions more focused on the chemistry side that which is what we learned in Chem27 4 weeks later or something.Final Project: Super enjoyable putting into practice everything you learned in class and analyzing something of your choice. Highly recommend taking their early deadlines seriously and really planning out what you want to talk about vs last minute cramming because this is meant to be enjoyable and you understanding how your favorite natural product's mechanism and its 3D structure.
worse_comment: It's a really fun class that covers a lot of natural products and molecules! The psets can be long, but if you get started on them early during section and over the weekend, you can do it. The final presentation is chill and low stress, but you should start early to get feedback and fix anything you need to.
course_title_2026: The pharmacy of life – exploring the function and biochemistry of natural products
description: Life has evolved countless bioactive molecules, or “natural products”, that act like pharmaceuticals to affect the cellular processes of other organisms, and many of these molecules serve as critical medicines and research tools. In this course, we will explore the diverse functions of natural products – including many important medicines like plant-derived chemotherapeutics, fungal psychedelics, and cone snail venoms – as case studies to teach fundamental principles of biochemistry and cell biology. By exploring the diverse pharmacy of natural products that have evolved in nature, we aim to illustrate how specific, molecular level interactions can lead to powerful toxic and medicinal effects on other organisms. Additionally, we will introduce major research techniques that are used to study the biological functions of natural products and discuss the essential role of these techniques for future efforts to discover new drugs from nature. Collectively, this course will provide a cross-disciplinary platform for exploring the molecular and biochemical properties that make natural products a critical component of not just the evolution of species, but also our medicine, culture, and research.

best_comment: To be brutally honest, I had a very mixed experience with this course. I enjoyed reading the papers and learning the content, but the volume just felt overwhelming and consequently took away from the course.  That being said, I have faith that Craig will take our feedback into consideration and will make the course a lot more manageable. Therefore, I strongly recommend this course. The summaries are graded very harshly, but they ultimately did help me improve. The papers, while high in volume, had a great distribution and were super interesting. The presentations, journal clubs, and discussions were all great (though probably could have been reduced to journal clubs and presentations), and I enjoyed preparing for and participating in them.
worse_comment: Take this course if you like a discussion–based cancer biology course. The majority of the semester will be spent reading, discussing, and presenting recent literature. You'll learn quite a bit about cancer mechanisms, factors or events that accelerate/promote tumorigenesis, immunotherapy, personalized therapy, cancer monitoring and tracking, cutting edge technology, etc through these papers. Assignments mainly involve creating scientific summaries and questions for assigned papers and preparing for journal clubs, discussions, and presentations. Overall, it's different from a typical biology course and I quite enjoy taking this course.
description: This is a project and discussion-based course for advanced students to explore the genetic and genomic basis of cancer and the development of cancer therapeutics.  The course is interactive, with an emphasis on critical analysis, discussion, and collaboration. The assignments are structured to encourage both individual and group engagement with the material, ensuring that students develop a comprehensive understanding of the subject matter while honing their communication skills. The readings will focus on seminal discoveries, modern experimental approaches, and break-through treatments.  The learning goals for the students include, how to read the primary literature, how to ask scientific questions, and how to apply the scientific method.

course_title_2025: Interplay between Viruses and their Hosts 001
best_comment: This class is super chill overall–––highly recommend it if you are looking for a manageable upper level MCB course during a busy semester. The weekly workload is just reading a (relatively more complex) research paper and writing a 500–word summary for it. Sometimes it is a bit tricky deciding what to fit into your summary, but it is excellent practice for being concise and getting the broad picture when discussing a complex topic. There are not too many instructions for these assignments, so you have a lot of freedom in terms of how you approach your work. This could be helpful but it can also be confusing exactly what is expected of you. But I would say they are super chill graders, so if you put in decent effort and show you are doing your best to understand and grow, you'll be fine. Besides, you can always reach out with questions and they are usually very fast at answering emails. The quizzes during every class can sound daunting but usually they turn out fine. Just study your materials a bit before class and it shouldn't be a problem. The final presentation at the end of the semester, like all other assignments, were pretty flexible and you are not given that many instructions. So overall, I would just say give all assignments your best effort–––participate in section–––and you will do more than fine. The lack of directions sometimes can feel overwhelming at first, but I think that is supposed to help you and not hurt (or restrict) you too much.  Lastly, the lectures can be very fast–paced and confusing sometimes. The slides could have been more clear and informative for someone who does not know that much about viruses and HIV (the main virus we talk about throughout the semester). A lot of the times, I had to do more research after class to clear up what was discussed during class, but overall, no big problems.
course_title_2026: Interplay between Viruses and their Hosts
description: This course provides a foray into virology, advanced cell biology, biochemistry and structural biology topics through the lens of viruses as they invade their hosts. Lectures first demonstrate concepts by placing a particular emphasis on the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which provides well-studied examples of intricate virus-host interactions that occur throughout its complex life cycle. Discussion sections then solidify these concepts by analysis of primary literature on other viruses, for example SARS-CoV2, Ebola, etc.
course_requirements: Prerequisite: MCB

course_title_2025: Brain Invaders: Building and Breaking Barriers in the Nervous System 001
best_comment: The content was really interesting. I loved the applications and case studies we explored. I definitely learned a lot. The exams can be a little difficult, so make sure to study well for them. It's a ton of memorization, don't wait till last minute. I felt like the write–ups and presentation were graded pretty harshly. There weren't many instructions on the write–ups and the grading was mainly subjective. I didn't like that aspect of the course and wish they were more transparent/had a set standardized rubric. That being said, I really enjoyed the discussion aspect of the course and learning more from my peers about the papers they presented. The studies were really fascinating. I also gained a lot of critical thinking skills and research design/methodology skills (which isn't necessarily a huge emphasis of the course) through reading the papers and critically analyzing them.  I recommend taking this class although it is not a gem or an easy A. Laura and Brendan were great instructors and really helpful!
course_title_2026: Brain Invaders: Building and Breaking Barriers in the Nervous System
description: The brain has evolved a unique but very effective system to protect itself from invaders. In this course, we will explore the specific defenses that the nervous system uses to protect itself. We will also examine how some pathogens evade or breach those defenses and the impact of those invasions. Finally, we will explore how scientists have been able to translate their understanding of these pathogenic mechanisms into technologies for research and therapeutic applications.

course_title_2025: MCO 101: The PhD Journey - Navigating Towards Success 001
worse_comment: Don't recommend
course_title_2026: MCO 101: The PhD Journey - Navigating Towards Success
description: Identifying a scientific question that excites you and effectively communicating your research progress to the community are critical components of a successful graduate experience. This course provides an essential roadmap for first-year MCO graduate students to learn how to present their research questions and articulate their impact in the most effective way. Students will learn how to deliver a 10-minute oral presentation on their research progress by giving three rounds of rotation progress talks in class. Short oral presentations are the most common presentation format that graduate students encounter during their training and at conferences, making this a critical skill to master. In addition, students will learn about the fellowship competition process, including proposal preparation and peer review. They will write a Specific Aims page and participate in peer review by evaluating each other’s drafts. Overall, the course is designed to support MCO students as they prepare for their PhD journey and full research commitment.

best_comment: Background: I took this class as a sophomore who took the LS1 series, MCB 60, and CHEM 17 before this and CHEM 27 concurrently. This class was so fun, but it was pretty hard for me without the LS50 primer in stat mech. I feel like my brain is bigger now than it was at the beginning of the semester. MCB 65 was the class that finally got me to learn the amino acids, structural biology lab techniques, and how to be kind of good at using PyMOL. It did take a lot of work to keep up with everything, but the grading isn't insane if that helps, and they're nice about giving out opportunities for bonus points. LPS assignments (PSETs) are due every ~2 weeks and they're pretty big. I'd recommend getting started with each question as soon as you learn the relevant material so you aren't staying up until 4 the night before they're due. The two midterms and final are tough, but they give you a cheat sheet and a bunch of review material to work with, and I felt like I got the hang of it by the end of the semester. There aren't really free points (even attendance is marked for correctness) but as long as you're willing to commit I think the experience is worth it. The community also rocks. It's a small enough and hard enough class that you kind of have to make friends with everyone else. The lecturers are also so cool. Monique is honestly just incredible I love her so much. Max is good when he's lecturing about things he cares about. The TFs were also super solid, very knowledgable about the material and happy to help. Guest lecturers were hit or miss, but some of the opportunities (tour of a crystallography lab, computational protein design) were super super cool. This is my favorite MCB class I've taken so far. It took full commitment at some points (RIP my CHEM 27 grade) but if I could go back in time I would take it again.
worse_comment: I found the course really difficult. Lab every week is a killer. Thankfully we had the GOAT TF George. Other than that .............. study a lot because there's a lot of material. The LPS assignments are killer and take a long time to complete, 6+ hours at least unless you work with others. They are also pretty strict about following the rules so read the instructions of every assignment carefully
instructors: Monique Brewster, Maxim Prigozhin, Rebecca LaCroix
description: This course develops your understanding of fundamental biochemistry concepts and how they are applied in cutting-edge structural and molecular biology research. You will learn about protein and nucleic acid structure, thermodynamics, kinetics, and intermolecular interactions while exploring techniques like cryo-electron microscopy, AlphaFold protein structure prediction, molecular dynamics, and protein design with Rosetta. The course emphasizes applying these concepts to cell signaling, metabolism and drug-target interactions using interactive lectures.

This is a semester-long course aimed to help you reflect on your teaching goals and practices. The course will cover topics such as: active learning, backward design, student feedback and evaluation, equity and inclusion, disciplinary transparency, and content delivery. The course will meet once a week and is designed to minimize work outside of class time. It is intended for graduate students in the life sciences and adjacent fields.

best_comment: Enjoy :)
description: This course encompasses multiple sections that follow independent paths of study based on the general exam requirements of different degree programs. Students will engage with music from across a wide range of historical and cultural contexts, covering topics such as functional harmony or post-tonality, while also branching into popular and non-Western music-theoretical systems and styles based on student research interests. In assignments, students will learn how to apply analytical tools through close readings of music examples, and they will further forge connections between theory and practice through sight-singing and ear-training activities. Students should consult with the professor at the beginning of the semester to establish which areas of musicianship will be prioritized in their course of study.
course_requirements: Pre-requisite: MUSIC BHFA

course_title_2025: Foundations of Tonal Music I LEC
best_comment: Take this class!! It was lots of fun, and definitely very friendly to beginners. The teaching team is also outstanding for this course. Liam is an excellent lecturer, and my TF Sara was also wonderful. You get the chance to write a few songs in the class, which was honestly such a fun learning experience. The final exam was also very reasonable, and the teaching team provided lots of support and resources leading up to it (although in my opinion the course is already taught extremely well so there was really no need to study much!) I had such a wonderful experience in this class so you should totally consider taking it if you were ever interested in learning more about music!
description: Course description: In Music 2, students will learn the fundamental elements of music and staff notation, learning standard terminology and fundamental techniques through a variety of methods and repertories. We will study the principles of musical organization (within a range of styles and historical periods) by means of composition projects, score analysis, improvisation, and aural skills. We will begin to think critically about larger topics, such as how music communicates emotion, and how this might change between cultures. No prior experience with music performance or with reading notation is required. Who should take this class? This course is best suited for students with little to no background in music, at least in terms of terminology and notation. Students who are already familiar with the fundamentals of music should consider Music 51a.What will I take away from this class? By the end of the course students will have learnt the basics of music terminology and notation, as well as the norms of Western harmony as far as the composition and analysis of simple chord progressions is concerned. Students will also have gained the experience of writing and performing a few simple pieces of their own.
notes: Department of Music courses in music theory will no longer require students to complete a placement exam. Instead, students are instructed to self-place into music theory course(s) that match their abilities and experience levels at the time of course registration. Students should follow the instructions here for more information: https://music.fas.harvard.edu/music-theory-course-placement/

best_comment: This class was really cool! But it was not really what I expected. Chaya is a very modern composer (she has music online you can listen to for a sense); super atonal, and she is all about getting you out of the box. People in our class had really different music backgrounds, and it was so fun seeing what that meant for everyone. This isn't a class that will refine your understanding of super technical aspects of composition, (harmony, voicing, whatever), it's much more about the broad, artistic aspects of what you're writing. Very little direction is given because Chaya and Ali want you to just write what you're going too write, which can be scary or it can be super fun.Anyway take it if you want to just write a lot and take a pretty chill class and hear what other people are writing
description: In this course, students will be engaged with different modalities of creation through composing, listening, and discussing. At times students will become storytellers in sound, at other times, they will try to create meaningful musical phrases by using one tone only. The class offers space for experimentation and provides ways of discoveries and out-of-the-box thinking as one works with sound and sonic ideas. Students will work within their aesthetic preferences while also being challenged to grow by going beyond their comfort zone and imagining new possibilities. The final project will be a class concert.

best_comment: This class is a great way to continue being involved with music at Harvard with peers who probably also did music at a high level before Harvard. The one thing I will say is: do not underestimate the amount of time you have to put into the class. Of course, it is possible to breeze through by barely rehearsing, since the only mandatory thing is a 1 hour weekly coaching (and if your group wants to do this class this way that's totally valid). But after taking this class 4 times, I have realized most groups do actually want to sound good by the final concert, and are pretty serious about rehearsing. For my group, we had regular weekly rehearsals but also extra rehearsals for the performance classes, the final jury, and the final concert, and all that rehearsal time builds up—our group also had extra coaching sessions (so more time again). So ultimately whether this class is a 5th class gem or a pretty substantial class in itself really depends on how serious your group is about sounding good and rehearsing a lot (and note how much your group cares could change DURING the semester). As for the new policy removing pre–formed groups (starting Fall 2025), I understand it may be unpopular—but I agree with the decision. (For context, the status quo is that if you have a pre–formed group, you essentially get into the course automatically, without much consideration to the individual level of the players, and people who applied individually despite essentially being professional–level musicians have gotten rejected due to pre–formed groups having priority). I don't think this is fair, especially for students with professional–level training/performing experience. I think the audition process should be merit–based and not based on social connections and ultimately, whoever is a better musician gets to take the course. Moreover, yes, it is nice to play with your friends, but I think the purpose of a class like this should be personal and musical development. I think playing with people you don’t know—especially ones at a similar level—can actually be a better means to achieve this goal and can challenge you in different and productive ways. Of course, it works when a pre–formed group is compatible, but I believe that the overall pre–forming process often results in several unbalanced groups with players of different levels, resulting in a worse 189 experience for people in these unbalanced groups. I've also seen a fair amount of politicking with the pre–forming process e.g. people trying to “lock in” players early, or abandoning one group for a better one mid–process, which can get messy. I think the staff have a good idea of which players are similar in ability and compatible with others and will ultimately create more balanced groups, resulting in a better overall 189 experience for everyone. The counter of course is that this assumes the staff know better than the students which musicians will be more compatible with each other, which might be difficult in a 10–minute audition. BUT, at least they get to hear everyone directly and assess musical levels side–by–side and for me, that puts them in a better position than students to create balanced, compatible ensembles. Also, stepping back a bit, I don't think the policy is unreasonable—at chamber music festivals the norm is for the organizers/coaches to assign the groups, and in the industry groups are often pieced together last–minute and musicians often have no say in who they play with.Aside from this digression, this is a brilliant course that any classical musician at Harvard should consider taking! The Parker Quartet is amazing and the course is a huge value–add for the overall music environment and music community at Harvard.
worse_comment: It can be great, but be careful about scheduling. It can be really frustrating to deal with schedule total incompatabily.
instructors: Jessica Bodner, Daniel Chong, Kee-Hyun Kim, Ken Hamao
description: Through auditions, students will be divided into chamber music ensembles by the Parker Quartet, and have weekly coachings with members of the Parker Quartet and pianist Mia Chung. The semester will culminate with public performances in Paine Hall. Instrumentalists and vocalists are welcome to audition; however, duos or vocal-only ensembles are not allowed. Students will be expected to rehearse between each coaching and to participate in class meetings throughout the semester. There will be a final jury evaluation prior to the final public performances, to be held sometime during Reading Period--all students are required to be available. Students who do not meet the requirements in the Course Notes below may take the course for Pass/Fail credit. Please check audition dates and other mandatory meetings/classes on the Canvas Music 189R home page.
notes: New for the 2025-26 school year: students will not be able to request pre-formed groups or personnel preferences. All group personnel decisions will be made by the instructors. Please visit Canvas page for the most updated schedule. In addition to end-of-semester public performances, this course will have mandatory full-class meetings on select Tuesday/Thursday evenings. Additionally, coachings will be scheduled throughout the semester between each group and instructor. Students who are currently in the NEC/Harvard dual program or enrolled in Music 189 for the Fall 2025 semester do not need to audition for the Spring 2026 semester, although this does not guarantee acceptance. ALL students (including those exempt from a live audition) must fill out a questionnaire and submit it through Music 189's Canvas page. Students intending to enroll in both Harvard-Radcliffe Orchestra and Music 189R must audition for each course separately. This course is offered for letter-grade credit only when students are involved in one or more of the following: a Concentrator in Music; enrollment in a Department of Music course concurrently or in a previous semester (other than 189R); a member of a faculty-led music ensemble in the same semester; a student of the NEC/Harvard dual program. Students who do not meet one of these requirements may take the course for Pass/Fail credit, which must be done by petition after the first week of class.

course_title_2025: Age of Empires: Violence, Ideology, and the Making of Ancient Near Eastern Societies 001
course_title_2026: Age of Empires: Violence, Ideology, and the Making of Ancient Near Eastern Societies
description: What is empire? Why and how are some political collectives more successful than others in achieving dominance over diverse geographic locales and social groups? What role does violence and ideology play in the imperial project? And what strategies do communities employ to negotiate their position under non-local rule? This course explores the range of answers to such questions by surveying the rise and fall of several major Bronze and Iron Age empires of ancient southwest Asia, including New Kingdom Egypt, the Hittites, Assyria, Babylon, Achaemenid Persia, and the arrival of Hellenism under Alexander of Macedon. In concert with investigating the structure, ideologies, and characteristics of expansion of these imperial powers, the archaeological, visual, and epigraphic record will be engaged to give equal focus to the diverse experiences of peoples subjected to such structures of domination. Specific focus is placed on the region of the ancient Levant and the communities therein, exploring their reaction to these imperial programs throughout the late second through first millennium BCE. In doing so, we will investigate how the intersection of imperial objectives dovetailed with local strategies of resistance and/or adaptation, resulting in the making of ancient Near Eastern societies.

course_title_2025: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament 2: Latter Prophets and Writings 001
best_comment: If you are at all interested in the Hebrew Bible / Old Testament, please take this class. Prof. Teeter is so knowledgeable and is so skilled at drawing out the rich tapestry or literary art and meaning in these texts. He is a pioneer in his approach to reading the Hebrew Bible, and it is a privilege to learn from him. You should consider taking this course even if you have already learned the Old Testament in a personal religious context. As an evangelical, I grew in my faith and appreciation for God's Word through this text. You may not agree with everything Prof. Teeter or your classmates say (you will agree with a lot of it though!), and it will be time well spent learning about and engaging with these ideas.
worse_comment: Take the class if interested in Hebrew Bible beyond source criticism.
course_title_2026: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament 2: Latter Prophets and Writings
description: A critical introduction to the literature and theology of the Hebrew Bible, considered in light of the historical contexts of its formation and the interpretive contexts of its reception within Judaism and Christianity. The course, the second part of a divisible, year-long sequence, will focus on the Latter Prophets and the Writings.
notes: Offered jointly with the Divinity School as HDS 1103.

course_title_2025: Historical Background to the Contemporary Middle East: Religion, Literature and Politics 001
best_comment: This is an excellent course that I’d recommend to NELC or non NELC concentrators. You get a great sense of the topics available within NELC and the workload is reasonable. Dr. Shahvand is also amazing and the nicest guy, and his personal story is super interesting as well. Great course!!
course_title_2026: Historical Background to the Contemporary Middle East: Religion, Literature and Politics
description: What defines the Middle East? What long-term historical and cultural developments can we trace in the region? How do these affect contemporary global order and policy? This team-taught course in the NELCdepartment will address these three fundamental questions of great present relevance by introducing students to the ancient and modern peoples, languages, cultures, and societies of Western Asia and North Africa. The study of this diverse region is uniquely aided by a deep-time perspective afforded by thousands of years of vibrant art, writing and cultural artefacts. Relying on the classic expertise integral to area studies, the course brings together faculty from a variety of disciplines – from history and archaeology to literature and philology, and from sociology and economy to the political sciences – in a common endeavour to explore the rich cultural complex of the region through four key topics: history, religion, literature and politics.
notes: Formerly NEC 97r, this course satisfies the NELC Sophomore Tutorial requirements.

best_comment: Persian is such a beautiful and rich language, you should definitely take this class if you are interested in learning more about it. This being said, this class is a good amount of work considering it is an introductory language, so be prepared to put the time and effort in that is needed to succeed!
description: This course continues Persian AA (Elementary Persian I) and is designed to further develop students' elementary-level Persian language proficiency and improve their listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills. We will communicate primarily by speaking, listening, reading, and writing in both written and spoken Persian. We will use modern Persian poetry and pop music songs to enhance our comprehension.
notes: Not open to auditors. Cannot be taken pass/fail. .

best_comment: If you have any interest in Persian/Farsi, I highly recommend taking this course!
description: In this course, students will continue to develop intermediate-level competence in spoken and written Persian. Emphasis is on reading comprehension, grammar, and writing, as well as cultural and historical knowledge. Through pop songs, modern Persian poetry, short stories, and Iranian movies, students will continue to develop their proficiency in intermediate-level Persian. Persian will be the primary language of the class.
notes: Not open to auditors. Cannot be taken pass/fail.

best_comment: What a wonderful time!! Turkish is such a fun and interesting language to learn, and Meryem Hocam is such an enthusiastic and clear instructor who cares so much about your individual learning. It is so cool to have walked into this class (starting with Turkish AA in the fall) not understanding a single thing to now having built a very solid foundation. Over the course of this class, you will encounter many new grammatical structures via chalkboard diagram (and learn to enjoy this process!), gain exposure to Turkish music + culture, and learn many things about your fellow classmates through discussions and creative assignments (like poems and stories)! Having very friendly and dedicated classmates makes this class even more awesome. Take Turkish, you will DEFINITELY love it!!
description: Emphasis on all aspects of Turkish grammar toward developing a solid foundation for speaking, listening, reading, writing, and vocabulary skills.
notes: Not open to auditors. Cannot be taken pass/fail. Please note this course meets all four days listed.

course_title_2025: Biology and Evolution of Invertebrate Animals 001
best_comment: Very good course. Not too difficult if you keep on top of studying the new content every week, but it's easy to fall behind and cramming is basically impossible since it asks you to know a lot. There is very little required work outside of class every week, so use that time to consistently review content. Cassandra and Bronwyn are great – don't be afraid to email them your questions and especially head to their office hours before exams. The trip was super fun –– very unique for Harvard classes. This is not your typical beach bum vacation, though –– if you don't enjoy science and labwork, you won't enjoy the trip or get nearly as much out of it as you should. The trip is to collect animals to study in lab, so it is rewarding if you're passionate about the subject matter and like applying what we learn to real specimens, but not if you're looking for a free beach vacation. That being said, we got 2 nights to explore the town/city, but otherwise you can't leave the base at night. Overall it's a very fun and rewarding class, but they make you work for it. Don't do it if you're only loosely interested in it or because you want a free trip –– do it because you're actually interested.
course_title_2026: Biology and Evolution of Invertebrate Animals
description: Introduction to invertebrate diversity, will cover the development, adult anatomy, biology and evolutionary relationships of the main animal phyla including sponges, mollusks, annelids and arthropods among others. Special emphasis is placed on understanding the broad diversity of animal forms and their adaptations to different ecosystems and how these phenomena shape animal evolution. Lectures will be complemented with a mandatory weekly lab, and the course includes a field trip to different areas of outstanding marine diversity in the Caribbean.
notes: Optional field trip to the Caribbean for research during spring break.  Mandatory Lab component:  Wednesdays, 3:00-5:45 PM.

best_comment: This is a really excellent course here. The teaching staff is awesome ( and do a wonderful job lecturing), field trips are a great opportunity to get off campus ( and also very fun), lab is really just getting to see how cool plants are, and the assignments are not terribly stressful. This has made this class a wonderful science class to take at Harvard. The organization and course format is very well done, making this a great class for students. The content is also very interesting. As a side note: I took this class with OEB 103 and found this class and OEB 103 to go hand and hand. What I learned in OEB 103 was incredibly helpful for this class and vice versa. If you are thinking about taking both classes, they both inform and help each other. It was a great plant semester.
worse_comment: This is easily the most fun I've had in a Harvard class over the past four years. I came from a completely unrelated major and stumbled upon this course in the catalog basically by chance. If you like plants in any capacity whatsoever, take this class! If this class fulfills a requirement for you but you think you hate plants, take this class anyway!
description: Introduction to the structure, diversity, and physiology of plants with an emphasis on evolutionary relationships and adaptations to life on land. Topics include growth, resource acquisition, interactions with other organisms (i.e., fungi, bacteria, insects), reproduction, and survival in extreme environments. Laboratory sessions provide an overview of plant and diversity and an introduction to basic physiological processes.

best_comment: This is a really excellent course here. The teaching staff is awesome ( and do a wonderful job lecturing), field trips are a great opportunity to get off campus ( and also very fun), lab is really just getting to see how cool plants are, and the assignments are not terribly stressful. This has made this class a wonderful science class to take at Harvard. The organization and course format is very well done, making this a great class for students. The content is also very interesting. As a side note: I took this class with OEB 103 and found this class and OEB 103 to go hand and hand. What I learned in OEB 103 was incredibly helpful for this class and vice versa. If you are thinking about taking both classes, they both inform and help each other. It was a great plant semester.
worse_comment: This is easily the most fun I've had in a Harvard class over the past four years. I came from a completely unrelated major and stumbled upon this course in the catalog basically by chance. If you like plants in any capacity whatsoever, take this class! If this class fulfills a requirement for you but you think you hate plants, take this class anyway!
description: Introduction to the structure, diversity, and physiology of plants with an emphasis on evolutionary relationships and adaptations to life on land. Topics include growth, resource acquisition, interactions with other organisms (i.e., fungi, bacteria, insects), reproduction, and survival in extreme environments. Laboratory sessions provide an overview of plant and diversity and an introduction to basic physiological processes.

course_title_2025: The History and Evolution of Life on Earth 001
best_comment: Both professors are good lecturers and are engaged with the class. If you're interested in OEB, it's probably a good introductory class to the history of life. I had literally zero OEB knowledge going in which made some of the content basically roll off me because I had no background/frame of reference for it. The class isn't too difficult or time consuming—there's no pset, just lab assignments that are sometimes basically a pset. Labs were hit or miss. Some involved looking at cool fossils, and some were mostly googling what the differences between two random extinct plants are. I discovered about halfway through the class that I am not a history of plants and animals enjoyer, which unfortunately led to me going "why do we care?" about a lot of the later content (which is mostly that) despite the lectures being good. So if you're considering taking this to fulfill an EPS sub–discipline requirement, I'd recommend thoughtfully assessing how much the evolution of life actually interests you.
worse_comment: This class is interesting, and it is a pretty decent balance between biology and EPS. The work load is fair and the teaching staff is supportive, but make sure you stay up to date on the lecture notes and actually attend class. If you don't, thdings can start becoming a lot because such a large time span is covered. While the midterm and final are fair, they can become difficult if you do not spend enough time reviewing. Overall, this is a good course that teaches you a lot about how the Earth has evolved and changed over time. It is not super easy or super hard, but it requires consistent attention and effort to thrive.
course_title_2026: The History and Evolution of Life on Earth
instructors: Javier Ortega-Hernandez, Nadja Drabon, David Johnston
description: Within our solar system, Earth is distinguished as the planet with life. Living organisms are complex entities that originated from planetary processes, have been sustained by the same processes for approximately four billion years, and have fundamentally affected the functioning and composition of the Earth's surface and atmosphere. In this course we will investigate the ways that Earth and life interact with each other, focusing on the biogeochemical cycles of major elements, and the interplay between complex organisms and their ever-changing environment. This will provide a framework for interpreting the fascinating history of life reconstructed from a comprehensive understanding of the rock record, the diversity of life through time, and evolutionary biology.
notes: Course includes a weekly three-hour lab to be arranged and one domestic or  international field trip during the Spring Break. OEB 56 is also offered as EPS 56. Students may not take both for credit. This course fulfils the EPS sub-discipline requirement of Earth History and Geobiology.

course_title_2025: Topics in Organismic and Evolutionary Biology 001
best_comment: Bring Tupperware. But, in all seriousness, this is a very helpful course for those who have not taught before, and feel free to ask questions about asking questions.
course_title_2026: Topics in Organismic and Evolutionary Biology
description: Presents the research interests and experiences of scientists in organismic and evolutionary biology. Specific topics treated vary from year to year.
notes: Required of all first-year graduate students in Organismic and Evolutionary Biology.

best_comment: If you're really into moral/ethical philosophy, I think you will absolutely love this class. If you're only kind of interested like I was/am, you'll have a good time, but things can get a little boring. The class is VERY formulaic week to week: you read a few texts, Seth explains them in lecture, and you discuss them in section. There is very little throughout the semester to break up this routine, which can make the whole course just blend into one big blob of philosophy. That being said, I still give this class a very positive review. Seth is very intentional with what/how he teaches, and it's obvious that one of his goals is for each of his students to leave his class as better people. He's also just a cool dude, and makes the whole class a super chill vibe. I also really like how major assignments are structured. You have to write two ~1500 word essays which are based more on your own thinking and perspective than a standard research paper. They were overall really enjoyable to write, and the grading is pretty friendly if you do a good job. Great class! If you're looking for a fun elective which is easy, but not a joke, and you want to learn something along the way, this is an excellent choice.
worse_comment: This course had great readings and fascinating discussions about human ethics, but I couldn't help but feel that it was quite disorganized.
description: Does might make right? Should a person focus on achieving immortality or on living a simple, happy mortal life? Is morality simply a matter of convention? Why be moral when being immoral could provide access to more wealth, fame, and power? What is the relationship between etiquette and morality? What do people owe a society that has failed in its obligations to its people? How can we identify and resist oppression, marginalization, and injustice? Human beings all over the world have been thinking about, discussing, and debating questions like these for thousands of years. This course aims to look at this history of ethics and moral philosophy from a genuinely inclusive perspective by focusing on ethical thought both from all over the world, with special emphasis on that of members of traditionally marginalized groups and from areas of the world that typically receive much less attention in academic philosophy and ethics.

best_comment: If you have a chance, TAKE THIS CLASS.  I can not tell you exactly what you will learn, since the course is improved upon each semester, but I can tell you that it will be fundamentally fascinating. We spent the first half of the semester essentially rederiving linear algebra, and the second rederiving all of the axioms of quantum mechanics, all from base principles with very little prior math knowledge needed. Readings included many paper from the original proposal/formulations of quantum mechanics, and section/OH helped a lot with interpretation, so that prior philosophy knowledge requirements were also minimal. Though I took the course as Phil 151, there was a fairly even distribution of people who took it as a physics course, and one could consistently rely on others who had more experience in either physics or philosophy for perspective. The class is small (30ish people), competitive to get into (because the subject and professor are both well liked by students), and takes all years/levels of experience (everything is self contained/taught within the course). This is also a wonderful class for a more logical/formulaic philosophy experience and a more questions/interpretation–based experience physics. I would definitely recommend attending section/OH if possible, the material is fascinating and teaching staff are very willing to discuss related topics. The course generally follows the professors own formulation of quantum mechanics, has no exams (only a final essay), and has only one pset a week (with a reading section and a very straightforward math section). Overall, I had a wonderful time in this class and would absolutely choose to take it again. I seriously can not overstate how interesting and welcoming this class is!TLDR; Best class, heavily consider taking it
description: Quantum theory is our most empirically successful scientific framework. The theory reliably accounts for the measurement results of atomic clocks and particle accelerators to many decimal places, and much of our modern technology relies on it. However, the theory’s axiomatic foundations are arguably either inconsistent or incomplete, and there is still no consensus over what the theory entails about the world. This course will cover the century-long effort to resolve these mysteries and others, a story that features fantastical notions like parallel universes, pilot waves, quasi-probabilities, alive-and-dead cats, and spooky action at a distance. Throughout the course, we will engage with many relevant questions in philosophy, from determinism and causation to epistemology and the meaning of probability.Assessments: The course will have weekly homework assignments consisting of a mixture of primary-source readings, short essays, and mathematical exercises. The course will not have any exams. We will conclude with a final paper on a topic that students can choose from a list of available prompts.

best_comment: In my opinion, great course. I saw reviews saying lectures are dry. Sure, but any class has dry lectures. If you are interested in this topic and philosophy, especially the metaphysical side, this is a great course. You won't think lectures are dry, you will have tons of fun with the content and the assignments are great, useful –– no busy work. It will hone your philosophy skills well. (my thoughts)
worse_comment: not sure I would recommend thisclass, interesting subject matter but lectures are pretty boring and mostly just recap readings. Sections were very helpful, though. The papers weren’t too bad – three six–pagers, which felt much less stressful than having one big final paper.
description: A philosophical examination of the mind and its relation to the natural world. Topics include: the mind – body problem, consciousness, other minds, animal cognition, and artificial intelligence. Readings will consist primarily of influential papers from the latter half of the 20th Century.

best_comment: You will likely learn to love this topic by the end of the course and develop a genuine interest in the topics covered. Professor Siegel does an outstanding job in facilitation and the course really feels engaging throughout the whole class period.
description: Topics to be examined include perception, mind-wandering, roles for attention in dynamics of thought, and the psychological dimensions of inquiry.

best_comment: This class is absolutely wonderful! Zoe is one of the best professors I have had here at Harvard. Not only is she super funny, but she knows her philosophy so well and does a great job breaking it down during lectures. Zoe's lectures are super engaging– she is very bubbly and enthusiatic, and she always have activities during lecture! One thing I would say about this class is it's super important to stay on top of the readings. The reading summaries (while they may annoy you in the moment), will be your absolute best friend when it comes to that final! This is a class both undergraduates and graduate students can take, and I highly recommend it as an undergraduate myself– what I will say is that the readings are very complexed, so you have to be committed to sitting there and putting in the effort to understand. Zoe and Jing Hwan are fantastic and are readily available, which is great. The two papers are very short (1500 words), and make sure you come to class to get your participation points! Overall, this has been one of my favorite classes, and I'm really going to miss it!
description: This course is an introduction to contemporary metaethics. It will address questions like the following:Does the existence of widespread ethical disagreement mean that there can’t be any objective facts and it’s all just a matter of opinion? Can we reconcile the idea of an objective ethical reality with evolutionary and sociological arguments that explain how we developed our beliefs? Is it strange that there can be facts that tell you what to do?We will begin by examining three famous arguments for an “anti-realist” metaethics: J.L. Mackie’s arguments from disagreement and from “queerness”, and Sharon Street’s “Darwinian dilemma”. All three arguments challenge the idea that our ethical beliefs reflect some kind of mind-independent facts. We will begin to develop philosophical skills through close analysis of these arguments, identifying their logical structure and the places where they could be challenged. We will then apply these skills to a series of texts defending alternative metaethical views, including reductive and non-reductive naturalism, quasi-realism, and constructivism. We will explore those four positions and the main challenges for each of them. Throughout, we will ask whether our ethical beliefs are on surer footing than some other kinds of normative beliefs, especially beliefs about aesthetics, beliefs about rationality, and – most importantly – beliefs about what we should believe.

course_title_2025: Mechanics and Statistical Physics from an Analytic, Numerical and Experimental Perspective 001
best_comment: Okay, so here’s the deal. I took this class coming off of AP Physics 1, and honestly, I wasn’t sure what to expect. I’d learned the basics, but I was looking for something that would push me further without turning into an all–consuming nightmare. Physical Sciences 12a totally delivered on that. It’s not just a repeat of high school physics—it’s a chance to build on what you already know, dive deeper into some cool stuff like fluid mechanics, and leave with a stronger understanding of physics than you walked in with.It’s also just a great course if you want to understand physics but not dive into the deep end. For someone like me, who’s not majoring in physics but needs a solid foundation for engineering, this class was perfectPros:A Real Review That’s Actually Helpful:Coming from AP Physics 1, I thought I knew the basics. Like, I knew how to do some basic mechanics, forces, and energy problems. But when I jumped into 12a, I realized that there’s a level of depth I hadn’t even touched yet. This course didn’t just breeze through what I already knew—it helped me really understand it. Fluid mechanics was a whole new world for me, and I got to see how the math and concepts actually fit together. Honestly, I walked out of this class with a much better grasp of physics than I had going in.Demos & Labs: Total Game Changer:Let’s be real, I didn’t expect the demos to be as entertaining as they were. They were straight–up cool. We didn’t just watch some pendulum swing back and forth—these demos brought the physics to life in ways that made everything feel real. And the labs? They weren’t just a way to pass time. I actually enjoyed them. I got to team up with people, test out theories, and see how physics works in the real world. It wasn’t some dry, boring “let’s just get this done” experience—it was genuinely fun. Plus, the labs were a good way to meet people, so there’s that bonus.Stars System: Not Perfect, But Solid:I was a little skeptical about the Stars system at first, but once I got into it, I saw how it helped me stay on top of the material. The idea is simple: prove you know your stuff, earn a Star. It gives you smaller, more manageable goals to work toward instead of one big exam stress fest. Now, I’m not gonna lie, the Stars system can be intense. If you mess up even a little bit, you miss the Star. But there’s a silver lining: if you miss a Star, you can meet with the course leadership to show that you’ve got a handle on the material. It’s kind of like an insurance policy—you get another shot to prove you know your stuff. This kept me from panicking about exams and helped me focus on actually learning.Incredible Support from the Course Leadership:One of my favorite things about this class was the course leadership. They weren’t just checking boxes—they actually cared that you understood the material. Any time I had a question or felt like I was falling behind, they were there to help. It wasn’t some generic “go to office hours” vibe; they’d actually meet with you one–on–one, break down concepts until they clicked, and make sure you were on the right track. It was refreshing, especially in a course that’s got some heavy material.Confidence Boost Like No Other:Before this course, I felt like I understood physics, but not in the deep way I wanted to. After 12a, though? I felt like I could actually do physics. The new material, like fluid mechanics, was challenging, but the course gave me the tools and understanding to tackle it head–on. By the end of it, I was ready to keep going with physics. If you’ve taken AP Physics 1 or have some basic understanding and are worried about taking that next step, this course will give you the confidence you need to keep pushing forward.Shoutout to the CAs:Alright, let’s talk about problem sets. They’re no joke. But what made them manageable was the support I got from the CAs. Seriously—if you’re struggling, get to office hours. The CAs (NeNe, Rohil, Will, Tyler—you guys are the real MVPs) were always ready to break things down and explain stuff until it clicked. It made those PSets way less stressful, and honestly, I probably wouldn’t have made it through without their help.Cons:9 A.M. = No Fun:We all know how it goes—9 a.m. is way too early for anything. Especially when you’ve been pulling late–night study sessions, dealing with other classes, or just living your life. Getting up for this class felt like an Olympic sport in itself. Don’t let the early start fool you—if you’re not a morning person, prepare to drag yourself out of bed.Stars System (Again):As much as I loved the Stars system, it’s not all sunshine and rainbows. There were times where I felt like the smallest mistake—something minor—would cost me a Star. And that little bit of stress over missing Stars can get to you, especially if you're someone who’s a little on the perfectionist side. It’s a great system in theory, but it can sometimes feel like you're walking a tightrope.Coding Projects (Sigh):Okay, I get it—coding is part of the physics game now, and I see the value of integrating it. But honestly? The coding projects were a bit of a headache. It wasn’t a huge deal since they’re not on the final, but they still felt like extra busywork. They weren’t terrible, just kind of annoying.PSets Are Time–Consuming (But What Else Is New?):Let’s face it—problem sets in any physics class are going to take time. These were no exception. Some weeks, I’d be buried in them for hours. It’s manageable, but if you’ve got a packed schedule, they can start to feel like a never–ending cycle. Again, office hours help, but they do take up a good chunk of your time.
worse_comment: This course teaches more than other introductory physics courses, but the format of the course is terrible. The CS and statistics are not well integrated with the physics.
course_title_2026: Mechanics and Statistical Physics from an Analytic, Numerical and Experimental Perspective
description: This is the first term of a two-semester introductory course in physics. The focus is on quantitative scientific reasoning, with the first term exploring Newtonian mechanics. Topics include kinematics, linear and rotational motion, forces, energy, momentum, collisions, gravitation, oscillations, and waves, with a brief introduction to statistical physics. Examples are drawn from across the physical sciences and engineering. Students will gain competence in both analytic (pencil and paper) and computational tools (programming in Python) used by scientists to model simple physical systems and analyze experimental data, including problem solving, basic programming, measurement of physical quantities, and chi squared model testing and curve fitting.The course is aimed at first year students who have an interest in pursuing a concentration in the sciences or engineering. The course includes lecture, laboratory, and discussion components.
