It was refreshing, especially in a course that’s got some heavy material.Confidence Boost Like No Other:Before this course, I felt like I understood physics, but not in the deep way I wanted to. After 12a, though? I felt like I could actually do physics. The new material, like fluid mechanics, was challenging, but the course gave me the tools and understanding to tackle it head–on. By the end of it, I was ready to keep going with physics. If you’ve taken AP Physics 1 or have some basic understanding and are worried about taking that next step, this course will give you the confidence you need to keep pushing forward.Shoutout to the CAs:Alright, let’s talk about problem sets. They’re no joke. But what made them manageable was the support I got from the CAs. Seriously—if you’re struggling, get to office hours. The CAs (NeNe, Rohil, Will, Tyler—you guys are the real MVPs) were always ready to break things down and explain stuff until it clicked. It made those PSets way less stressful, and honestly, I probably wouldn’t have made it through without their help.Cons:9 A.M. = No Fun:We all know how it goes—9 a.m. is way too early for anything. Especially when you’ve been pulling late–night study sessions, dealing with other classes, or just living your life. Getting up for this class felt like an Olympic sport in itself. Don’t let the early start fool you—if you’re not a morning person, prepare to drag yourself out of bed.Stars System (Again):As much as I loved the Stars system, it’s not all sunshine and rainbows. There were times where I felt like the smallest mistake—something minor—would cost me a Star. And that little bit of stress over missing Stars can get to you, especially if you're someone who’s a little on the perfectionist side. It’s a great system in theory, but it can sometimes feel like you're walking a tightrope.Coding Projects (Sigh):Okay, I get it—coding is part of the physics game now, and I see the value of integrating it. But honestly? The coding projects were a bit of a headache. It wasn’t a huge deal since they’re not on the final, but they still felt like extra busywork. They weren’t terrible, just kind of annoying.PSets Are Time–Consuming (But What Else Is New?):Let’s face it—problem sets in any physics class are going to take time. These were no exception. Some weeks, I’d be buried in them for hours. It’s manageable, but if you’ve got a packed schedule, they can start to feel like a never–ending cycle. Again, office hours help, but they do take up a good chunk of your time.
worse_comment: This course teaches more than other introductory physics courses, but the format of the course is terrible. The CS and statistics are not well integrated with the physics.
course_title_2026: Mechanics and Statistical Physics from an Analytic, Numerical and Experimental Perspective
description: This is the first term of a two-semester introductory course in physics. The focus is on quantitative scientific reasoning, with the first term exploring Newtonian mechanics. Topics include kinematics, linear and rotational motion, forces, energy, momentum, collisions, gravitation, oscillations, and waves, with a brief introduction to statistical physics. Examples are drawn from across the physical sciences and engineering. Students will gain competence in both analytic (pencil and paper) and computational tools (programming in Python) used by scientists to model simple physical systems and analyze experimental data, including problem solving, basic programming, measurement of physical quantities, and chi squared model testing and curve fitting.The course is aimed at first year students who have an interest in pursuing a concentration in the sciences or engineering. The course includes lecture, laboratory, and discussion components.

best_comment: PLEASE DEAR STUDENT TAKE THIS CLASS.  If you want an answer to the question "what were your top 5 most favorite classes you took throughout all college?" this should be top 3, if not the first.  This class is MIT's equivalent of "how to build almost everything", and you're not missing out by not taking the MIT version: this is seriously one of the best courses offered here.My background: CS/Econ.  Almost no 'building–hardware' experience but wanted to explore that.You get to work with a small group of people, which I think really adds to the vibe.  The staff and teaching fellows are super fun to hang around and are very easy to ask questions to.  What's kind of funny is that the lab is in the science center (SC 102) and visitors will come by to look in at the work you're doing.  Feels like you're on display, which some may not like, but I actually loved it because it felt cool to show off what you've been working on![What I Learned]The course site essentially describes all of this, but I'll put it here:– Microcontroller programming– CNC Milling (wood, acrylic, foam)– Laser Cutting (wood, acrylic)– Metalwork– Circuitry fundamentals (capacitors, resistors, breadboards)– Inputs/outputs you can attach to the circuit (servos and other actuators, stepper/DC motors, Piezo buzzers, RFID scanners, light displays, and so much more)– Circuit board fabrication (PCBs)– Radio communication (wired, wireless, Bluetooth)[Typical Week]– You'll be given a project to work on Tuesday, then have until the following Thursday to complete it.– If you don't complete it to the level you desire, you're free to redo it or continue on it until the end of the semester, but I advise just moving on and focusing on the next weekly task, then go back to that one at the end, that way you're not feeling lagged behind by any means.– The workload each week is not the same.  Some projects will take longer.  Of all the weeks, I think the heaviest weeks are: kinetic sculpture, radio communication, and machine building (robot machine).  Those weeks take about 10 hours.Again, PLEASE TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU WANNA DO HANDS ON WORK.  This stuff is so fun.  I know I say 10 hours for the worst weeks but honestly it does not even feel like 10 weeks, it's more like "an hour of work here" and "two hours of work there", what's nice is you can basically come in any time with a buddy and they have so many office hours it's quite ridiculous, there's never a shortage of that.  You'll do awesome!!
description: An immersive introduction to rapid prototyping, fusing physics, design, computer science, engineering, and art. Students will learn to safely use software and hardware to fabricate programmable projects. Tools and topics will include programmable microcontrollers, 3D CAD/CAM, electronic circuit design, and wireless networking (Internet of Things). Additionally, students will learn operational principles for techniques such as laser cutting, 3D printing, and computer-controlled milling. The course will culminate with an individual final project of the student’s own conception, integrating as many of the weekly topics as possible. The course emphasizes self-directed learning, and supports students in accessing resources to help advance the development of their unique projects. Applications may include personal fabrication, product prototyping, fine arts, and the creation of scientific research tools. Students will document work on each weekly topic in a personal website, thereby finishing the course with an online portfolio that not only illustrates their new skill sets, but also contributes to a collective repository of knowledge that serves as a foundation for continued learning.Course website: https://tinyurl.com/tasr7b6Related Sections: In addition to class times, students enroll in a lab section where they will interact with course staff for hands-on assignment work. The shop will also remain open to enrolled students at additional times throughout the week.
notes: Attendance is mandatory since safety training will occur during class times. Class will meet twice each week. The first meeting will consist of a brief review of the previous week’s assignment, followed by a short introduction to the current week’s topic and assignment. The second meeting will primarily focus on a hands-on training session for the accompanying assignment. Meetings may also include appearances by guest presenters or experts on a particular topic.

best_comment: TAKE IT! TAKE IT! TAKE IT!!!!!! This was the best STEM course I took at Harvard so far. I highly suggest taking 15a instead of 12a if you are truly interested in learning how Physics works. The material is awesome, the lectures are great and the labs are super manageable. I loved it!
worse_comment: This class is not super interesting. I didn't really get an intuition for why these physics concepts occur (which might be my fault, but still). If you are coming to this class out of a curiosity for physics, you should probably take physics 19.
instructors: Anna Klales, John Huth, Stephen Adams
description: Physics 15a is an introduction to the topics of Newtonian mechanics and special relativity, but it is also an introduction to what it means to be a physicist—formulating theoretical models to describe the natural world and testing those models for consistency with data. Topics include: vectors; kinematics in three dimensions; Newton's laws; force, work, power; conservative forces, potential energy; momentum, collisions; rotational motion, angular momentum, torque; static equilibrium, simple harmonic motion, damped and driven oscillations; gravitation; fictitious forces; fluids; special relativity; experimental methods and tools including: basic programming, experimental design and data acquisition, model testing and error analysis; scientific communication.
notes: Principles of Scientific Inquiry (PSI) is the laboratory component of Physics 15a. Topics include experimental design, model testing, error analysis, basic programming, and oral presentations. PSI will meet weekly throughout the semester.

best_comment: Take this course if you really need to satisfy the Electromagnetism requirement. Carlos is a good professor, though their lectures can sometimes leave you desiring a little more. The textbook is honestly not the best in my opinion. I found it more useful for review rather than actually using it to study. Referring to it after completing a problem set and going over lecture notes is honestly more useful, in my opinion. The lab component of this course is also alright. It is a lot better than the mechanics labs we had to do. Office hours and sections will be a must if you struggle a bit in this course. The CAs and TFs will definitely help you get back on track as long as you are willing to put in the effort. As a student who had little to no experience with Electromagnetism (beyond AP physics 2 and what I learned in Physics 19), I'd say the content can be challenging, but it certainly is not difficult at all to grasp once you get some practice in. I don't recommend taking this course as your first physics class, you should take some level of a mechanics course before taking this class. Also, if you feel very confident about your math skills and are considering taking 153 over this course, don't feel afraid to shop it. Though I did not mind my time in 15b, a part of me does wonder if I should have considered shopping 153.  You should be familiar with some multivariable calculus for this class, but it's not essential. I took 22b alongside this course, and honestly, you can get by without having learn multivar/currently in the process of learning it.All in all, this is not a bad course. Some lectures did feel rushed at times, others felt like they didn't go fast enough, but most of the time, the content was taught fairly well, in my opinion. Though Carlos could be confusing at times, it seems like they do care about what they are teaching. They always took questions and did their best to make sure students were engaged and learning.  However, I do feel a little disappointed in the course. As exciting as some of the material could be, it honestly often felt more like math–bashing than actual physics. The class has its moments (especially with the demos done during lecture), but personally, I was hoping for a little more rigor, especially with some of the proofs done in class. I feel like I learned more about how to solve physics problems than actual physics. To summarize, don't feel afraid to shop the course, and it's a decent way to get the Electromagnetism requirement out of the way, and its not a bad introduction to the field, especially if you plan to take Electrodynamics the following spring.
worse_comment: I would say only take this course if you have to. It is a frustrating experience, especially if you have no previous E&M background. The organization of the course was not good, students had to remind through slack that the materials were posted, and this was especially bad close to the exam season. The lectures were not the most effective, even if the material was interesting. The course needs a lot of restructuring, because it is frustrating and hard to take. The exams were not fair taking into account no extra practice materials were provided to understand what was going to appear in the course. E&M is a cool subject, I just wish it was presented better.
description: This course is an undergraduate-level course on electromagnetism. Topics include electrostatics, electric currents, magnetic field, electromagnetic induction, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic radiation, magnetic fields in materials, and some basic notions in kinetic theory, entropy, temperature, and phase transition associated with electricity and magnetism.
notes: Principles of Scientific Inquiry (PSI) is the laboratory component of Physics 15b. The labs are designed to enhance your understanding of material presented in lectures. They also present applications of electricity and magnetism, as well as offering opportunities to build simple circuits and develop experience using measuring instruments, including oscilloscopes.

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE. . It's my favorite course I've ever had at Harvard. If you're trying to decide, this is your sign. TAKE IT. But on a more serious note, if you're wondering what this course is like, it really is a physicist's math course. It's all about giving you the tools to solve problems. In a typical math course, we learn techniques and kind of problems, but there's a lot of theory and explanation surrounding it. It's not that the course fails to give you a solid theoretical grounding, but it's less concerned with rigor, giving you enough of an intro to understand the motivation behind a formula without exhaustive justification of our methods. But because of this, you can cover SO MUCH. For example, I took Math 113 and learned wonderful things, but in terms of how to solve actual problems in the field, a week of this course taught me 80% of a semester of Math 113. And the math is SO relevant for a physicist. I was taking 143A at the same time and often I'd learn a subject in 106 then have to apply it or derive it in 143A a week later. And the course is really fun. interesting lectures cool problems. In summary the course A. Will teach you a lot. B. Is super relevant to physics. C. Is really fun. TAKEITTAKEITTAKEITTAKEITTAKEIT
description: This course is designed to give students the mathematical tools that will be helpful in their physics courses. Topics include: Fourier analysis, special functions, tensors, differential equations, contour integration, group theory, probability, statistics, variational principle, phase space, Green’s functions, transforms.

best_comment: If you have a chance, TAKE THIS CLASS.  I can not tell you exactly what you will learn, since the course is improved upon each semester, but I can tell you that it will be fundamentally fascinating. We spent the first half of the semester essentially rederiving linear algebra, and the second rederiving all of the axioms of quantum mechanics, all from base principles with very little prior math knowledge needed. Readings included many paper from the original proposal/formulations of quantum mechanics, and section/OH helped a lot with interpretation, so that prior philosophy knowledge requirements were also minimal. Though I took the course as Phil 151, there was a fairly even distribution of people who took it as a physics course, and one could consistently rely on others who had more experience in either physics or philosophy for perspective. The class is small (30ish people), competitive to get into (because the subject and professor are both well liked by students), and takes all years/levels of experience (everything is self contained/taught within the course). This is also a wonderful class for a more logical/formulaic philosophy experience and a more questions/interpretation–based experience physics. I would definitely recommend attending section/OH if possible, the material is fascinating and teaching staff are very willing to discuss related topics. The course generally follows the professors own formulation of quantum mechanics, has no exams (only a final essay), and has only one pset a week (with a reading section and a very straightforward math section). Overall, I had a wonderful time in this class and would absolutely choose to take it again. I seriously can not overstate how interesting and welcoming this class is!TLDR; Best class, heavily consider taking it
description: Quantum theory is our most empirically successful scientific framework. The theory reliably accounts for the measurement results of atomic clocks and particle accelerators to many decimal places, and much of our modern technology relies on it. However, the theory’s axiomatic foundations are arguably either inconsistent or incomplete, and there is still no consensus over what the theory entails about the world. This course will cover the century-long effort to resolve these mysteries and others, a story that features fantastical notions like parallel universes, pilot waves, quasi-probabilities, alive-and-dead cats, and spooky action at a distance. Throughout the course, we will engage with many relevant questions in philosophy, from determinism and causation to epistemology and the meaning of probability.
notes: This course is cross-listed as Philosophy 151 and Physics 137. When taken as Philosophy 151, this course satisfies a divisional distribution in Arts and Humanities. When taken as Physics 137, this course satisfies a divisional distribution in Science & Engineering & Applied Science. Either way, this course counts toward the concentration requirements for the physics concentration.

best_comment: This was an amazing class. If you are considering physics at all, take this!!! Eslam is an amazing professor and he is super kind and super willing to accomodate to each students needs. I have nothing negative to say about this course. Seriously just an amazing class.
worse_comment: I really disliked this class. The lecture style was proof/derivation based and there was no emphasis on building intuition or how to apply concepts to problems. There was no mention of how these concepts are applied/why they matter in the real world. It was entirely demoralizing and a massive time suck. Don't take it if Khalaf teaches it. 21B is definitely required.
description: Introduction to nonrelativistic quantum mechanics: uncertainty relations; Schrödinger equation; Dirac notation; matrix mechanics; one-dimensional problems including particle in box, tunneling, and harmonic oscillator; angular momentum, hydrogen atom, spin, Pauli principle; and if time allows: time-independent perturbation theory; and scattering.

best_comment: Physics 153 with Girma is an incredible experience. Although Girma is not the clearest of lecturers, this is compensated by his boundless enthusiasm and love for electrodynamics which he radiates (no EM pun intended) at every lecture! Girma is a very accessible instructor whom you can ask any question without fear of judgment, and it was always a pleasure to attend his office hours during which I gained a lot of physical insight. The subject–matter of the course — electrodynamics — is an extremely beautiful subject, and knowledge and mastery thereof is crucial to any budding theoretical physicist. Unfortunately, we did not cover the entirety of Griffiths in sufficient depth due to temporal constraints — which is a shame — but in future renditions of the course, this can be easily remedied by adding a third lecture every week. In terms of prior background and preparation, 153 is a self–contained course that builds up the theory of classical electrodynamics from scratch, so you really do not need a ton of prior knowledge in EM (contrary to what the course prerequisites might say). That being said, such knowledge is useful insofar as it makes the fast pace of 153 more manageable. Personally, I came into the class with only AP Physics C and physics 19 under my belt and did just fine (incidentally, this just goes to show that physics 16 really is unnecessary for more advanced courses like 153). If you're considering taking 153, my suggestion would be to study chapter 1 of Griffiths over winter break if you have never seen multi–variable calculus before. If you have time, you should also take a look at chapters 2 and 3 just so that you don't get lost in the first few weeks. To end this QGuide, I'd like to give some advice on how to get the most out of 153 during the semester. Besides going to all the lectures, I strongly recommend that you read Griffiths (by read, I mean read it religiously). Due to lack of time, I did not read Griffiths in its entirety, which in hindsight I regret given the phenomenal amount of physical insight that this book contains. I think the best strategy is to read Girma's lecture notes before coming to lecture to get a brief overview of the material that will be covered (otherwise, you will easily get lost, because oftentimes Girma skips a lot of the mathematical steps and refers you to the lecture notes), and then after lecture you can read the corresponding sections/chapters in Griffiths to solidify your understanding. I cannot stress the importance of doing this, because with the take–home format of the exams, it is very easy to get away with fragmented understanding of the material, whereas what you should be aiming for is a robust grasp on electrodynamics. TL;DR: Fantastic course, beautiful material, wonderful instructor. Not a lot of background is required. Just read the first chapter(s) of Griffiths over winter break, and make an effort to read the textbook throughout the semester to get the most out of this course.
worse_comment: I would describe this course as a mathematical methods course for physics. A lot of very bashy problems, but useful and worth taking. I would not recommend taking this course under Girma if you have the choice, he is not a great lecturer. Despite many promises, it was not clear.
description: Aimed at advanced undergraduates. Emphasis on the properties and sources of the electromagnetic fields and on the wave aspects of the fields. Course starts with electrostatics and subsequently develops the Maxwell equations. Topics: electrostatics, dielectrics, magnetostatics, electrodynamics, radiation, wave propagation in various media, wave optics, diffraction and interference. A number of applications of electrodynamics and optics in modern physics are discussed.

best_comment: Nice one.Do not listen to the naysayers in the Q, let me provide you with a defense of this wonderful course. First of all, the teaching staff: Professor Schwartz is deeply passionate about the material and teaching as such. He truly wants you to understand statistical mechanics and how to apply it to whatever interests you. He is also accessible outside of class and will explain concepts to you. He is very knowledgeable in many areas of physics and thus a great teacher for this course. The only criticism I have is that the lectures can be somewhat hard to follow at times due to notation inconsistent with the lecture notes or minor notational mistakes. Further the lectures do not comprehensively cover the lecture notes. This is, however, despite what the naysayers falsely have proclaimed, proclaim in this Q and will proclaim ad infinitum not an issue as you have the SUPERB LECTURE NOTES to rely on. They provide detailed derivations of the material and are more than comprehensive.With regards to assignments, the course is relatively easy. There are weekly PSETS that (once again ignore the naysayers) are easy to do with the lecture notes and support from your friends: ChatGPT and Gemini. Yes you heard correctly: generative AI is allowed and its usage is even encouraged in this glorious class. This is part of professor Schwartz's educational doctrine, which I'm very much in support of. Ample extra credit opportunities (such as tempering chocolate) give you a chance to make up for any minor mistakes that happened. Lastly there is a take–home midterm and final, which by their very nature are easy to do. Overall I'm very happy to have taken the course as a Chemistry major over the alternatives the Chemistry department has to offer. There are no pre–requisites. I have not taken any quantum or any proper mechanics. High–school math and physics is all you need, anything else can be learned along the way. The course covers many interesting topics from the basics of stat. mech. over tedious thermodynamics (my hatred has only increased) to interesting applications in semiconductor physics and astrophysics. Once again do not listen to the overly critical voices in this year's Q. From first–hand knowledge I can attest that many of these naysayers did not read the lecture notes or attend lectures, which indeed causes a challenge in understanding the material.
worse_comment: Very bashy. Unsure if this is just physics as a whole or a problem with this particular class.
description: This course provides an introduction to statistical mechanics and thermal physics. It surveys the fundamental elements of classical and quantum statistical mechanics (ensembles and partition functions) and thermodynamics (temperature, heat, work, free energy) and their application to a variety of physical systems. Topics covered may include heat engines, solid-state physics, blackbody radiation, phase transitions, physical chemistry, stellar physics, quantum information, Bose-Einstein condensation, and transport phenomena.
notes: May not be taken for credit in addition to Engineering Sciences 181.

course_title_2025: Introduction to Quantum Materials and Devices 001
best_comment: This is a great class where you learn a lot about many topics in condensed matter. It's especially great if you want to learn more about experimental condensed matter. Professor Westervelt is great and the guest speakers are amazing!
course_title_2026: Introduction to Quantum Materials and Devices
description: This course provides an introduction to quantum materials and devices, including low-dimensional materials, single and double quantum dots, Josephson junctions, and graphene. Their behavior is explained using quantum and semiclassical transport, the Coulomb blockade, and superconductivity. Quantum devices offer new approaches for electronics and photonics.
notes: Formerly ENGSCI 171. Physics 195b is also offered as Applied Physics 195b. Students may not take both for credit.

best_comment: This was the greatest course I've taken, or will ever take, at Harvard. Jordan has set the new standard for teaching 210, par excellence. His deep understanding of general relativity, combined with his philosophical perspective, created a class where I did not merely learn how to compute a bunch of metrics, but to ponder the deep mystery of space and time. Jordan declared his thesis statement at the beginning of the first lecture: Einstein's theory of general relativity gives the definitive explanation of the nature of space and time, a question which had provoked thought for millennia. He developed this thesis throughout the semester. It is my understanding that by the end of February we had covered what past renditions of 210 take the entire semester to do. Despite this, Jordan's lectures felt appropriately paced and incredibly insightful.I especially appreciate how the second half of the course was devoted to topics and applications in GR. Jordan's conjuring of the Ghosts of Universes Past, Present, and Yet–to–Come in the series on cosmology was particularly beautiful. The final lecture may have been the greatest of them all. What I will remember most from this course are the parting words Jordan left for us at the end of the final class. He shared two quotes, one from Einstein and another from Wittgenstein, which were a fitting chiasmus to his opening remarks at the start of the semester. General relativity provides an outlet for wonder more than anything else. It is a theory of singular beauty, yet one which retains a quality bordering on the mystical a century after its inception. That space and time so desperately want to be equals yet are forever distinguished by a single minus sign really makes you wonder. The curvature of spacetime flies in the face of common intuition. Plato writes that what distinguishes knowledge from mere belief is the ability to peer into the realm of Forms and see the underlying, unchanging nature of things. This class teaches you knowledge of the real nature of space, time, matter, and indeed the universe itself. I looked forward to this class every Monday and Wednesday, and hope to cross paths with Jordan again in the future, if our world lines intersect. The Physics Department has done a great job at hiring new faculty in the past few years. It would be a honest shame, and Harvard's loss, if they can't keep Jordan around.
description: An introduction to general relativity: the principle of equivalence, Riemannian geometry, Einstein's field equation, the Schwarzschild solution, the Newtonian limit, experimental tests, black holes.

course_title_2025: Introduction to Classical and Quantum Black Holes 001
best_comment: Take it! Strominger is a great lecturer, you'll finally understand BHI colloquia by the end of it, and psets are hard but interesting. Ahmed is also super open to questions and good at explaining.
description: A selection of topics in quantum gravity focusing on the bottom-up approach to holography. Introductions will be given to black hole entropy and  microstates, AdS/CFT, deSitter and flat holography, twistor theory and soft algebras.

best_comment: This course takes a lot of time (8 hours of classes a week ends up feeling much longer than you expect) but is worth it. You'll become comfortable with basic lab techniques and get a feel for doing data analysis and writing papers. Joe and Jieping will be your best friends at the end of the semester. 2 very important recommendations: make sure to come into the class with a lab partner that you know you work well with, and always start the papers early – they take a LOT of time.
instructors: Matteo Mitrano, Jenny Hoffman, Jieping Fang, Joseph Peidle
description: Students will engage in the practice and discussion of experimental science by completing three projects, drawn from the fields of condensed matter, atomic, optical, nuclear, and/or particle physics.  Laboratory techniques, theoretical understanding, data analysis methods, and scientific reading and writing skills are developed in collaboration with a lab partner, and with guidance from a team of experimental physics faculty and staff. Students will learn to write the results of each project in a format that is appropriate for a peer-reviewed journal. Available experiments range from classics of the twentieth century such as relativistic mass of the electron, lifetime of the muon, superfluid helium, and the quantum Hall effect, to topics of current interest such as slow light, nitrogen-vacancy centers in diamond, superconductivity and the Meissner effect, optical tweezers, and ultrafast optical spectroscopy.
notes: A substantial amount of outside reading is expected.  Physics 247 is the same course as Physics 191; if you are an undergraduate, please enroll in 191.

Joe and Jieping will be your best friends at the end of the semester. 2 very important recommendations: make sure to come into the class with a lab partner that you know you work well with, and always start the papers early – they take a LOT of time.

best_comment: This was a great class. Vishwanath is a fantastic lecturer and very willing to answer questions. I found the pacing a lot calmer than 251a, but the material we covered (especially quantum information) was still very fascinating. The lecture notes were a real highlight of the course for me; they were very organized and worked through the material thoroughly. Would definitely recommend taking this class!
worse_comment: The first unit on quantum computing was neat. After that the class became rather dull as we covered various methods in perturbation theory and scattering. The problem sets are straightforward, the in class midterm was very easy, and the take home final was more annoying than difficult. The lecture notes are very detailed, which is nice. Overall, 251b is a lot of nuts and bolts stuff every physicist should see at least once, but it's not the most exciting material in the world.
description: Path integrals; relativistic quantum mechanics and quantum fields; identical particles; scattering theory; quantum information theory.

best_comment: The details of this course will probably vary a lot depending on the professor teaching it. However, I imagine broad similarities will remain––namely, this course is going to be more difficult than 253a by a good margin, and you will understand less than you did in 253a by a good margin. However, I found that by the end of 253b, I definitely understood some of the material in 253a a lot better, so you get that I guess. We had biweekly problem sets this year, but don't let that fool you into thinking that this course is not much work––the problem sets were sometimes devilishly difficult, and took us countless hours to solve. The final presentations were fun and good way to finish this kind of course. If you are going into theory/want to develop a good understanding of QFT, you should definitely take this course, and there aren't many alternatives, but know what you're getting into when you enroll.
description: A continuation of physics 253a. Topics include non-renormalizable theories, infrared divergences, the renormalization group, non-Abelian gauge theories, spinor helicity methods, spontaneous symmetry breaking, weak interactions, anomalies and quantum chromodynamics. Additional or alternative topics may be covered depending on time and interest.

Hands-on, experienced-based course for graduate students on teaching and communicating physics, conducted through practice, observation, feedback, and discussion. Departmental rules for teaching fellows, section and laboratory teaching, office hours, assignments, grading, and difficult classroom situations.

best_comment: People say this course is worse in the Spring, but I actually really enjoyed Prof. Pinker's lectures. He was by far my most interesting lecturer this year. I recommend attending lectures, it just helped with my buy–in for the course but they do upload recordings before the midterm and final, respectively. I attended every lecture and section and don't regret it – If you do that and do basic route memorization before each assessment, you'll end with an A.My foolproof way of studying before the midterm and final was going over the relevant lecture study questions (they're reused in the FRQs) and then just hand writing down terms I didn't feel familiar with over and over again until I memorized them. People told me this was worse in the Spring but I found the format super straightforward and doable. The most hours I put into this course was only the 2 days leading up to the midterm or final (6 hrs studying combined in the respective 2ish days leading up to the exam) and then the biggest time sink by far was the 10 page research paper, which I did very late (don't recommend) – took 8–9 hours in 2.5ish days.
worse_comment: The exams will be very difficult, and if you don't enjoy a lecture style class, you might not enjoy the course overall. However, the base knowledge in psychology I got from it was incredibly helpful.
description: Psychology 1 is not just an introduction to the field of psychology but an owner's manual for the human mind — and an opportunity to explore some of the most fascinating issues in intellectual life. After laying a foundation in concepts about the brain, evolution, information, nature and nurture, and scientific approaches to psychology, the course covers specific topics including perception, cognition, attention, learning, memory, emotion, decision making, consciousness, development, language, personality, individual differences, psychopathology, social cognition, cooperation and conflict, and love and sex.
course_requirements: Anti-Req: Cannot be taken for credit if SLS 20 already complete.

best_comment: People say this course is worse in the Spring, but I actually really enjoyed Prof. Pinker's lectures. He was by far my most interesting lecturer this year. I recommend attending lectures, it just helped with my buy–in for the course but they do upload recordings before the midterm and final, respectively. I attended every lecture and section and don't regret it – If you do that and do basic route memorization before each assessment, you'll end with an A.My foolproof way of studying before the midterm and final was going over the relevant lecture study questions (they're reused in the FRQs) and then just hand writing down terms I didn't feel familiar with over and over again until I memorized them. course_requirements: Anti-Req: Cannot be taken for credit if SLS 20 already complete.

best_comment: Definitely one of the more challenging foundational psych classes available but also one of the most fulfilling if you enjoy academic rigor and learning new things. I would honestly say this is one of the more difficult non–PSET classes I've taken overall as a student at Harvard simply because of the depth and technical details of the materials we learn as it is a bit neuroscience heavy at the start of the course–– but this is not to say at all that I would not recommend the course. As someone who enjoys an easier class here and there, I would still recommend this class to any psych student interested in cognition / language acquisition because I honestly learned so so much in this course that I don't think I would have been able to get in such depth elsewhere in the courses I've already taken. Absolutely fantastic class and the structure/organization is so clear and upfront. I absolutely applaud Dr. B and Srijani (one of my fav TFs of all time!) for their hard work this semester. I have honestly never seen a TF work harder than Srijani. Love them both! They are also both very fair and empathetic educators, which makes me respect this course even more. They are understanding of any unique circumstances you face while ensuring they accommodate you in a fair manner for all students in the course. This course has transformed the way I perceive everything in my everyday life and I highly recommend if you have the bandwidth to put in the effort and learn!
description: This course focuses on the impressive human cognitive capacity, asking what a mind is and how we can find out. We will cover great debates, methods, and foundational topics within Cognitive Science and Cognitive Psychology, spanning questions like how we think, decide, remember, talk, perceive, and make meaning. Students in this course will gain experience (a) reading and evaluating classic texts, cutting-edge empirical research, and popular science, and (b) learning analytic skills they can apply to understanding basic cognitive phenomena, and how they can be measured, described, or predicted at different levels of representation. This is a lecture course intended as a foundational course for Psychology concentrators but also intentionally accessible for the Cognitive Science-curious in related areas like linguistics, philosophy, computer science, neuroscience, education, and anthropology.
notes: This course counts toward foundational requirements for Psychology and should be taken before courses at the 1000 level or higher.
course_requirements: Pre-Req: SLS20 or PSY1 or Psychology AP=5 or Psychology IB=7 or Psyc S-1

best_comment: this is an amazing class! as someone who has been planning on going into clinical psych since before college, I was excited to finally be able to take this class once the spring semester started, but I recommend this to anyone interested in psychology and anyone in general as well since you learn a lot about mental illness, which is something that affects all of us in one way or another! Dr. Shingleton is an amazing professor and the TFs are all great, and we had some great guest speakers particularly with Dr. Abigail Judge, so this class does a great job at drawing in other sources of outside knowledge! The actual assignments are fairly straightforward, the CI submission each week are easy and not time consuming at all, and the midterms are more chill than I was expecting as long as you use their key concepts and terms guides. The memoir responses are interesting as well and not very complicated, just make sure you note down page numbers for examples of each question as you read so you save time later on.
worse_comment: I think that there were a few things that I was dissatisfied with from just like a how–should–we–approach–and–talk–about–psychology perspective, but as a course I don't think there are any standout issues.
best_gem_comment: This course is truly a gem. If you are interested in psychology, take this course. I loved attending lecture and section. The tests are very fair. It's a lot of memorization but if you studying, you will find the exams to be very easy. Another bigger aspect of you grade is the memoirs and papers. The memoirs are honestly so interesting. I loved this course. Dr. Shingleton and the rest of the teaching staff is amazing. They are so approachable and helpful.
description: Introduction to the study of psychological dysfunction. Focuses on abnormal behavior as it relates to the definition, etiology, and treatment of major symptom domains. This course will emphasize critical evaluation of the causes and mechanisms of mental illness, with special attention paid to how these disorders present clinically.
notes: Formerly named "Abnormal Psychology". This course counts toward foundational requirements for Psychology and should be taken before courses at the 1000 level or higher.
course_requirements: Pre-Req: SLS20 or PSY1 or Psychology AP=5 or Psychology IB=7 or Psyc S-1

course_title_2025: Contemporary Issues in Psychology: Intensive Cross-level Analyses 001
best_comment: I absolutely loved my Sophomore Tutorial! Your experience depends a lot on how engaged other people are in the section, as well as who teaches your section. I was lucky on both counts, the people in my section were very engaged and contributed to discussions in a valuable manner. The person teaching my section, Jada, was an absolutely wonderful TF and a great person in general. I absolutely appreciated all of the diversity in the materials she included in the syllabus, as well as how she centered some discussions around her own work. The work she does on stigma is also very related to my interests and I will actually be working with her this summer!
course_title_2026: Contemporary Issues in Psychology: Intensive Cross-level Analyses
description: Examines selected issues and phenomena in contemporary psychological research. Special attention to examining topics from a variety of perspectives, to reading primary sources in the field, and to developing thinking, writing, research, and discussion skills. This tutorial, or Psych 975, is required of concentrators upon entering the concentration, normally in the sophomore year. Letter graded.
notes: Please visit the Canvas course website for important information about the specific deadlines and processes for enrolling in this course. Section placements will occur during the registration period. Students may take this course before formally declaring Psychology as their concentration. PSY 971 and PSY 975 are interchangeable for Psychology requirements.

course_title_2025: Contemporary Issues in Psychology: Intensive Cross-level Analyses 001

best_comment: This is an excellent and super interesting course! Course content and material is the strength of this class, and Professor Davis's enthusiasm makes every class engaging.
worse_comment: I was not satisfied with this class. Dr. Davis has certain views, which she imposes upon the class. Her lectures are long tirades about material that is irrelevant to the readings, giving the appearance that she is often unprepared for class and is just "freestyling" it. She often complains about how much other stuff she had to do as an excuse for her inability to return assignments on–time. She is often three to four assignments behind in terms of grading, meaning students don't receive the feedback they need to improve on their future work. The readings are unnecessarily long compared to the amount of time she spends engaging with them. The mock trial is a cool concept but isn't very successfully implemented. That said, it's not a ton of work as a class.
description: Why do eyewitnesses often identify the wrong suspect? Why would an innocent person confess to a crime they did not commit? Can we predict who will commit a violent crime in the future? This course examines how behavioral science can be used to answer these and other questions central to the legal system. Psychologists with expertise at the intersection of psychology and criminal law conduct empirical research, interpret study findings and provide explanations to judges and juries, evaluate the mental states of criminal defendants and victims, consult with attorneys and law enforcement agencies, and serve in a variety of roles to help improve the fairness of our criminal justice system. Drawing on key areas of research from clinical and social psychology, we will delve into theories of criminal behavior, forensic evaluation, the role of bias in the courtroom, false confessions, eyewitness testimony, and deception. Research will be applied to real-world cases.

best_comment: I LOVED this course! It's a fantastic way to learn about different mental health treatments and particularly how different techniques are employed by clinical psychologists. Lectures were always so interesting, with a solid mix of open discussion, group turn–and–talk, and listening. Each class opened with a mindfulness activity which was really enjoyable (and educational), we got to hear from some featured speakers, and lots of the slideshows included engaging video examples of psychologists working with patients. Prof Santucci is phenomenal. She creates a safe space for discussion, asks great questions that make us think, and delivers the content in really accessible ways. Her kindness and compassion in her teaching made all the difference, too. Workload–wise, she kept assignments to a minimum; this class is really feasible while still feeling like you're getting the most out of your learning. The final presentation/paper are very open–ended (picking any everyday behavior to treat), so personalize it and have fun with it!
description: The goal of this course is to give you exposure to the types of evidence-based psychological interventions available for many clinical and non-clinical conditions, such as sadness, anxiety, substance use, and arguments with your significant other. Through this seminar, you will learn to notice and apply principles of psychological intervention to the world around you, not only in theory but also in practice. The seminar is not a self-help program or a training program for providing therapeutic services to others. Instead, the weekly discussions, exercises, and assignments will help you view the world through the lens of a scientist-practitioner – and apply those insights to everyday life in a scientific manner.
notes: This is the same course as PSY 1852 Clinical Psychology in Everyday Life, which has been offered previously. Students who have taken 1852 cannot enroll in this course.

best_comment: I LOVED this course! It's a fantastic way to learn about different mental health treatments and particularly how different techniques are employed by clinical psychologists. Lectures were always so interesting, with a solid mix of open discussion, group turn–and–talk, and listening. Each class opened with a mindfulness activity which was really enjoyable (and educational), we got to hear from some featured speakers, and lots of the slideshows included engaging video examples of psychologists working with patients.
